					<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading mw-first-heading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Poland</span></h1>

<div id="p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown mw-portlet mw-portlet-lang"  >
	<input type="checkbox" id="p-lang-btn-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox mw-interlanguage-selector" aria-label="Go to an article in another language. Available in 296 languages"   >
	<label id="p-lang-btn-label" for="p-lang-btn-checkbox" class="vector-dropdown-label cdx-button cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--weight-quiet cdx-button--action-progressive mw-portlet-lang-heading-296" aria-hidden="true"  ><span class="vector-icon mw-ui-icon-language-progressive mw-ui-icon-wikimedia-language-progressive"></span>

<span class="vector-dropdown-label-text">296 languages</span>
	</label>
	<div class="vector-dropdown-content">

		<div class="vector-menu-content">

			<ul class="vector-menu-content-list">

					<div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content"><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" lang="en" dir="ltr"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in Central Europe</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">"Polska" and "Rzeczpospolita Polska" redirect here. For the dance, see <a href="/wiki/Polska_(dance)" title="Polska (dance)">Polska (dance)</a>. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Poland_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Poland (disambiguation)">Poland (disambiguation)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rzeczpospolita_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Rzeczpospolita (disambiguation)">Rzeczpospolita (disambiguation)</a>.</div>

capita">39th</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a>&#160;<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488"><span class="nobold">(nominal)</span></th><td class="infobox-data">2023&#160;estimate</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div class="ib-country-fake-li">â¢&#160;Total</div></th><td class="infobox-data"><span typeof="mw:File"><span title="Increase"><img alt="Increase" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" class="mw-file-element" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300" /></span></span> $842.172 billion<sup id="cite_ref-International_Monetary_Fund_2023_13-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-International_Monetary_Fund_2023-13">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup>&#32;(<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">21st</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedbottomrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div class="ib-country-fake-li">â¢&#160;Per capita</div></th><td class="infobox-data"><span typeof="mw:File"><span title="Increase"><img alt="Increase" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" class="mw-file-element" href="#cite_note-International_Monetary_Fund_2023-13">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup>&#32;(<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">45th</a>)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Gini_coefficient" title="Gini coefficient">Gini</a>&#160;<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488"><span class="nobold">(2020)</span></th><td class="infobox-data"><span typeof="mw:File"><span title="Positive decrease"><img alt="Positive decrease" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Decrease_Positive.svg/11px-Decrease_Positive.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Decrease_Positive.svg/17px-Decrease_Positive.svg.png 1.5x, id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup><br /><span class="nowrap"><span class="tmp-color" style="color:forestgreen">low</span></span></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">HDI</a>&#160;<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488"><span class="nobold">(2021)</span></th><td class="infobox-data"><span typeof="mw:File"><span title="Increase"><img alt="Increase" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300" /></span></span>&#160;0.876<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup><br /><span class="nowrap"><span class="tmp-color" style="color:darkgreen">very high</span></span>&#160;(<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">34th</a>)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Currency</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Polish_z%C5%82oty" title="Polish zÅoty">ZÅoty</a> (<a href="/wiki/ISO_4217" title="ISO 4217">PLN</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Time zone</th><td class="infobox-data"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>+1</span> (<a href="/wiki/Central_European_Time" title="Central European Time">CET</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedbottomrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div class="ib-country-fake-li">â¢&#160;Summer&#160;(<a href="/wiki/Daylight_saving_time" title="Daylight saving time">DST</a>)</div></th><td class="infobox-data"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>+2</span> (<a href="/wiki/Central_European_Summer_Time" title="Central European Summer Time">CEST</a>)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Date format</th><td class="infobox-data">dd.mm.yyyy (<a href="/wiki/Common_Era" title="Common Era">CE</a>)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Left-_and_right-hand_traffic" title="Left- and right-hand traffic">Driving side</a></th><td class="infobox-data">right</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Poland" title="Telephone numbers in Poland">Calling code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Poland" title="Telephone numbers in Poland">+48</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166" title="ISO 3166">ISO 3166 code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-2:PL" title="ISO 3166-2:PL">PL</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/.pl" title=".pl">.pl</a> <sup>[a]</sup></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-full-data"><div class="ib-country-fn"><ol class="ib-country-fn-alpha">
<li value="1">Also .eu, shared with other European Union member states.</li>
</ol></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Poland</b> (<a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a>: <i lang="pl">Polska</i> <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="pl-Latn-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">&#91;ËpÉlska&#93;</a></span> <span class="ext-phonos skin-invert"><span data-nosnippet="" id="ooui-php-1" class="ext-phonos-PhonosButton noexcerpt ext-phonos-PhonosButton-emptylabel oo-ui-widget oo-ui-widget-enabled oo-ui-buttonElement oo-ui-buttonElement-frameless oo-ui-iconElement oo-ui-buttonWidget" data-ooui="{&quot;_&quot;:&quot;mw.Phonos.PhonosButton&quot;,&quot;href&quot;:&quot;\/\/upload.wikimedia.org\/wikipedia\/commons\/transcoded\/9\/98\/Pl-Polska.ogg\/Pl-Polska.ogg.mp3&quot;,&quot;rel&quot;:[&quot;nofollow&quot;],&quot;framed&quot;:false,&quot;icon&quot;:&quot;volumeUp&quot;,&quot;data&quot;:{&quot;ipa&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;text&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;lang&quot;:&quot;en&quot;,&quot;wikibase&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;file&quot;:&quot;Pl-Polska.ogg&quot;},&quot;classes&quot;:[&quot;ext-phonos-PhonosButton&quot;,&quot;noexcerpt&quot;,&quot;ext-phonos-PhonosButton-emptylabel&quot;]}"><a role="button" tabindex="0" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/9/98/Pl-Polska.ogg/Pl-Polska.ogg.mp3" rel="nofollow" aria-label="Play audio" title="Play audio" class="oo-ui-buttonElement-button"><span class="oo-ui-iconElement-icon oo-ui-icon-volumeUp"></span><span class="oo-ui-labelElement-label"></span><span class="oo-ui-indicatorElement-indicator oo-ui-indicatorElement-noIndicator"></span></a></span><sup class="ext-phonos-attribution noexcerpt navigation-not-searchable"><a href="/wiki/File:Pl-Polska.ogg" title="File:Pl-Polska.ogg">â</a></sup></span>), officially the <b>Republic of Poland</b>,<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;c&#93;</a></sup> is a country in <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central Europe</a>. It is divided into 16 administrative <a href="/wiki/Voivodeships_of_Poland" title="Voivodeships of Poland">voivodeship</a> provinces, covering an area of 312,696&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (120,733&#160;sq&#160;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> Poland has a population of over 38 million and is the fifth-most populous <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">member state of the European Union</a>. <a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">Warsaw</a> is the nation's capital and largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Poland" title="List of cities and towns in Poland">metropolis</a>. Other major cities include <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="KrakÃ³w">KrakÃ³w</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw" title="WrocÅaw">WrocÅaw</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C5%81%C3%B3d%C5%BA" title="ÅÃ³dÅº">ÅÃ³dÅº</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pozna%C5%84" title="PoznaÅ">PoznaÅ</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk" title="GdaÅsk">GdaÅsk</a>.
</p><p>Poland has a <a href="/wiki/Temperateness" class="mw-redirect" title="Temperateness">temperate transitional</a> climate, and its territory traverses the <a href="/wiki/North_European_Plain" title="North European Plain">Central European Plain</a>, extending from the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a> in the north to the <a href="/wiki/Sudetes" title="Sudetes">Sudetes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains" title="Carpathian Mountains">Carpathian Mountains</a> in the south. The longest Polish river is the <a href="/wiki/Vistula" title="Vistula">Vistula</a>, and Poland's highest point is <a href="/wiki/Mount_Rysy" class="mw-redirect" title="Mount Rysy">Mount Rysy</a>, situated in the <a href="/wiki/Tatra_Mountains" title="Tatra Mountains">Tatra mountain range</a> of the Carpathians. The country is bordered by <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">Lithuania</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> to the northeast,<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;d&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> to the east, <a href="/wiki/Slovakia" title="Slovakia">Slovakia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic">Czech Republic</a> to the south, and <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> to the west. It also shares <a href="/wiki/Maritime_boundary" title="Maritime boundary">maritime boundaries</a> with <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">Sweden</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Prehistory_and_protohistory_of_Poland" title="Prehistory and protohistory of Poland">Prehistoric human activity on Polish soil</a> dates to the <a href="/wiki/Lower_Paleolithic" title="Lower Paleolithic">Lower Paleolithic</a>, with continuous settlement since the end of the <a href="/wiki/Last_Glacial_Period" title="Last Glacial Period">Last Glacial Period</a>. Culturally diverse throughout <a href="/wiki/Late_antiquity" title="Late antiquity">late antiquity</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Early_Middle_Ages" title="Early Middle Ages">early medieval period</a> the region became inhabited by the tribal <a href="/wiki/Polans_(western)" title="Polans (western)">Polans</a>, who gave <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Poland" title="Names of Poland">Poland its name</a>. The process of establishing proper statehood, which began in 966, coincided with the conversion of a <a href="/wiki/Mieszko_I" title="Mieszko I">pagan ruler of the Polans</a> to Christianity, under the auspices of the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Roman Catholic Church</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Poland" title="Kingdom of Poland">Kingdom of Poland</a> emerged in 1025, and in 1569 cemented its long-standing <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_union" title="PolishâLithuanian union">association with Lithuania</a>, thus forming the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth">PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth</a>. At the time, the Commonwealth was one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_modern_great_powers" title="List of modern great powers">great powers</a> of Europe, with a <a href="/wiki/Golden_Liberty" title="Golden Liberty">uniquely liberal</a> political system which adopted <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_3_May_1791" title="Constitution of 3 May 1791">Europe's first modern constitution</a> in 1791.
</p><p>With the passing of the prosperous <a href="/wiki/Polish_Golden_Age" title="Polish Golden Age">Polish Golden Age</a>, the country was <a href="/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland" title="Partitions of Poland">partitioned by neighbouring states</a> at the end of the 18th century. Poland regained its <a href="/wiki/National_Independence_Day_(Poland)" title="National Independence Day (Poland)">independence</a> in 1918 as the <a href="/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic" title="Second Polish Republic">Second Polish Republic</a> and successfully <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Warsaw_(1920)" title="Battle of Warsaw (1920)">defended</a> it in the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Soviet_War" title="PolishâSoviet War">PolishâSoviet War</a> from 1919 to 1921. In September 1939, the <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland" title="Invasion of Poland">invasion of Poland</a> by <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Germany</a> <a href="/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Poland" title="Soviet invasion of Poland">and the</a> <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> marked the beginning of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, which resulted in <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_Poland" title="The Holocaust in Poland">the Holocaust</a> and millions of <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_(1939%E2%80%931945)" title="History of Poland (1939â1945)">Polish casualties</a>. Forced into the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a> in the global <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Polish_People%27s_Republic" title="Polish People&#39;s Republic">Polish People's Republic</a> was a founding signatory of the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Pact" title="Warsaw Pact">Warsaw Pact</a>. Through the emergence and contributions of the <a href="/wiki/Solidarity_(Polish_trade_union)" title="Solidarity (Polish trade union)">Solidarity movement</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Polish_United_Workers%27_Party" title="Polish United Workers&#39; Party">communist government</a> was <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_(1945%E2%80%931989)" title="History of Poland (1945â1989)">dissolved</a> and Poland re-established itself as a <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democratic state</a> in 1989.
</p><p>Poland is a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a>, with its <a href="/wiki/Bicameralism" title="Bicameralism">bicameral legislature</a> comprising the <a href="/wiki/Sejm" title="Sejm">Sejm</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_Poland" title="Senate of Poland">Senate</a>. It is a <a href="/wiki/Developed_market" title="Developed market">developed market</a> and a <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_high-income_economy" title="World Bank high-income economy">high-income economy</a>. Considered a <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a>, Poland has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">sixth-largest</a> economy in the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> by <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP (nominal)</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">fifth-largest by GDP (PPP)</a>. It provides a <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">very high standard of living</a>, safety, and <a href="/wiki/Economic_freedom" title="Economic freedom">economic freedom</a>, as well as free <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Poland" title="Education in Poland">university education</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Poland" title="Health care in Poland">universal health care</a> system. The country has 17 <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Poland" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Poland">World Heritage Sites</a>, 15 of which are cultural. Poland is a founding member state of the United Nations, as well as a member of the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>, <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>, <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> (including the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen Area</a>).
</p>
<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc" />
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Poland" title="Names of Poland">Names of Poland</a></div>
<p>The native <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a> name for Poland is <span title="Polish-language text"><i lang="pl">Polska</i></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> The name is derived from the <a href="/wiki/Polans_(western)" title="Polans (western)">Polans</a>, a <a href="/wiki/West_Slavs" title="West Slavs">West Slavic</a> tribe who inhabited the <a href="/wiki/Warta_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Warta River">Warta River</a> basin of present-day <a href="/wiki/Greater_Poland" title="Greater Poland">Greater Poland</a> region (6thâ8th century CE).<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> The tribe's name stems from the <a href="/wiki/Proto-Slavic" class="mw-redirect" title="Proto-Slavic">Proto-Slavic</a> noun <i>pole</i> meaning field, which in-itself originates from the <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_language" title="Proto-Indo-European language">Proto-Indo-European</a> word <i>*plehâ-</i> indicating flatland.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> The etymology alludes to the <a href="/wiki/Topography" title="Topography">topography</a> of the region and the flat landscape of Greater Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> form <i>Polonia</i> was widely used throughout Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-Buko_2014_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Buko_2014-24">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The country's alternative archaic name is <i><a href="/wiki/Lechia" class="mw-redirect" title="Lechia">Lechia</a></i> and its root syllable remains in official use in several languages, notably <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">Hungarian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">Lithuanian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Exonym" class="mw-redirect" title="Exonym">exonym</a> possibly derives from either <a href="/wiki/Lech_and_Czech" class="mw-redirect" title="Lech and Czech">Lech</a>, a legendary ruler of the <a href="/wiki/Lechites" title="Lechites">Lechites</a>, or from the <a href="/wiki/Lendians" title="Lendians">Lendians</a>, a West Slavic tribe that dwelt on the south-easternmost edge of <a href="/wiki/Lesser_Poland" title="Lesser Poland">Lesser Poland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Dabrowski_2014_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dabrowski_2014-26">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> The origin of the tribe's name lies in the <a href="/wiki/Old_Polish_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Old Polish language">Old Polish</a> word <i>lÄda</i> (plain).<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup> Initially, both names <i>Lechia</i> and <i>Polonia</i> were used interchangeably when referring to Poland by chroniclers during the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland" title="History of Poland">History of Poland</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_and_protohistory">Prehistory and protohistory</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Stone-Age_Poland" title="Stone-Age Poland">Stone-Age Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bronze-_and_Iron-Age_Poland" title="Bronze- and Iron-Age Poland">Bronze- and Iron-Age Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poland_in_antiquity" title="Poland in antiquity">Poland in antiquity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Early_Slavs" title="Early Slavs">Early Slavs</a>, <a href="/wiki/West_Slavs" title="West Slavs">West Slavs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lechites" title="Lechites">Lechites</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Poland_in_the_Early_Middle_Ages" title="Poland in the Early Middle Ages">Poland in the Early Middle Ages</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Biskupin1.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Biskupin1.jpg/220px-Biskupin1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="129" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Biskupin1.jpg/330px-Biskupin1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Biskupin1.jpg/440px-Biskupin1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3237" data-file-height="1902" /></a><figcaption>A reconstruction of a <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lusatian_culture" title="Lusatian culture">Lusatian culture</a> settlement in <a href="/wiki/Biskupin" title="Biskupin">Biskupin</a>, 8th century BC</figcaption></figure>
<p>The first <a href="/wiki/Stone_Age" title="Stone Age">Stone Age</a> archaic humans and <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_erectus" title="Homo erectus">Homo erectus</a></i> species settled what was to become Poland approximately 500,000 years ago, though the ensuing hostile climate prevented early humans from founding more permanent encampments.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup> The arrival of <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_sapiens" class="mw-redirect" title="Homo sapiens">Homo sapiens</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/Early_European_modern_humans" class="mw-redirect" title="Early European modern humans">anatomically modern humans</a> coincided with the climatic discontinuity at the end of the <a href="/wiki/Last_Glacial_Period" title="Last Glacial Period">Last Glacial Period</a> (<a href="/wiki/Weichselian_glaciation" title="Weichselian glaciation">Northern Polish glaciation</a> 10,000 BC), when Poland became habitable.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> excavations indicated broad-ranging development in that era; the earliest evidence of European cheesemaking (5500 BC) was discovered in Polish <a href="/wiki/Kuyavia" title="Kuyavia">Kuyavia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Bronocice_pot" title="Bronocice pot">Bronocice pot</a> is incised with the earliest known depiction of what may be a wheeled vehicle (3400 BC).<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The period spanning the <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Early_Iron_Age" class="mw-redirect" title="Early Iron Age">Early Iron Age</a> (1300 BCâ500 BC) was marked by an increase in population density, establishment of <a href="/wiki/Palisade" title="Palisade">palisaded</a> settlements (<a href="/wiki/Gord_(archaeology)" title="Gord (archaeology)">gords</a>) and the expansion of <a href="/wiki/Lusatian_culture" title="Lusatian culture">Lusatian culture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup> A significant archaeological find from <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_and_protohistory_of_Poland" title="Prehistory and protohistory of Poland">the protohistory of Poland</a> is a fortified settlement at <a href="/wiki/Biskupin" title="Biskupin">Biskupin</a>, attributed to the Lusatian culture of the <a href="/wiki/Late_Bronze_Age" class="mw-redirect" title="Late Bronze Age">Late Bronze Age</a> (mid-8th century BC).<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Throughout <a href="/wiki/Classical_antiquity" title="Classical antiquity">antiquity</a> (400 BCâ500 AD), many distinct ancient populations inhabited the territory of present-day Poland, notably <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celtic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scythia" title="Scythia">Scythian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sarmatians" title="Sarmatians">Sarmatian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Balts" title="Balts">Baltic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Early_Slavs" title="Early Slavs">Slavic</a> tribes.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup> Furthermore, archaeological findings confirmed the presence of <a href="/wiki/Roman_Legions" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Legions">Roman Legions</a> sent to protect the <a href="/wiki/Amber_Road" title="Amber Road">amber trade</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Polish_tribes" title="Polish tribes">Polish tribes</a> emerged following the <a href="/wiki/Migration_Period#Second_wave" title="Migration Period">second wave of the Migration Period</a> around the 6th century AD;<sup id="cite_ref-Buko_2014_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Buko_2014-24">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> they were <a href="/wiki/Slavs" title="Slavs">Slavic</a> and may have included assimilated remnants of peoples that earlier dwelled in the area.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup> Beginning in the early 10th century, the <a href="/wiki/Polans_(western)" title="Polans (western)">Polans</a> would come to dominate other <a href="/wiki/Lechites" title="Lechites">Lechitic</a> tribes in the region, initially forming a tribal federation and later a centralised monarchial state.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Kingdom_of_Poland">Kingdom of Poland</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_during_the_Piast_dynasty" title="History of Poland during the Piast dynasty">History of Poland during the Piast dynasty</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_during_the_Jagiellonian_dynasty" title="History of Poland during the Jagiellonian dynasty">History of Poland during the Jagiellonian dynasty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Baptism_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Baptism of Poland">Baptism of Poland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Poland" title="Kingdom of Poland">Kingdom of Poland</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Poland960.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Poland960.png/220px-Poland960.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="217" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Poland960.png/330px-Poland960.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Poland960.png/440px-Poland960.png 2x" data-file-width="520" data-file-height="513" /></a><figcaption>Poland under the rule of <a href="/wiki/Mieszko_I" title="Mieszko I">Mieszko I</a>, whose acceptance of Christianity under the auspices of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholic Church">Roman Church</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Baptism_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Baptism of Poland">Baptism of Poland</a> marked the beginning of statehood in 966</figcaption></figure>
<p>Poland began to form into a recognisable unitary and territorial entity around the middle of the 10th century under the <a href="/wiki/Piast_dynasty" title="Piast dynasty">Piast dynasty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup> In 966, ruler of the Polans <a href="/wiki/Mieszko_I_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Mieszko I of Poland">Mieszko I</a> accepted Christianity under the auspices of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholic Church">Roman Church</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Baptism_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Baptism of Poland">Baptism of Poland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup> In 968, a missionary <a href="/wiki/Bishopric" class="mw-redirect" title="Bishopric">bishopric</a> was established in <a href="/wiki/Pozna%C5%84" title="PoznaÅ">PoznaÅ</a>. An <a href="/wiki/Incipit" title="Incipit">incipit</a> titled <a href="/wiki/Dagome_iudex" title="Dagome iudex">Dagome iudex</a> first defined Poland's geographical boundaries with its capital in <a href="/wiki/Gniezno" title="Gniezno">Gniezno</a> and affirmed that its monarchy was under the protection of the <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_See" class="mw-redirect" title="Apostolic See">Apostolic See</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Curta_2016_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Curta_2016-44">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> The country's early origins were described by <a href="/wiki/Gallus_Anonymus" title="Gallus Anonymus">Gallus Anonymus</a> in <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la"><a href="/wiki/Gesta_principum_Polonorum" title="Gesta principum Polonorum">Gesta principum Polonorum</a></i></span>, the oldest Polish chronicle.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup> An important national event of the period was the <a href="/wiki/Martyrdom" class="mw-redirect" title="Martyrdom">martyrdom</a> of <a href="/wiki/Adalbert_of_Prague" title="Adalbert of Prague">Saint Adalbert</a>, who was killed by <a href="/wiki/Old_Prussians" title="Old Prussians">Prussian</a> pagans in 997 and whose remains were reputedly bought back for their weight in gold by Mieszko's successor, <a href="/wiki/Boles%C5%82aw_I_the_Brave" title="BolesÅaw I the Brave">BolesÅaw I the Brave</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Curta_2016_44-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Curta_2016-44">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1000, at the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Gniezno" title="Congress of Gniezno">Congress of Gniezno</a>, BolesÅaw obtained the right of <a href="/wiki/Investiture" title="Investiture">investiture</a> from <a href="/wiki/Otto_III,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Otto III, Holy Roman Emperor">Otto III, Holy Roman Emperor</a>, who assented to the creation of additional bishoprics and an archdioceses in Gniezno.<sup id="cite_ref-Curta_2016_44-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Curta_2016-44">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> Three new dioceses were subsequently established in <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="KrakÃ³w">KrakÃ³w</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ko%C5%82obrzeg" title="KoÅobrzeg">KoÅobrzeg</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw" title="WrocÅaw">WrocÅaw</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup> Also, Otto bestowed upon BolesÅaw royal <a href="/wiki/Regalia" title="Regalia">regalia</a> and a replica of the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Lance" title="Holy Lance">Holy Lance</a>, which were later used at his coronation as the first <a href="/wiki/List_of_Polish_monarchs" title="List of Polish monarchs">King of Poland</a> in <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;1025</span>, when BolesÅaw received permission for his coronation from <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_XIX" title="Pope John XIX">Pope John XIX</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup> BolesÅaw also expanded the realm considerably by seizing parts of German <a href="/wiki/Lusatia" title="Lusatia">Lusatia</a>, Czech <a href="/wiki/Moravia" title="Moravia">Moravia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Upper_Hungary" title="Upper Hungary">Upper Hungary</a> and southwestern regions of the <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus&#39;">Kievan Rus'</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Casimir_the_Great_by_Leopold_L%C3%B6ffler.PNG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Casimir_the_Great_by_Leopold_L%C3%B6ffler.PNG/170px-Casimir_the_Great_by_Leopold_L%C3%B6ffler.PNG" decoding="async" width="170" height="265" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Casimir_the_Great_by_Leopold_L%C3%B6ffler.PNG/255px-Casimir_the_Great_by_Leopold_L%C3%B6ffler.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Casimir_the_Great_by_Leopold_L%C3%B6ffler.PNG/340px-Casimir_the_Great_by_Leopold_L%C3%B6ffler.PNG 2x" data-file-width="470" data-file-height="734" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Casimir_III_the_Great" title="Casimir III the Great">Casimir III the Great</a> is the only Polish king to receive the title of <i>Great</i>. He built extensively during his reign, and reformed the Polish army along with the country's legal code, 1333â70.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The transition from <a href="/wiki/Slavic_paganism" title="Slavic paganism">paganism</a> in Poland was not instantaneous and resulted in the <a href="/wiki/Pagan_reaction_in_Poland" title="Pagan reaction in Poland">pagan reaction of the 1030s</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> In 1031, <a href="/wiki/Mieszko_II_Lambert" title="Mieszko II Lambert">Mieszko II Lambert</a> lost the title of king and fled amidst the violence.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> The unrest led to the transfer of the capital to KrakÃ³w in 1038 by <a href="/wiki/Casimir_I_the_Restorer" title="Casimir I the Restorer">Casimir I the Restorer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup> In 1076, <a href="/wiki/Boles%C5%82aw_II_the_Generous" class="mw-redirect" title="BolesÅaw II the Generous">BolesÅaw II</a> re-instituted the office of king, but was banished in 1079 for murdering his opponent, <a href="/wiki/Stanislaus_of_Szczepan%C3%B3w" title="Stanislaus of SzczepanÃ³w">Bishop Stanislaus</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup> In 1138, the country <a href="/wiki/Testament_of_Boles%C5%82aw_III_Wrymouth" title="Testament of BolesÅaw III Wrymouth">fragmented</a> into five principalities when <a href="/wiki/Boles%C5%82aw_III_Wrymouth" title="BolesÅaw III Wrymouth">BolesÅaw III Wrymouth</a> divided his lands among his sons.<sup id="cite_ref-Dabrowski_2014_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dabrowski_2014-26">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> These comprised <a href="/wiki/Lesser_Poland" title="Lesser Poland">Lesser Poland</a>, Greater Poland, <a href="/wiki/Silesia" title="Silesia">Silesia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Masovia" class="mw-redirect" title="Masovia">Masovia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sandomierz" title="Sandomierz">Sandomierz</a>, with intermittent hold over <a href="/wiki/Pomerania" title="Pomerania">Pomerania</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup> In 1226, <a href="/wiki/Konrad_I_of_Masovia" title="Konrad I of Masovia">Konrad I of Masovia</a> invited the <a href="/wiki/Teutonic_Knights" class="mw-redirect" title="Teutonic Knights">Teutonic Knights</a> to aid in combating the <a href="/wiki/Balts" title="Balts">Baltic</a> Prussians; a decision that later led to centuries of warfare with the Knights.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the first half of the 13th century, <a href="/wiki/Henry_I_the_Bearded" class="mw-redirect" title="Henry I the Bearded">Henry I the Bearded</a> and <a href="/wiki/Henry_II_the_Pious" title="Henry II the Pious">Henry II the Pious</a> aimed to unite the fragmented dukedoms, but the <a href="/wiki/First_Mongol_invasion_of_Poland" title="First Mongol invasion of Poland">Mongol invasion</a> and the death of Henry II in <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Legnica" title="Battle of Legnica">battle</a> hindered the unification.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup> As a result of the devastation which followed, depopulation and the demand for craft labour spurred a migration of <a href="/wiki/History_of_Germans_in_Poland" title="History of Germans in Poland">German and Flemish settlers</a> into Poland, which was encouraged by the Polish dukes.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup> In 1264, the <a href="/wiki/Statute_of_Kalisz" title="Statute of Kalisz">Statute of Kalisz</a> introduced unprecedented autonomy for the <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Poland" title="History of the Jews in Poland">Polish Jews</a>, who came to Poland fleeing persecution elsewhere in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1320, <a href="/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_I_the_Elbow-high" class="mw-redirect" title="WÅadysÅaw I the Elbow-high">WÅadysÅaw I the Short</a> became the first king of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Poland_(1025%E2%80%931385)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Poland (1025â1385)">a reunified Poland</a> since <a href="/wiki/Przemys%C5%82_II" title="PrzemysÅ II">PrzemysÅ II</a> in 1296,<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup> and the first to be crowned at <a href="/wiki/Wawel_Cathedral" title="Wawel Cathedral">Wawel Cathedral</a> in KrakÃ³w.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup>
Beginning in 1333, the reign of <a href="/wiki/Casimir_III_the_Great" title="Casimir III the Great">Casimir III the Great</a> was marked by developments in <a href="/wiki/Trail_of_the_Eagle%27s_Nests" title="Trail of the Eagle&#39;s Nests">castle infrastructure</a>, army, judiciary and <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Krak%C3%B3w" title="Congress of KrakÃ³w">diplomacy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup> Under his authority, Poland transformed into a major European power; he instituted Polish rule over <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ruthenia" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Ruthenia">Ruthenia</a> in 1340 and imposed quarantine that prevented the spread of <a href="/wiki/Black_Death" title="Black Death">Black Death</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup> In 1364, Casimir inaugurated the <a href="/wiki/Jagiellonian_University" title="Jagiellonian University">University of KrakÃ³w</a>, one of the oldest institutions of higher learning in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup> Upon his death in 1370, the Piast dynasty came to an end.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup> He was succeeded by his closest male relative, <a href="/wiki/Louis_I_of_Hungary" title="Louis I of Hungary">Louis of Anjou</a>, who ruled Poland, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary" title="Kingdom of Hungary">Hungary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Croatia_in_personal_union_with_Hungary" title="Croatia in personal union with Hungary">Croatia</a> in a <a href="/wiki/Personal_union" title="Personal union">personal union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Davies_2001_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davies_2001-68">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup> Louis' younger daughter <a href="/wiki/Jadwiga_of_Poland" title="Jadwiga of Poland">Jadwiga</a> became Poland's first female monarch in 1384.<sup id="cite_ref-Davies_2001_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davies_2001-68">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Battle_of_Tannenberg.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Battle_of_Tannenberg.jpg/170px-Battle_of_Tannenberg.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="204" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Battle_of_Tannenberg.jpg/255px-Battle_of_Tannenberg.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Battle_of_Tannenberg.jpg/340px-Battle_of_Tannenberg.jpg 2x" data-file-width="551" data-file-height="662" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Grunwald" title="Battle of Grunwald">Battle of Grunwald</a> was fought against the <a href="/wiki/Teutonic_Knights" class="mw-redirect" title="Teutonic Knights">German Order of Teutonic Knights</a>, and resulted in a decisive victory for the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Poland_(1385%E2%80%931569)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Poland (1385â1569)">Kingdom of Poland</a>, 15 July 1410.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In 1386, Jadwiga of Poland entered a marriage of convenience with <a href="/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_II_Jagie%C5%82%C5%82o" title="WÅadysÅaw II JagieÅÅo">WÅadysÅaw II JagieÅÅo</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duke_of_Lithuania" class="mw-redirect" title="Grand Duke of Lithuania">Grand Duke of Lithuania</a>, thus forming the <a href="/wiki/Jagiellonian_dynasty" title="Jagiellonian dynasty">Jagiellonian dynasty</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_union" title="PolishâLithuanian union">PolishâLithuanian union</a> which spanned the late <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a> and early <a href="/wiki/Modern_history" class="mw-redirect" title="Modern history">Modern Era</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup> The partnership between Poles and Lithuanians brought the vast multi-ethnic <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">Lithuanian</a> territories into Poland's sphere of influence and proved beneficial for its inhabitants, who coexisted in one of the largest European <a href="/wiki/Personal_union" title="Personal union">political entities</a> of the time.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the Baltic Sea region, the struggle of Poland and Lithuania with the <a href="/wiki/Teutonic_Knights" class="mw-redirect" title="Teutonic Knights">Teutonic Knights</a> continued and culminated at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Grunwald" title="Battle of Grunwald">Battle of Grunwald</a> in 1410, where a combined Polish-Lithuanian army inflicted a decisive victory against them.<sup id="cite_ref-Wyrozumski_1986_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wyrozumski_1986-71">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup> In 1466, after the <a href="/wiki/Thirteen_Years%27_War_(1454%E2%80%9366)" class="mw-redirect" title="Thirteen Years&#39; War (1454â66)">Thirteen Years' War</a>, king <a href="/wiki/Casimir_IV_Jagiellon" title="Casimir IV Jagiellon">Casimir IV Jagiellon</a> gave royal consent to the <a href="/wiki/Second_Peace_of_Thorn_(1466)" title="Second Peace of Thorn (1466)">Peace of Thorn</a>, which created the future <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Prussia" title="Duchy of Prussia">Duchy of Prussia</a> under Polish suzerainty and forced the Prussian rulers to pay <a href="/wiki/Homage_(feudal)" title="Homage (feudal)">tributes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Dabrowski_2014_26-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dabrowski_2014-26">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> The Jagiellonian dynasty also established dynastic control over the kingdoms of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Bohemia" title="Kingdom of Bohemia">Bohemia</a> (1471 onwards) and Hungary.<sup id="cite_ref-Norman_Davies_1996_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Norman_Davies_1996-72">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup> In the south, Poland confronted the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Khanate" title="Crimean Khanate">Crimean Tatars</a>, and in the east helped Lithuania to combat <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow" class="mw-redirect" title="Grand Duchy of Moscow">Russia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Dabrowski_2014_26-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dabrowski_2014-26">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Poland was developing as a <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudal</a> state, with a predominantly agricultural economy and an increasingly powerful <a href="/wiki/Landed_nobility" title="Landed nobility">landed nobility</a> that confined the population to private manorial farmsteads, or <a href="/wiki/Folwark" title="Folwark">folwarks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup> In 1493, <a href="/wiki/John_I_Albert" title="John I Albert">John I Albert</a> sanctioned the creation of a <a href="/wiki/Bicameral_parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="Bicameral parliament">bicameral parliament</a> composed of a lower house, the <a href="/wiki/Sejm" title="Sejm">Sejm</a>, and an upper house, the <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_Poland" title="Senate of Poland">Senate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Nihil_novi" title="Nihil novi">Nihil novi</a></i> act adopted by the Polish <a href="/wiki/General_Sejm" class="mw-redirect" title="General Sejm">General Sejm</a> in 1505, transferred most of the <a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">legislative power</a> from the monarch to the parliament, an event which marked the beginning of the period known as <a href="/wiki/Golden_Liberty" title="Golden Liberty">Golden Liberty</a>, when the state was ruled by the seemingly free and equal <a href="/wiki/Szlachta" title="Szlachta">Polish nobles</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Wawel_View.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Wawel_View.jpg/280px-Wawel_View.jpg" decoding="async" width="280" height="121" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Wawel_View.jpg/420px-Wawel_View.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Wawel_View.jpg/560px-Wawel_View.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3463" data-file-height="1494" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Wawel_Castle" title="Wawel Castle">Wawel Castle</a> in <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="KrakÃ³w">KrakÃ³w</a>, seat of <a href="/wiki/List_of_Polish_monarchs" title="List of Polish monarchs">Polish kings</a> from 1038 until the capital was moved to <a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">Warsaw</a> in 1596</figcaption></figure>
<p>The 16th century saw <a href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a> movements making deep inroads into Polish Christianity, which resulted in the establishment of policies promoting religious tolerance, unique in Europe at that time.<sup id="cite_ref-Knoll_2011_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Knoll_2011-76">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup> This tolerance allowed the country to avoid the religious turmoil and <a href="/wiki/European_wars_of_religion" title="European wars of religion">wars of religion</a> that beset Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-Knoll_2011_76-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Knoll_2011-76">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup> In Poland, <a href="/wiki/Nontrinitarianism" title="Nontrinitarianism">Nontrinitarian Christianity</a> became the doctrine of the so-called <a href="/wiki/Polish_Brethren" title="Polish Brethren">Polish Brethren</a>, who separated from their <a href="/wiki/Calvinism" title="Calvinism">Calvinist</a> denomination and became the co-founders of global <a href="/wiki/Unitarianism" title="Unitarianism">Unitarianism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The European <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> evoked under <a href="/wiki/Sigismund_I_the_Old" title="Sigismund I the Old">Sigismund I the Old</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sigismund_II_Augustus" title="Sigismund II Augustus">Sigismund II Augustus</a> a sense of urgency in the need to promote a <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_in_Poland" title="Renaissance in Poland">cultural awakening</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Dabrowski_2014_26-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dabrowski_2014-26">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Golden_Age" title="Polish Golden Age">Polish Golden Age</a>, the nation's economy and culture flourished.<sup id="cite_ref-Dabrowski_2014_26-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dabrowski_2014-26">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> The Italian-born <a href="/wiki/Bona_Sforza" title="Bona Sforza">Bona Sforza</a>, daughter of the <a href="/wiki/Gian_Galeazzo_Sforza" title="Gian Galeazzo Sforza">Duke of Milan</a> and queen consort to Sigismund I, made considerable contributions to <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Poland" title="Architecture of Poland">architecture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polish_cuisine" title="Polish cuisine">cuisine</a>, language and court customs at <a href="/wiki/Wawel_Castle" title="Wawel Castle">Wawel Castle</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Dabrowski_2014_26-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dabrowski_2014-26">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Polish.E2.80.93Lithuanian_Commonwealth"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="PolishâLithuanian_Commonwealth">PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_in_the_Early_Modern_era_(1569%E2%80%931795)" class="mw-redirect" title="History of Poland in the Early Modern era (1569â1795)">History of Poland in the Early Modern era (1569â1795)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_the_Kingdom_of_Poland" title="Crown of the Kingdom of Poland">Crown of the Kingdom of Poland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth">PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_in_1619.PNG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_in_1619.PNG/280px-Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_in_1619.PNG" decoding="async" width="280" height="219" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_in_1619.PNG/420px-Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_in_1619.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_in_1619.PNG/560px-Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_in_1619.PNG 2x" data-file-width="1996" data-file-height="1558" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth</a> at its greatest extent in 1619. At that time it was the largest country in Europe</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Lublin" title="Union of Lublin">Union of Lublin</a> of 1569 established the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth">PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth</a>, a unified federal state with an <a href="/wiki/Elective_monarchy" title="Elective monarchy">elective monarchy</a>, but largely governed by the nobility.<sup id="cite_ref-Butterwick_2021_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Butterwick_2021-78">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup> The latter coincided with a period of prosperity; the Polish-dominated union thereafter becoming a leading power and a major cultural entity, exercising political control over parts of Central, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southeastern_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Southeastern Europe">Southeastern</a> and Northern Europe. The PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth occupied approximately 1&#160;million&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (390,000&#160;sq&#160;mi) <a href="/wiki/Truce_of_Deulino" title="Truce of Deulino">at its peak</a> and was the largest state in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup> Simultaneously, Poland imposed <a href="/wiki/Polonisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Polonisation">Polonisation</a> policies in newly acquired territories which were met with resistance from ethnic and religious minorities.<sup id="cite_ref-Butterwick_2021_78-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Butterwick_2021-78">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1573, <a href="/wiki/Henry_III_of_France" title="Henry III of France">Henry de Valois of France</a>, the first elected king, approbated the <a href="/wiki/Henrician_Articles" title="Henrician Articles">Henrician Articles</a> which obliged future monarchs to respect the rights of nobles.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> His successor, <a href="/wiki/Stephen_B%C3%A1thory" title="Stephen BÃ¡thory">Stephen BÃ¡thory</a>, led a successful <a href="/wiki/Livonian_campaign_of_Stephen_B%C3%A1thory" title="Livonian campaign of Stephen BÃ¡thory">campaign</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Livonian_War" title="Livonian War">Livonian War</a>, granting Poland more <a href="/wiki/Livonia" title="Livonia">lands across the eastern shores</a> of the Baltic Sea.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup> State affairs were then headed by <a href="/wiki/Jan_Zamoyski" title="Jan Zamoyski">Jan Zamoyski</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Chancellor_(Poland)" title="Chancellor (Poland)">Crown Chancellor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup> In 1592, <a href="/wiki/Sigismund_III_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Sigismund III of Poland">Sigismund III of Poland</a> succeeded his father, <a href="/wiki/John_III_of_Sweden" title="John III of Sweden">John Vasa</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sweden" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Sweden">Sweden</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Polish-Swedish_union" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish-Swedish union">Polish-Swedish union</a> endured until 1599, when he was <a href="/wiki/War_against_Sigismund" title="War against Sigismund">deposed</a> by the Swedes.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Jan_III_Schultz.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Jan_III_Schultz.jpg/170px-Jan_III_Schultz.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="228" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Jan_III_Schultz.jpg/255px-Jan_III_Schultz.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Jan_III_Schultz.jpg/340px-Jan_III_Schultz.jpg 2x" data-file-width="564" data-file-height="758" /></a><figcaption>King <a href="/wiki/John_III_Sobieski" title="John III Sobieski">John III Sobieski</a> defeated the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Turks</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vienna" title="Battle of Vienna">Battle of Vienna</a> on 12 September 1683.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In 1609, Sigismund <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Muscovite_War_(1605%E2%80%931618)" class="mw-redirect" title="PolishâMuscovite War (1605â1618)">invaded</a> <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">Russia</a> which was engulfed in a <a href="/wiki/Time_of_Troubles" title="Time of Troubles">civil war</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Dabrowski_2014_26-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dabrowski_2014-26">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> and a year later the Polish <a href="/wiki/Polish_hussars" title="Polish hussars">winged hussar</a> units under <a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_%C5%BB%C3%B3%C5%82kiewski" title="StanisÅaw Å»Ã³Åkiewski">StanisÅaw Å»Ã³Åkiewski</a> <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_occupation_of_Moscow" title="PolishâLithuanian occupation of Moscow">occupied</a> Moscow for two years after defeating the Russians at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Klushino" title="Battle of Klushino">Klushino</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Dabrowski_2014_26-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dabrowski_2014-26">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> Sigismund also countered the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> in the southeast; at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Khotyn_(1621)" title="Battle of Khotyn (1621)">Khotyn</a> in 1621 <a href="/wiki/Jan_Karol_Chodkiewicz" title="Jan Karol Chodkiewicz">Jan Karol Chodkiewicz</a> achieved a decisive victory against the Turks, which ushered the downfall of Sultan <a href="/wiki/Osman_II" title="Osman II">Osman II</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Sigismund's long reign in Poland coincided with the <a href="/wiki/Sigismund_III_Vasa#Legacy" title="Sigismund III Vasa">Silver Age</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup> The liberal <a href="/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_IV_Vasa" title="WÅadysÅaw IV Vasa">WÅadysÅaw IV</a> effectively defended Poland's territorial possessions but after his death the vast Commonwealth began declining from internal disorder and constant warfare.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup> In 1648, the Polish hegemony over Ukraine sparked the <a href="/wiki/Khmelnytsky_Uprising" title="Khmelnytsky Uprising">Khmelnytsky Uprising</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup> followed by the decimating <a href="/wiki/Deluge_(history)" title="Deluge (history)">Swedish Deluge</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Second_Northern_War" title="Second Northern War">Second Northern War</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Scott_2015_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Scott_2015-92">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup> and Prussia's <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Bromberg" title="Treaty of Bromberg">independence</a> in 1657.<sup id="cite_ref-Scott_2015_92-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Scott_2015-92">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup> In 1683, <a href="/wiki/John_III_Sobieski" title="John III Sobieski">John III Sobieski</a> re-established military prowess when he halted the advance of an <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Army_(15th-19th_centuries)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman Army (15th-19th centuries)">Ottoman Army</a> into Europe at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vienna" title="Battle of Vienna">Battle of Vienna</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup> The successive <a href="/wiki/Wettin_dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Wettin dynasty">Saxon era</a>, under <a href="/wiki/Augustus_II_the_Strong" title="Augustus II the Strong">Augustus II</a> and <a href="/wiki/Augustus_III_of_Poland" title="Augustus III of Poland">Augustus III</a>, saw the rise of neighbouring countries in the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Northern_War" title="Great Northern War">Great Northern War</a> (1700) and the <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Polish_Succession" title="War of the Polish Succession">War of the Polish Succession</a> (1733).<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Partitions">Partitions</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_(1795%E2%80%931918)" title="History of Poland (1795â1918)">History of Poland (1795â1918)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland" title="Partitions of Poland">Partitions of Poland</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Stanis%C5%82aw_II_August_Poniatowski_in_coronation_clothes.PNG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Stanis%C5%82aw_II_August_Poniatowski_in_coronation_clothes.PNG/170px-Stanis%C5%82aw_II_August_Poniatowski_in_coronation_clothes.PNG" decoding="async" width="170" height="243" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Stanis%C5%82aw_II_August_Poniatowski_in_coronation_clothes.PNG/255px-Stanis%C5%82aw_II_August_Poniatowski_in_coronation_clothes.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Stanis%C5%82aw_II_August_Poniatowski_in_coronation_clothes.PNG/340px-Stanis%C5%82aw_II_August_Poniatowski_in_coronation_clothes.PNG 2x" data-file-width="1755" data-file-height="2510" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_II_Augustus" class="mw-redirect" title="StanisÅaw II Augustus">StanisÅaw II Augustus</a>, the last <a href="/wiki/King_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="King of Poland">King of Poland</a>, reigned from 1764 until his abdication on 25 November 1795.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Royal_elections_in_Poland" title="Royal elections in Poland">royal election</a> of 1764 resulted in the elevation of <a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_August_Poniatowski" title="StanisÅaw August Poniatowski">StanisÅaw II Augustus Poniatowski</a> to the monarchy.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup> His candidacy was extensively funded by his sponsor and former lover, Empress <a href="/wiki/Catherine_II_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Catherine II of Russia">Catherine II of Russia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup> The new king maneuvered between his desire to implement necessary modernising reforms, and the necessity to remain at peace with surrounding states.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup> His ideals led to the formation of the 1768 <a href="/wiki/Bar_Confederation" title="Bar Confederation">Bar Confederation</a>, a rebellion directed against the Poniatowski and all external influence, which ineptly aimed to preserve Poland's sovereignty and privileges held by the nobility.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup> The failed attempts at government restructuring as well as the domestic turmoil provoked its neighbours to intervene.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1772, the <a href="/wiki/First_Partition_of_Poland" title="First Partition of Poland">First Partition of the Commonwealth</a> by Prussia, Russia and Austria took place; an act which the <a href="/wiki/Partition_Sejm" title="Partition Sejm">Partition Sejm</a>, under considerable duress, eventually ratified as a <a href="/wiki/List_of_French_words_and_phrases_used_by_English_speakers#F" class="mw-redirect" title="List of French words and phrases used by English speakers">fait accompli</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Gierowski_1986_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gierowski_1986-100">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup> Disregarding the territorial losses, in 1773 a plan of critical reforms was established, in which the <a href="/wiki/Commission_of_National_Education" title="Commission of National Education">Commission of National Education</a>, the first government education authority in Europe, was inaugurated.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup> Corporal punishment of schoolchildren was officially prohibited in 1783. Poniatowski was the head figure of the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Enlightenment" title="Polish Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a>, encouraged the development of industries, and embraced republican <a href="/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture" title="Neoclassical architecture">neoclassicism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup> For his contributions to the arts and sciences he was awarded a <a href="/wiki/Fellowship_of_the_Royal_Society" class="mw-redirect" title="Fellowship of the Royal Society">Fellowship of the Royal Society</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1791, <a href="/wiki/Great_Sejm" title="Great Sejm">Great Sejm parliament</a> adopted the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_May_3,_1791" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitution of May 3, 1791">3 May Constitution</a>, the first set of supreme national laws, and introduced a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Targowica_Confederation" title="Targowica Confederation">Targowica Confederation</a>, an organisation of nobles and deputies opposing the act, appealed to Catherine and caused the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Russian_War_of_1792" title="PolishâRussian War of 1792">1792 PolishâRussian War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup> Fearing the reemergence of Polish hegemony, Russia and Prussia arranged and in 1793 executed, the <a href="/wiki/Second_Partition_of_Poland" title="Second Partition of Poland">Second Partition</a>, which left the country deprived of territory and incapable of independent existence. On 24 October 1795, the Commonwealth was <a href="/wiki/Third_Partition_of_Poland" title="Third Partition of Poland">partitioned for the third time</a> and ceased to exist as a territorial entity.<sup id="cite_ref-Gierowski_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gierowski-106">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup> StanisÅaw Augustus, the last King of Poland, abdicated the throne on 25 November 1795.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Era_of_insurrections">Era of insurrections</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Austrian_Partition" title="Austrian Partition">Austrian Partition</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prussian_Partition" title="Prussian Partition">Prussian Partition</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russian_Partition" title="Russian Partition">Russian Partition</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Rzeczpospolita_Rozbiory_3.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Rzeczpospolita_Rozbiory_3.png/290px-Rzeczpospolita_Rozbiory_3.png" decoding="async" width="290" height="239" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Rzeczpospolita_Rozbiory_3.png/435px-Rzeczpospolita_Rozbiory_3.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Rzeczpospolita_Rozbiory_3.png/580px-Rzeczpospolita_Rozbiory_3.png 2x" data-file-width="1906" data-file-height="1568" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland" title="Partitions of Poland">partitions of Poland</a>, carried out by the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Prussia" title="Kingdom of Prussia">Kingdom of Prussia</a> (<i>blue</i>), the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a> (<i>brown</i>), and the <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_monarchy" title="Habsburg monarchy">Austrian Habsburg Monarchy</a> (<i>green</i>) in <a href="/wiki/First_Partition_of_Poland" title="First Partition of Poland">1772</a>, <a href="/wiki/Second_Partition_of_Poland" title="Second Partition of Poland">1793</a> and <a href="/wiki/Third_Partition_of_Poland" title="Third Partition of Poland">1795</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>The Polish people <a href="/wiki/List_of_wars_involving_Poland" title="List of wars involving Poland">rose several times against the partitioners</a> and occupying armies. An unsuccessful attempt at defending Poland's sovereignty took place in the 1794 <a href="/wiki/Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_Uprising" title="KoÅciuszko Uprising">KoÅciuszko Uprising</a>, where a popular and distinguished general <a href="/wiki/Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko" title="Tadeusz KoÅciuszko">Tadeusz KoÅciuszko</a>, who had several years earlier served under <a href="/wiki/George_Washington" title="George Washington">George Washington</a> in the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">American Revolutionary War</a>, led Polish insurgents.<sup id="cite_ref-Storozynski_2009_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Storozynski_2009-109">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup> Despite the victory at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Rac%C5%82awice" title="Battle of RacÅawice">Battle of RacÅawice</a>, his ultimate defeat ended Poland's independent existence <a href="/wiki/Third_Partition_of_Poland" title="Third Partition of Poland">for 123 years</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1806, an <a href="/wiki/Greater_Poland_uprising_(1806)" title="Greater Poland uprising (1806)">insurrection</a> organised by <a href="/wiki/Jan_Henryk_D%C4%85browski" title="Jan Henryk DÄbrowski">Jan Henryk DÄbrowski</a> liberated western Poland ahead of <a href="/wiki/Napoleon_I_of_France" class="mw-redirect" title="Napoleon I of France">Napoleon's</a> advance into Prussia during the <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Fourth_Coalition" title="War of the Fourth Coalition">War of the Fourth Coalition</a>. In accordance with the 1807 <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Tilsit" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty of Tilsit">Treaty of Tilsit</a>, Napoleon proclaimed the <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Warsaw" title="Duchy of Warsaw">Duchy of Warsaw</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Client_state" title="Client state">client state</a> ruled by his ally <a href="/wiki/Frederick_Augustus_I_of_Saxony" title="Frederick Augustus I of Saxony">Frederick Augustus I of Saxony</a>. The Poles actively aided French troops in the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>, particularly those under <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Poniatowski" title="JÃ³zef Poniatowski">JÃ³zef Poniatowski</a> who became <a href="/wiki/Marshal_of_the_Empire" title="Marshal of the Empire">Marshal of France</a> shortly before his death at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Leipzig" title="Battle of Leipzig">Leipzig</a> in 1813.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup> In the aftermath of Napoleon's exile, the Duchy of Warsaw was abolished at the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna" title="Congress of Vienna">Congress of Vienna</a> in 1815 and its territory was divided into Russian <a href="/wiki/Congress_Kingdom_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Congress Kingdom of Poland">Congress Kingdom of Poland</a>, the Prussian <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Posen" title="Grand Duchy of Posen">Grand Duchy of Posen</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Austrian_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Austrian Poland">Austrian Galicia</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Free_City_of_Krak%C3%B3w" class="mw-redirect" title="Free City of KrakÃ³w">Free City of KrakÃ³w</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="noresize thumb tleft" style=";">
<div class="thumbinner" style="overflow:hidden;width:152px;">
<div class="thumbimage" style="height:162px; overflow:hidden; position:relative; background-color:white;">
<div style=";left:-25px; top:-25px; width:200px; position:absolute;"> <span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_(%C3%96aL).jpg" class="mw-file-description" title="Tadeusz KoÅciuszko was a veteran and hero of both the Polish and American wars of independence.[105]"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg/200px-Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="265" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg/300px-Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg/400px-Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="980" data-file-height="1297" /></a></span></div>
<div style="text-align:left; background-color:transparent; line-height:110%;">
</div>
<div style="visibility:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File/Frameless"><a href="/wiki/File:Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_(%C3%96aL).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg/200px-Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="265" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg/300px-Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg/400px-Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="980" data-file-height="1297" /></a></span></div>
</div>
<div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_(%C3%96aL).jpg" title="File:Karl G Schweikart - Tadeusz KoÅciuszko (ÃaL).jpg"> </a></div><a href="/wiki/Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko" title="Tadeusz KoÅciuszko">Tadeusz KoÅciuszko</a> was a veteran and hero of both the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Russian_War_of_1792" title="PolishâRussian War of 1792">Polish</a> and <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">American</a> wars of independence.<sup id="cite_ref-Storozynski_2009_109-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Storozynski_2009-109">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup></div>
</div></div>
