<p>In 1830, <a href="/wiki/Non-commissioned_officer" title="Non-commissioned officer">non-commissioned officers</a> at Warsaw's <a href="/wiki/Corps_of_Cadets_(Warsaw)" title="Corps of Cadets (Warsaw)">Officer Cadet School</a> rebelled in what was the <a href="/wiki/November_Uprising" title="November Uprising">November Uprising</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup> After its collapse, Congress Poland lost its <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Congress_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitution of Congress Poland">constitutional autonomy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Army_of_Congress_Poland" title="Army of Congress Poland">army</a> and legislative assembly.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Spring_of_Nations" class="mw-redirect" title="Spring of Nations">European Spring of Nations</a>, Poles took up arms in the <a href="/wiki/Greater_Poland_Uprising_(1848)" title="Greater Poland Uprising (1848)">Greater Poland Uprising of 1848</a> to resist <a href="/wiki/Germanisation" title="Germanisation">Germanisation</a>, but its failure saw duchy's status reduced to a mere <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Posen" title="Province of Posen">province</a>; and subsequent integration into the <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">German Empire</a> in 1871.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup> In Russia, the fall of the <a href="/wiki/January_Uprising" title="January Uprising">January Uprising</a> (1863â1864) prompted severe <a href="/wiki/January_Uprising#The_decades_of_reprisals" title="January Uprising">political, social and cultural reprisals</a>, followed by deportations and <a href="/wiki/Pogroms" class="mw-redirect" title="Pogroms">pogroms</a> of the Polish-Jewish population. Towards the end of the 19th century, Congress Poland became heavily industrialised; its primary exports being coal, <a href="/wiki/Zinc" title="Zinc">zinc</a>, iron and textiles.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Second_Polish_Republic">Second Polish Republic</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_(1918%E2%80%931939)" title="History of Poland (1918â1939)">History of Poland (1918â1939)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Warsaw_(1920)" title="Battle of Warsaw (1920)">Battle of Warsaw (1920)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic" title="Second Polish Republic">Second Polish Republic</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski_(-1930).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski_%28-1930%29.jpg/170px-J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski_%28-1930%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="234" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski_%28-1930%29.jpg/255px-J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski_%28-1930%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski_%28-1930%29.jpg/340px-J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski_%28-1930%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="1649" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Naczelnik_pa%C5%84stwa" class="mw-redirect" title="Naczelnik paÅstwa">Chief of State</a> Marshal <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski" title="JÃ³zef PiÅsudski">JÃ³zef PiÅsudski</a> was a hero of the Polish independence campaign and the nation's premiere statesman from 1918 until his death on 12 May 1935.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In the aftermath of <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allies</a> agreed on the reconstitution of Poland, confirmed through the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Treaty of Versailles">Treaty of Versailles</a> of June 1919.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup> A total of 2 million Polish troops fought with the armies of the three occupying powers, and over 450,000 died.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Armistice_with_Germany_(Compi%C3%A8gne)" class="mw-redirect" title="Armistice with Germany (CompiÃ¨gne)">armistice with Germany</a> in November 1918, Poland regained its independence as the <a href="/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic" title="Second Polish Republic">Second Polish Republic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Second Polish Republic reaffirmed its sovereignty after <a href="/wiki/List_of_wars_involving_Poland" title="List of wars involving Poland">a series of military conflicts</a>, most notably the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Soviet_War" title="PolishâSoviet War">PolishâSoviet War</a>, when Poland inflicted a crushing defeat on the <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Warsaw_(1920)" title="Battle of Warsaw (1920)">Battle of Warsaw</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The inter-war period heralded a new era of Polish politics. Whilst Polish political activists had faced heavy censorship in the decades up until <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, a new political tradition was established in the country. Many exiled Polish activists, such as <a href="/wiki/Ignacy_Jan_Paderewski" title="Ignacy Jan Paderewski">Ignacy Jan Paderewski</a>, who would later become prime minister, returned home. A significant number of them then went on to take key positions in the newly formed political and governmental structures. Tragedy struck in 1922 when <a href="/wiki/Gabriel_Narutowicz" title="Gabriel Narutowicz">Gabriel Narutowicz</a>, inaugural holder of the presidency, was assassinated at the <a href="/wiki/Zach%C4%99ta" class="mw-redirect" title="ZachÄta">ZachÄta</a> Gallery in Warsaw by a painter and right-wing nationalist <a href="/wiki/Eligiusz_Niewiadomski" title="Eligiusz Niewiadomski">Eligiusz Niewiadomski</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bitter_glory_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bitter_glory-122">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1926, the <a href="/wiki/May_Coup_(Poland)" title="May Coup (Poland)">May Coup</a>, led by the hero of the Polish independence campaign Marshal <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski" title="JÃ³zef PiÅsudski">JÃ³zef PiÅsudski</a>, turned rule of the Second Polish Republic over to the nonpartisan <a href="/wiki/Sanacja" class="mw-redirect" title="Sanacja">Sanacja</a> (<i>Healing</i>) movement to prevent radical political organisations on both the left and the right from destabilizing the country.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup> By the late 1930s, due to increased threats posed by political extremism inside the country, the Polish government became increasingly heavy-handed, banning a number of radical organisations, including communist and ultra-nationalist political parties, which threatened the stability of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_II">World War II</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_(1939%E2%80%931945)" title="History of Poland (1939â1945)">History of Poland (1939â1945)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland" title="Invasion of Poland">Invasion of Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Poland_during_World_War_II" title="Military history of Poland during World War II">Military history of Poland during World War II</a>, and <a href="/wiki/War_crimes_in_occupied_Poland_during_World_War_II" title="War crimes in occupied Poland during World War II">War crimes in occupied Poland during World War II</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:7TP_Polish_Tank.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/7TP_Polish_Tank.png/220px-7TP_Polish_Tank.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="155" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/7TP_Polish_Tank.png/330px-7TP_Polish_Tank.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/7TP_Polish_Tank.png/440px-7TP_Polish_Tank.png 2x" data-file-width="704" data-file-height="497" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Polish_Armed_Forces_(Second_Polish_Republic)" title="Polish Armed Forces (Second Polish Republic)">Polish Army</a> <a href="/wiki/7TP" title="7TP">7TP</a> tanks on military manoeuvres shortly before the <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland" title="Invasion of Poland">invasion of Poland</a> in 1939</figcaption></figure>
<p>World War II began with the <a href="/wiki/Nazi_German" class="mw-redirect" title="Nazi German">Nazi German</a> <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland" title="Invasion of Poland">invasion of Poland</a> on 1 September 1939, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Poland" title="Soviet invasion of Poland">Soviet invasion of Poland</a> on 17 September. On 28 September 1939, <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Warsaw_(1939)" title="Siege of Warsaw (1939)">Warsaw fell</a>. As agreed in the <a href="/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact" title="MolotovâRibbentrop Pact">MolotovâRibbentrop Pact</a>, Poland was split into two zones, <a href="/wiki/Polish_areas_annexed_by_Nazi_Germany" title="Polish areas annexed by Nazi Germany">one occupied by Nazi Germany</a>, the other by <a href="/wiki/Territories_of_Poland_annexed_by_the_Soviet_Union" title="Territories of Poland annexed by the Soviet Union">the Soviet Union</a>. In 1939â1941, the Soviets deported hundreds of thousands of Poles. The Soviet <a href="/wiki/NKVD" title="NKVD">NKVD</a> executed thousands of Polish prisoners of war (among other incidents in the <a href="/wiki/Katyn_massacre" title="Katyn massacre">Katyn massacre</a>) ahead of <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">Operation Barbarossa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_2010_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_2010-125">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup> German planners had in November 1939 called for "the complete destruction of all Poles" and their fate as outlined in the genocidal <i><a href="/wiki/Generalplan_Ost" title="Generalplan Ost">Generalplan Ost</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Pilots_of_No._303_(Polish)_Squadron_RAF_with_one_of_their_Hawker_Hurricanes,_October_1940._CH1535.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Pilots_of_No._303_%28Polish%29_Squadron_RAF_with_one_of_their_Hawker_Hurricanes%2C_October_1940._CH1535.jpg/220px-Pilots_of_No._303_%28Polish%29_Squadron_RAF_with_one_of_their_Hawker_Hurricanes%2C_October_1940._CH1535.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Pilots_of_No._303_%28Polish%29_Squadron_RAF_with_one_of_their_Hawker_Hurricanes%2C_October_1940._CH1535.jpg/330px-Pilots_of_No._303_%28Polish%29_Squadron_RAF_with_one_of_their_Hawker_Hurricanes%2C_October_1940._CH1535.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Pilots_of_No._303_%28Polish%29_Squadron_RAF_with_one_of_their_Hawker_Hurricanes%2C_October_1940._CH1535.jpg/440px-Pilots_of_No._303_%28Polish%29_Squadron_RAF_with_one_of_their_Hawker_Hurricanes%2C_October_1940._CH1535.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1278" data-file-height="956" /></a><figcaption>Pilots of the <a href="/wiki/No._303_Polish_Fighter_Squadron" class="mw-redirect" title="No. 303 Polish Fighter Squadron">303 Polish Fighter Squadron</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Britain" title="Battle of Britain">Battle of Britain</a>, October 1940</figcaption></figure>
<p>Poland made the fourth-largest troop contribution in Europe,<sup id="cite_ref-Zaloga_1982_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zaloga_1982-127">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lerski_1996a_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lerski_1996a-128">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Walters_1988_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Walters_1988-129">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup> and its troops served both the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Government_in_Exile" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish Government in Exile">Polish Government in Exile</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Armed_Forces_in_the_West" title="Polish Armed Forces in the West">west</a> and Soviet leadership in the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Armed_Forces_in_the_East" title="Polish Armed Forces in the East">east</a>. Polish troops played an important role in the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Overlord" title="Operation Overlord">Normandy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_Campaign_(World_War_II)" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian Campaign (World War II)">Italian</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_African_Campaign" class="mw-redirect" title="North African Campaign">North African Campaigns</a> and <a href="/wiki/Operation_Pheasant" title="Operation Pheasant">Netherlands</a> and are particularly remembered for the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Britain" title="Battle of Britain">Battle of Britain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Monte_Cassino" title="Battle of Monte Cassino">Battle of Monte Cassino</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-tobruk_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tobruk-130">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-including_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-including-131">&#91;127&#93;</a></sup> Polish intelligence operatives proved extremely valuable to the Allies, providing much of the intelligence from Europe and beyond,<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Polish_Cipher_Bureau" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish Cipher Bureau">Polish code breakers</a> were responsible for <a href="/wiki/Cryptanalysis_of_the_Enigma" title="Cryptanalysis of the Enigma">cracking the Enigma cipher</a> and Polish scientists participating in the <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_Project" title="Manhattan Project">Manhattan Project</a> were co-creators of the American <a href="/wiki/Atomic_bomb" class="mw-redirect" title="Atomic bomb">atomic bomb</a>. In the east, the Soviet-backed <a href="/wiki/First_Polish_Army_(1944%E2%80%931945)" class="mw-redirect" title="First Polish Army (1944â1945)">Polish 1st Army</a> distinguished itself in the battles for <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Uprising" title="Warsaw Uprising">Warsaw</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Berlin" title="Battle of Berlin">Berlin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Lerski_1996b_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lerski_1996b-133">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Polish_resistance_movement_in_World_War_II" title="Polish resistance movement in World War II">wartime resistance movement</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Armia_Krajowa" class="mw-redirect" title="Armia Krajowa">Armia Krajowa</a> (<i>Home Army</i>), fought against German occupation. It was one of the three largest resistance movements of the entire war, and encompassed a range of clandestine activities, which functioned as an <a href="/wiki/Polish_Underground_State" title="Polish Underground State">underground state</a> complete with <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Poland_during_World_War_II" title="Education in Poland during World War II">degree-awarding universities</a> and <a href="/wiki/Underground_court" title="Underground court">a court system</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Stanislaw_Salmonowicz_1994_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stanislaw_Salmonowicz_1994-134">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup> The resistance was loyal to the exiled government and generally resented the idea of a communist Poland; for this reason, in the summer of 1944 it initiated <a href="/wiki/Operation_Tempest" title="Operation Tempest">Operation Tempest</a>, of which the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Uprising" title="Warsaw Uprising">Warsaw Uprising</a> that began on 1 August 1944 is the best-known operation.<sup id="cite_ref-Lerski_1996b_133-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lerski_1996b-133">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-polandinexile_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-polandinexile-135">&#91;131&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:WW2-Holocaust-Poland.PNG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/WW2-Holocaust-Poland.PNG/220px-WW2-Holocaust-Poland.PNG" decoding="async" width="220" height="237" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/WW2-Holocaust-Poland.PNG/330px-WW2-Holocaust-Poland.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/WW2-Holocaust-Poland.PNG/440px-WW2-Holocaust-Poland.PNG 2x" data-file-width="2007" data-file-height="2161" /></a><figcaption>Map of <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_occupied_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="The Holocaust in occupied Poland">the Holocaust in German-occupied Poland</a> with deportation routes and massacre sites. Major <a href="/wiki/Jewish_ghettos_in_German-occupied_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Jewish ghettos in German-occupied Poland">ghettos</a> are marked with yellow stars. Nazi <a href="/wiki/Extermination_camps" class="mw-redirect" title="Extermination camps">extermination camps</a> are marked with white skulls in black squares. The border in 1941 between <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> is marked in red.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Nazi German forces under orders from <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Hitler" title="Adolf Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a> set up six German <a href="/wiki/Extermination_camp" title="Extermination camp">extermination camps</a> in occupied Poland, including <a href="/wiki/Treblinka_extermination_camp" title="Treblinka extermination camp">Treblinka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Majdanek_concentration_camp" title="Majdanek concentration camp">Majdanek</a> and <a href="/wiki/Auschwitz_concentration_camp" title="Auschwitz concentration camp">Auschwitz</a>. The Germans <a href="/wiki/Holocaust_train" class="mw-redirect" title="Holocaust train">transported millions of Jews</a> from across occupied Europe to be murdered in those camps.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">&#91;132&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup> Altogether, 3 million Polish Jews<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">&#91;134&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup> â approximately 90% of Poland's pre-war Jewry â and between 1.8 and 2.8 million ethnic Poles<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">&#91;136&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">&#91;137&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">&#91;138&#93;</a></sup> were killed during the German <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Poland_(1939%E2%80%931945)" title="Occupation of Poland (1939â1945)">occupation of Poland</a>, including between 50,000 and 100,000 members of the Polish <a href="/wiki/Intelligentsia" title="Intelligentsia">intelligentsia</a> â academics, doctors, lawyers, nobility and priesthood. During the Warsaw Uprising alone, over 150,000 Polish civilians were killed, most were murdered by the Germans during the <a href="/wiki/Wola_massacre" title="Wola massacre">Wola</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ochota_massacre" title="Ochota massacre">Ochota</a> massacres.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">&#91;139&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup> Around 150,000 Polish civilians were killed by Soviets between 1939 and 1941 during the Soviet Union's occupation of eastern Poland (<a href="/wiki/Kresy" title="Kresy">Kresy</a>), and another estimated 100,000 Poles were murdered by the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Insurgent_Army" title="Ukrainian Insurgent Army">Ukrainian Insurgent Army</a> (UPA) between 1943 and 1944 in what became known as the <a href="/wiki/Massacres_of_Poles_in_Volhynia_and_Eastern_Galicia" title="Massacres of Poles in Volhynia and Eastern Galicia">WoÅyÅ Massacres</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">&#91;141&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties" title="World War II casualties">Of all the countries</a> in the war, Poland lost the highest percentage of its citizens: around 6 million perished â more than one-sixth of Poland's pre-war population â <a href="/wiki/Holocaust_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Holocaust in Poland">half of them</a> Polish Jews.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup> About 90% of deaths were non-military in nature.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1945, Poland's borders <a href="/wiki/Territorial_changes_of_Poland_immediately_after_World_War_II" title="Territorial changes of Poland immediately after World War II">were shifted westwards</a>. Over two million Polish inhabitants of <a href="/wiki/Kresy" title="Kresy">Kresy</a> <a href="/wiki/Polish_population_transfers_(1944%E2%80%931946)" title="Polish population transfers (1944â1946)">were expelled</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Curzon_Line" title="Curzon Line">Curzon Line</a> by <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Stalin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup> The western border became the <a href="/wiki/Oder-Neisse_line" class="mw-redirect" title="Oder-Neisse line">Oder-Neisse line</a>. As a result, Poland's territory was reduced by 20%, or 77,500 square kilometres (29,900&#160;sq&#160;mi). The shift forced the migration of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_evacuation_and_expulsion" title="World War II evacuation and expulsion">millions of other people</a>, most of whom were Poles, Germans, Ukrainians, and Jews.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BBC_2011_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_2011-154">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-war_communism">Post-war communism</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_(1945%E2%80%931989)" title="History of Poland (1945â1989)">History of Poland (1945â1989)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polish_People%27s_Republic" title="Polish People&#39;s Republic">Polish People's Republic</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Solidarity" title="History of Solidarity">History of Solidarity</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Polish_Round_Table_Agreement" title="Polish Round Table Agreement">Polish Round Table Agreement</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Solidarity_poster_1989.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Solidarity_poster_1989.jpg/170px-Solidarity_poster_1989.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="253" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Solidarity_poster_1989.jpg/255px-Solidarity_poster_1989.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/9/9e/Solidarity_poster_1989.jpg 2x" data-file-width="259" data-file-height="385" /></a><figcaption><i>At <a href="/wiki/High_Noon" title="High Noon">High Noon</a>, 4 June 1989</i>âpolitical poster featuring <a href="/wiki/Gary_Cooper" title="Gary Cooper">Gary Cooper</a> to encourage votes for the <a href="/wiki/Solidarity_(Polish_trade_union)" title="Solidarity (Polish trade union)">Solidarity</a> party in the <a href="/wiki/Contract_Sejm" title="Contract Sejm">1989 elections</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>At the insistence of <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Yalta_Conference" title="Yalta Conference">Yalta Conference</a> sanctioned the formation of a new provisional pro-Communist coalition government in Moscow, which ignored the <a href="/wiki/Polish_government-in-exile" title="Polish government-in-exile">Polish government-in-exile</a> based in London. This action angered many Poles who considered it a <a href="/wiki/Yalta_betrayal" class="mw-redirect" title="Yalta betrayal">betrayal</a> by the Allies. In 1944, Stalin had made guarantees to <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Churchill</a> and <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Roosevelt</a> that he would maintain Poland's sovereignty and allow democratic elections to take place. However, upon achieving victory in 1945, the elections organised by the occupying Soviet authorities were falsified and were used to provide a veneer of legitimacy for Soviet hegemony over Polish affairs. The Soviet Union instituted a new <a href="/wiki/Communist_state" title="Communist state">communist</a> government in Poland, analogous to much of the rest of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a>. <a href="/wiki/Anti-Communism_in_the_Communist_Bloc" class="mw-redirect" title="Anti-Communism in the Communist Bloc">As elsewhere in Communist Europe</a>, the Soviet influence over Poland was met with <a href="/wiki/Cursed_soldiers" title="Cursed soldiers">armed resistance</a> from the outset which continued into the 1950s.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite widespread objections, the new Polish government accepted the Soviet annexation of the pre-war eastern regions of Poland<sup id="cite_ref-Lane_1948_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lane_1948-156">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup> (in particular the cities of <a href="/wiki/Wilno" class="mw-redirect" title="Wilno">Wilno</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lw%C3%B3w" class="mw-redirect" title="LwÃ³w">LwÃ³w</a>) and agreed to the permanent garrisoning of <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a> units on Poland's territory. Military alignment within the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Pact" title="Warsaw Pact">Warsaw Pact</a> throughout the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> came about as a direct result of this change in Poland's political culture. In the European scene, it came to characterise the full-fledged integration of Poland into the brotherhood of communist nations.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The new communist government took control with the adoption of the <a href="/wiki/Small_Constitution_of_1947" title="Small Constitution of 1947">Small Constitution</a> on 19 February 1947. The <a href="/wiki/Polish_People%27s_Republic" title="Polish People&#39;s Republic">Polish People's Republic</a> (<i>Polska Rzeczpospolita Ludowa</i>) <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitution of the People&#39;s Republic of Poland">was officially proclaimed in 1952</a>. In 1956, after the death of <a href="/wiki/Boles%C5%82aw_Bierut" title="BolesÅaw Bierut">BolesÅaw Bierut</a>, the rÃ©gime of <a href="/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_Gomu%C5%82ka" title="WÅadysÅaw GomuÅka">WÅadysÅaw GomuÅka</a> became temporarily more liberal, freeing many people from prison and expanding some personal freedoms. <a href="/wiki/Collectivization_in_the_Polish_People%27s_Republic" title="Collectivization in the Polish People&#39;s Republic">Collectivisation in the Polish People's Republic</a> failed. A similar situation repeated itself in the 1970s under <a href="/wiki/Edward_Gierek" title="Edward Gierek">Edward Gierek</a>, but most of the time persecution of <a href="/wiki/Anti-communist_resistance_in_Poland_(1944%E2%80%931989)" title="Anti-communist resistance in Poland (1944â1989)">anti-communist opposition</a> groups persisted. Despite this, Poland was at the time considered to be one of the least oppressive states of the Eastern Bloc.<sup id="cite_ref-PWN_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PWN-158">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Labour turmoil in 1980 led to the formation of the independent trade union "<a href="/wiki/Solidarity_(Polish_trade_union)" title="Solidarity (Polish trade union)">Solidarity</a>" ("<i>SolidarnoÅÄ</i>"), which over time became a political force. Despite persecution and imposition of <a href="/wiki/Martial_law_in_Poland" title="Martial law in Poland">martial law in 1981</a> by General <a href="/wiki/Wojciech_Jaruzelski" title="Wojciech Jaruzelski">Wojciech Jaruzelski</a>, it eroded the dominance of the <a href="/wiki/Polish_United_Workers%27_Party" title="Polish United Workers&#39; Party">Polish United Workers' Party</a> and by 1989 had triumphed in Poland's first <a href="/wiki/Contract_Sejm" title="Contract Sejm">partially free and democratic parliamentary elections</a> since the end of the Second World War. <a href="/wiki/Lech_Wa%C5%82%C4%99sa" title="Lech WaÅÄsa">Lech WaÅÄsa</a>, a Solidarity candidate, eventually <a href="/wiki/1990_Polish_presidential_election" title="1990 Polish presidential election">won the presidency in 1990</a>. The Solidarity movement heralded the <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1989" title="Revolutions of 1989">collapse of communist regimes and parties across Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Third_Polish_Republic">Third Polish Republic</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_(1989%E2%80%93present)" title="History of Poland (1989âpresent)">History of Poland (1989âpresent)</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Flowers_in_front_of_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Warsaw.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Flowers_in_front_of_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Warsaw.jpg/180px-Flowers_in_front_of_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Warsaw.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="270" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Flowers_in_front_of_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Warsaw.jpg/270px-Flowers_in_front_of_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Warsaw.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Flowers_in_front_of_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Warsaw.jpg/360px-Flowers_in_front_of_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Warsaw.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="1200" /></a><figcaption>Flowers in front of the <a href="/wiki/Presidential_Palace,_Warsaw" title="Presidential Palace, Warsaw">Presidential Palace</a> following the <a href="/wiki/2010_Polish_Air_Force_Tu-154_crash" class="mw-redirect" title="2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash">death of Poland's top government officials</a> in a plane crash on 10 April 2010</figcaption></figure>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Shock_therapy_(economics)" title="Shock therapy (economics)">shock therapy</a> program, initiated by <a href="/wiki/Leszek_Balcerowicz" title="Leszek Balcerowicz">Leszek Balcerowicz</a> in the early 1990s, enabled the country to transform its <a href="/wiki/Soviet-style_socialism" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet-style socialism">Soviet-style</a> <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">planned economy</a> into a <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup> As with other <a href="/wiki/Post-communism" title="Post-communism">post-communist countries</a>, Poland suffered temporary declines in social, economic, and living standards,<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup> but it became the first post-communist country to reach its pre-1989 <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP levels</a> as early as 1995, largely due to its <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Poland" title="Economy of Poland">booming economy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup> Poland became a member of the <a href="/wiki/Visegr%C3%A1d_Group" title="VisegrÃ¡d Group">VisegrÃ¡d Group</a> in 1991,<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup> and joined <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> in 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup> Poles then voted to join the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> in <a href="/wiki/2003_Polish_European_Union_membership_referendum" title="2003 Polish European Union membership referendum">a referendum</a> in June 2003,<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/Poland_in_the_European_Union" title="Poland in the European Union">Poland becoming a full member</a> on 1 May 2004, following the <a href="/wiki/2004_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="2004 enlargement of the European Union">consequent enlargement of the organisation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Poland joined the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen Area</a> in 2007, as a result of which, <a href="/wiki/Borders_of_Poland" title="Borders of Poland">the country's borders</a> with other member states of the European Union were dismantled, allowing for <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_movement#European_Union" title="Freedom of movement">full freedom of movement</a> within most of the European Union.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_News_2007_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_News_2007-167">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup> On 10 April 2010, the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Poland" title="President of Poland">President of Poland</a> <a href="/wiki/Lech_Kaczy%C5%84ski" title="Lech KaczyÅski">Lech KaczyÅski</a>, along with 89 other high-ranking Polish officials <a href="/wiki/2010_Polish_Air_Force_Tu-154_crash" class="mw-redirect" title="2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash">died in a plane crash</a> near <a href="/wiki/Smolensk" title="Smolensk">Smolensk</a>, Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2011, the ruling <a href="/wiki/Civic_Platform" title="Civic Platform">Civic Platform</a> won <a href="/wiki/2011_Polish_parliamentary_election" title="2011 Polish parliamentary election">parliamentary elections</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">&#91;165&#93;</a></sup> In 2014, the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Poland" title="Prime Minister of Poland">Prime Minister of Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Donald_Tusk" title="Donald Tusk">Donald Tusk</a>, was chosen to be <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Council" title="President of the European Council">President of the European Council</a>, and resigned as prime minister.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/2015_Polish_parliamentary_election" title="2015 Polish parliamentary election">2015</a> and <a href="/wiki/2019_Polish_parliamentary_election" title="2019 Polish parliamentary election">2019 elections</a> were won by the national-conservative <a href="/wiki/Law_and_Justice" title="Law and Justice">Law and Justice</a> Party (PiS) led by <a href="/wiki/Jaros%C5%82aw_Kaczy%C5%84ski" title="JarosÅaw KaczyÅski">JarosÅaw KaczyÅski</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup> resulting in increased <a href="/wiki/Euroscepticism" title="Euroscepticism">Euroscepticism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Polish_constitutional_crisis" title="Polish constitutional crisis">increased friction</a> with the European Union.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup> In December 2017, <a href="/wiki/Mateusz_Morawiecki" title="Mateusz Morawiecki">Mateusz Morawiecki</a> was sworn in as the Prime Minister, succeeding <a href="/wiki/Beata_Szyd%C5%82o" title="Beata SzydÅo">Beata Szydlo</a>, in office since 2015. President <a href="/wiki/Andrzej_Duda" title="Andrzej Duda">Andrzej Duda</a>, supported by Law and Justice party, was re-elected in the 2020 presidential <a href="/wiki/2020_Polish_presidential_election" title="2020 Polish presidential election">election</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">&#91;170&#93;</a></sup> As of November 2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Poland&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Russian invasion of Ukraine">Russian invasion of Ukraine</a> had led to 17 million <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_refugee_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian refugee crisis">Ukrainian refugees</a> crossing the border to Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-UNHRC_Ukraine_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNHRC_Ukraine-175">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup> As of November 2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Poland&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, 0.9 million of those had stayed in Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-UNHRC_Ukraine_175-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNHRC_Ukraine-175">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup> In October 2023, the ruling Law and Justice (PiS) party won the largest share of the vote in the <a href="/wiki/2023_Polish_parliamentary_election" title="2023 Polish parliamentary election">election</a>, but lost its majority in parliament. In December 2023, Donald Tusk became the new Prime Minister leading a coalition called <a href="/wiki/Civic_Coalition_(Poland)" title="Civic Coalition (Poland)">Civic Coalition</a> made up of <a href="/wiki/Civic_Platform" title="Civic Platform">Civic Platform</a>, <a href="/wiki/Third_Way_(Poland)" title="Third Way (Poland)">Third Way</a>, and <a href="/wiki/The_Left_(Poland)" title="The Left (Poland)">The Left</a>. Law and Justice became the leading opposition party.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Poland" title="Geography of Poland">Geography of Poland</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Poland_topo.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Poland_topo.jpg/220px-Poland_topo.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="214" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Poland_topo.jpg/330px-Poland_topo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Poland_topo.jpg/440px-Poland_topo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1400" data-file-height="1364" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Topography" title="Topography">Topographic</a> map of Poland</figcaption></figure>
<p>Poland covers an administrative area of 312,722&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (120,743&#160;sq&#160;mi), and is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_countries_by_area" title="List of European countries by area">ninth-largest country in Europe</a>. Approximately 311,895&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (120,423&#160;sq&#160;mi) of the country's territory consists of land, 2,041&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (788&#160;sq&#160;mi) comprises internal waters and 8,783&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (3,391&#160;sq&#160;mi) is territorial sea.<sup id="cite_ref-Rocznik_2019_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rocznik_2019-177">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup> Topographically, the landscape of Poland is characterised by diverse <a href="/wiki/Landform" title="Landform">landforms</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hydrology" title="Hydrology">water bodies</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">ecosystems</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup> The central and northern region bordering the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a> lie within the flat <a href="/wiki/Northern_European_Plain" class="mw-redirect" title="Northern European Plain">Central European Plain</a>, but its south is hilly and mountainous.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup> The average <a href="/wiki/Height_above_sea_level" class="mw-redirect" title="Height above sea level">elevation above the sea level</a> is estimated at 173 metres.<sup id="cite_ref-Rocznik_2019_177-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rocznik_2019-177">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The country has a coastline spanning 770&#160;km (480&#160;mi); extending from the shores of the Baltic Sea, along the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Pomerania" title="Bay of Pomerania">Bay of Pomerania</a> in the west to the <a href="/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk_Bay" title="GdaÅsk Bay">Gulf of GdaÅsk</a> in the east.<sup id="cite_ref-Rocznik_2019_177-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rocznik_2019-177">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup> The beach coastline is abundant in <a href="/wiki/Sand_dunes" class="mw-redirect" title="Sand dunes">sand dune fields</a> or <a href="/wiki/Beach_ridge" title="Beach ridge">coastal ridges</a> and is indented by <a href="/wiki/Spit_(landform)" title="Spit (landform)">spits</a> and lagoons, notably the <a href="/wiki/Hel_Peninsula" title="Hel Peninsula">Hel Peninsula</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Vistula_Lagoon" title="Vistula Lagoon">Vistula Lagoon</a>, which is shared with Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup> The largest Polish island on the Baltic Sea is <a href="/wiki/Wolin" title="Wolin">Wolin</a>, located within <a href="/wiki/Wolin_National_Park" title="Wolin National Park">Wolin National Park</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">&#91;177&#93;</a></sup> Poland also shares the <a href="/wiki/Szczecin_Lagoon" title="Szczecin Lagoon">Szczecin Lagoon</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Usedom" title="Usedom">Usedom</a> island with Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The mountainous belt in the extreme south of Poland is divided into two major <a href="/wiki/Mountain_ranges" class="mw-redirect" title="Mountain ranges">mountain ranges</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Sudetes" title="Sudetes">Sudetes</a> in the west and the <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains" title="Carpathian Mountains">Carpathians</a> in the east. The highest part of the Carpathian massif are the <a href="/wiki/Tatra_Mountains" title="Tatra Mountains">Tatra Mountains</a>, extending along Poland's southern border.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup> Poland's highest point is <a href="/wiki/Mount_Rysy" class="mw-redirect" title="Mount Rysy">Mount Rysy</a> at 2,501 metres (8,205&#160;ft) in elevation, located in the Tatras.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup> The highest summit of the Sudetes massif is <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Anie%C5%BCka" class="mw-redirect" title="ÅnieÅ¼ka">Mount ÅnieÅ¼ka</a> at 1,603.3 metres (5,260&#160;ft), shared with the Czech Republic.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">&#91;181&#93;</a></sup> The lowest point in Poland is situated at <a href="/wiki/Raczki_Elbl%C4%85skie" title="Raczki ElblÄskie">Raczki ElblÄskie</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Vistula#Delta" title="Vistula">Vistula Delta</a>, which is 1.8 metres (5.9&#160;ft) below sea level.<sup id="cite_ref-Rocznik_2019_177-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rocznik_2019-177">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Morskie_Oko_o_poranku.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Morskie_Oko_o_poranku.jpg/220px-Morskie_Oko_o_poranku.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Morskie_Oko_o_poranku.jpg/330px-Morskie_Oko_o_poranku.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Morskie_Oko_o_poranku.jpg/440px-Morskie_Oko_o_poranku.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4500" data-file-height="3000" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Morskie_Oko" title="Morskie Oko">Morskie Oko</a> alpine lake in the <a href="/wiki/Tatra_Mountains" title="Tatra Mountains">Tatra Mountains</a>. Poland has one of the highest densities of lakes in the world.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Poland's <a href="/wiki/Rivers_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Rivers of Poland">longest rivers</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Vistula_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Vistula River">Vistula</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Oder_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Oder River">Oder</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Warta" title="Warta">Warta</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Bug_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Bug River">Bug</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Rocznik_2019_177-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rocznik_2019-177">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup> The country also possesses one of the highest densities of lakes in the world, numbering around ten thousand and mostly concentrated in the north-eastern region of <a href="/wiki/Masuria" title="Masuria">Masuria</a>, within the <a href="/wiki/Masurian_Lake_District" title="Masurian Lake District">Masurian Lake District</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup> The largest lakes, covering more than 100 square kilometres (39&#160;sq&#160;mi), are <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Aniardwy" title="Åniardwy">Åniardwy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lake_Mamry" title="Lake Mamry">Mamry</a>, and the deepest is <a href="/wiki/Ha%C5%84cza" title="HaÅcza">Lake HaÅcza</a> at 108.5 metres (356&#160;ft) in depth.<sup id="cite_ref-Rocznik_2019_177-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rocznik_2019-177">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Poland#Climate" title="Geography of Poland">Geography of Poland Â§&#160;Climate</a></div>
<p>The climate of Poland is <a href="/wiki/Temperateness" class="mw-redirect" title="Temperateness">temperate transitional</a>, and varies from <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic</a> in the north-west to <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">continental</a> in the south-east.<sup id="cite_ref-Korzeniewska_2020_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Korzeniewska_2020-187">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup> The mountainous southern fringes are situated within an <a href="/wiki/Alpine_climate" title="Alpine climate">alpine climate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Korzeniewska_2020_187-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Korzeniewska_2020-187">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup> Poland is characterised by warm summers, with a mean temperature of around 20&#160;Â°C (68.0&#160;Â°F) in July, and moderately cold winters averaging â1&#160;Â°C (30.2&#160;Â°F) in December.<sup id="cite_ref-Azad_2021_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Azad_2021-188">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup> The warmest and sunniest part of Poland is <a href="/wiki/Lower_Silesia" title="Lower Silesia">Lower Silesia</a> in the southwest and the coldest region is the northeast corner, around <a href="/wiki/Suwa%C5%82ki" title="SuwaÅki">SuwaÅki</a> in <a href="/wiki/Podlaskie_Voivodeship" title="Podlaskie Voivodeship">Podlaskie province</a>, where the climate is affected by <a href="/wiki/Cold_front" title="Cold front">cold fronts</a> from <a href="/wiki/Scandinavia" title="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Anna_Chodubska_2020_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Anna_Chodubska_2020-189">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Precipitation (meteorology)">Precipitation</a> is more frequent during the summer months, with highest rainfall recorded from June to September.<sup id="cite_ref-Azad_2021_188-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Azad_2021-188">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>There is a considerable fluctuation in day-to-day weather and the arrival of a particular season can differ each year.<sup id="cite_ref-Korzeniewska_2020_187-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Korzeniewska_2020-187">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">Climate change</a> and other factors have further contributed to interannual <a href="/wiki/Temperature_anomaly" title="Temperature anomaly">thermal anomalies</a> and increased temperatures; the average annual air temperature between 2011 and 2020 was 9.33&#160;Â°C (48.8&#160;Â°F), around 1.11&#160;Â°C higher than in the 2001â2010 period.<sup id="cite_ref-Anna_Chodubska_2020_189-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Anna_Chodubska_2020-189">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup> Winters are also becoming increasingly drier, with less <a href="/wiki/Rain_and_snow_mixed" title="Rain and snow mixed">sleet</a> and snowfall.<sup id="cite_ref-Korzeniewska_2020_187-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Korzeniewska_2020-187">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Poland#Biodiversity" title="Geography of Poland">Geography of Poland Â§&#160;Biodiversity</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:2020_%C5%BCubry_03.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/2020_%C5%BCubry_03.jpg/220px-2020_%C5%BCubry_03.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/2020_%C5%BCubry_03.jpg/330px-2020_%C5%BCubry_03.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/2020_%C5%BCubry_03.jpg/440px-2020_%C5%BCubry_03.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2736" data-file-height="1824" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Wisent" class="mw-redirect" title="Wisent">wisent</a>, one of <a href="/wiki/National_symbols_of_Poland" title="National symbols of Poland">Poland's national animals</a>, is commonly found at the ancient and <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Poland" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Poland">UNESCO</a>-protected <a href="/wiki/Bia%C5%82owie%C5%BCa_Forest" title="BiaÅowieÅ¼a Forest">BiaÅowieÅ¼a Forest</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Phytogeography" title="Phytogeography">Phytogeographically</a>, Poland belongs to the Central European province of the <a href="/wiki/Circumboreal_Region" title="Circumboreal Region">Circumboreal Region</a> within the <a href="/wiki/Boreal_Kingdom" title="Boreal Kingdom">Boreal Kingdom</a>. The country has four <a href="/wiki/Palearctic_realm" title="Palearctic realm">Palearctic ecoregions</a> â Central, Northern, Western European <a href="/wiki/Temperate_broadleaf_and_mixed_forest" class="mw-redirect" title="Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest">temperate broadleaf and mixed forest</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_montane_conifer_forests" title="Carpathian montane conifer forests">Carpathian montane conifer</a>. Forests occupy 31% of Poland's land area, the largest of which is the <a href="/wiki/Lower_Silesian_Wilderness" class="mw-redirect" title="Lower Silesian Wilderness">Lower Silesian Wilderness</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup> The most common <a href="/wiki/Deciduous_trees" class="mw-redirect" title="Deciduous trees">deciduous trees</a> found across the country are <a href="/wiki/Oak" title="Oak">oak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maple" title="Maple">maple</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Beech" title="Beech">beech</a>; the most common conifers are <a href="/wiki/Pine" title="Pine">pine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spruce" title="Spruce">spruce</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fir" title="Fir">fir</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup> An estimated 69% of all forests are <a href="/wiki/Coniferous" class="mw-redirect" title="Coniferous">coniferous</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Flora" title="Flora">flora</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Poland" title="Fauna of Poland">fauna</a> in Poland is that of <a href="/wiki/Continental_Europe" title="Continental Europe">Continental Europe</a>, with the <a href="/wiki/European_bison" title="European bison">wisent</a>, <a href="/wiki/White_stork" title="White stork">white stork</a> and <a href="/wiki/White-tailed_eagle" title="White-tailed eagle">white-tailed eagle</a> designated as national animals, and the <a href="/wiki/Papaver_rhoeas" title="Papaver rhoeas">red common poppy</a> being the unofficial floral emblem.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup> Among the most protected species is the <a href="/wiki/European_bison" title="European bison">European bison</a>, Europe's heaviest land animal, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_beaver" title="Eurasian beaver">Eurasian beaver</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_lynx" title="Eurasian lynx">lynx</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Gray_wolf" class="mw-redirect" title="Gray wolf">gray wolf</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Tatra_chamois" title="Tatra chamois">Tatra chamois</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Rocznik_2019_177-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rocznik_2019-177">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup> The region was also home to the extinct <a href="/wiki/Aurochs" title="Aurochs">aurochs</a>, the last individual dying in Poland in 1627.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup> Game animals such as <a href="/wiki/Red_deer" title="Red deer">red deer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roe_deer" title="Roe deer">roe deer</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wild_boar" title="Wild boar">wild boar</a> are found in most woodlands.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup> Poland is also a significant breeding ground for <a href="/wiki/Migratory_birds" class="mw-redirect" title="Migratory birds">migratory birds</a> and hosts around one quarter of the global population of white storks.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Around 315,100 hectares (1,217&#160;sq&#160;mi), equivalent to 1% of Poland's territory, is protected within 23 <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="List of national parks of Poland">Polish national parks</a>, two of which â <a href="/wiki/Bia%C5%82owie%C5%BCa_Forest" title="BiaÅowieÅ¼a Forest">BiaÅowieÅ¼a</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bieszczady_National_Park" title="Bieszczady National Park">Bieszczady</a> â are <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Poland" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Poland">UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup> There are 123 areas designated as <a href="/wiki/Landscape_Park_(Poland)" class="mw-redirect" title="Landscape Park (Poland)">landscape parks</a>, along with numerous <a href="/wiki/Nature_reserve" title="Nature reserve">nature reserves</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_Poland" title="Protected areas of Poland">protected areas</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Natura_2000" title="Natura 2000">Natura 2000</a> network.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Poland" title="Politics of Poland">Politics of Poland</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:268px;max-width:268px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:127px;max-width:127px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Prezydent_Rzeczypospolitej_Polskiej_Andrzej_Duda.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Andrzej Sebastian Duda" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Prezydent_Rzeczypospolitej_Polskiej_Andrzej_Duda.jpg/125px-Prezydent_Rzeczypospolitej_Polskiej_Andrzej_Duda.jpg" decoding="async" width="125" height="184" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Prezydent_Rzeczypospolitej_Polskiej_Andrzej_Duda.jpg/188px-Prezydent_Rzeczypospolitej_Polskiej_Andrzej_Duda.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Prezydent_Rzeczypospolitej_Polskiej_Andrzej_Duda.jpg/250px-Prezydent_Rzeczypospolitej_Polskiej_Andrzej_Duda.jpg 2x" data-file-width="915" data-file-height="1348" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/President_of_Poland" title="President of Poland">President</a><br /><a href="/wiki/Andrzej_Duda" title="Andrzej Duda">Andrzej Duda</a> <br /><small>since 6 August 2015</small></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:137px;max-width:137px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Donald_Tusk_EPP_Summit_2023.png" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Donald Franciszek Tusk" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Donald_Tusk_EPP_Summit_2023.png/135px-Donald_Tusk_EPP_Summit_2023.png" decoding="async" width="135" height="185" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Donald_Tusk_EPP_Summit_2023.png/203px-Donald_Tusk_EPP_Summit_2023.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Donald_Tusk_EPP_Summit_2023.png/270px-Donald_Tusk_EPP_Summit_2023.png 2x" data-file-width="2096" data-file-height="2880" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Poland" title="Prime Minister of Poland">Prime Minister</a><br /><a href="/wiki/Donald_Tusk" title="Donald Tusk">Donald Tusk</a><br /> <small>since 13 December 2023</small></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Poland is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative democracy</a>, with a <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Republic_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="President of the Republic of Poland">president</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Serwis_Rzeczypospolitej_Polskiej_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Serwis_Rzeczypospolitej_Polskiej-199">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup> The executive power is exercised further by the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_the_Republic_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Council of Ministers of the Republic of Poland">Council of Ministers</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_Republic_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Prime Minister of the Republic of Poland">prime minister</a> who acts as the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Serwis_Rzeczypospolitej_Polskiej_199-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Serwis_Rzeczypospolitej_Polskiej-199">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup> The council's individual members are selected by the prime minister, appointed by the president and approved by parliament.<sup id="cite_ref-Serwis_Rzeczypospolitej_Polskiej_199-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Serwis_Rzeczypospolitej_Polskiej-199">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup> The head of state is elected by <a href="/wiki/Direct_election" title="Direct election">popular vote</a> for a five-year term.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">&#91;196&#93;</a></sup> The current president is <a href="/wiki/Andrzej_Duda" title="Andrzej Duda">Andrzej Duda</a> and the prime minister is <a href="/wiki/Donald_Tusk" title="Donald Tusk">Donald Tusk</a>.
</p><p>Poland's <a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">legislative</a> assembly is a <a href="/wiki/Bicameralism" title="Bicameralism">bicameral</a> parliament consisting of a 460-member lower house (<a href="/wiki/Sejm" title="Sejm">Sejm</a>) and a 100-member upper house (<a href="/wiki/Senate_of_the_Republic_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Senate of the Republic of Poland">Senate</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">&#91;197&#93;</a></sup> The Sejm is elected under <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">proportional representation</a> according to the <a href="/wiki/D%27Hondt_method" title="D&#39;Hondt method">d'Hondt method</a> for vote-seat conversion.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup> The Senate is elected under the <a href="/wiki/First-past-the-post" class="mw-redirect" title="First-past-the-post">first-past-the-post</a> electoral system, with one senator being returned from each of the one hundred constituencies.<sup id="cite_ref-Granat_2021_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Granat_2021-203">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup> The Senate has the right to amend or reject a statute passed by the Sejm, but the Sejm may override the Senate's decision with a majority vote.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Zgromadzenie_Narodowe_4_czerwca_2014_Kancelaria_Senatu_01.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Zgromadzenie_Narodowe_4_czerwca_2014_Kancelaria_Senatu_01.JPG/220px-Zgromadzenie_Narodowe_4_czerwca_2014_Kancelaria_Senatu_01.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Zgromadzenie_Narodowe_4_czerwca_2014_Kancelaria_Senatu_01.JPG/330px-Zgromadzenie_Narodowe_4_czerwca_2014_Kancelaria_Senatu_01.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Zgromadzenie_Narodowe_4_czerwca_2014_Kancelaria_Senatu_01.JPG/440px-Zgromadzenie_Narodowe_4_czerwca_2014_Kancelaria_Senatu_01.JPG 2x" data-file-width="5616" data-file-height="3744" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Sejm" title="Sejm">Sejm</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Lower_house" title="Lower house">lower house</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Poland" title="Parliament of Poland">parliament of Poland</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>With the exception of ethnic minority parties, only candidates of <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Poland" title="List of political parties in Poland">political parties</a> receiving at least 5% of the total national vote can enter the Sejm.<sup id="cite_ref-Granat_2021_203-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Granat_2021-203">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup> Both the lower and upper houses of parliament in Poland are elected for a four-year term and each member of the Polish parliament is guaranteed <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_immunity" title="Parliamentary immunity">parliamentary immunity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Jasinski_2019_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jasinski_2019-205">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup> Under current legislation, a person must be 21 years of age or over to assume the position of deputy, 30 or over to become senator and 35 to run in a presidential election.<sup id="cite_ref-Jasinski_2019_205-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jasinski_2019-205">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Members of the Sejm and Senate jointly form the <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_the_Republic_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="National Assembly of the Republic of Poland">National Assembly of the Republic of Poland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bien-Kacala_2021_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bien-Kacala_2021-206">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup> The National Assembly, headed by the <a href="/wiki/Marshal_of_the_Sejm" title="Marshal of the Sejm">Sejm Marshal</a>, is formed on three occasions â when a new president takes the <a href="/wiki/Oath_of_office" title="Oath of office">oath of office</a>; when an indictment against the president is brought to the <a href="/wiki/State_Tribunal_(Poland)" title="State Tribunal (Poland)">State Tribunal</a>; and in case a president's permanent incapacity to exercise his duties due to the state of his health is declared.<sup id="cite_ref-Bien-Kacala_2021_206-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bien-Kacala_2021-206">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Poland" title="Administrative divisions of Poland">Administrative divisions of Poland</a></div>
<p>Poland is divided into 16 provinces or states known as <a href="/wiki/Voivodeships_of_Poland" title="Voivodeships of Poland">voivodeships</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Teryt_2022_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Teryt_2022-207">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup> As of 2022, the voivodeships are subdivided into 380 counties (<i><a href="/wiki/Powiat" title="Powiat">powiats</a></i>), which are further fragmented into 2,477 municipalities (<i><a href="/wiki/Gmina" title="Gmina">gminas</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-Teryt_2022_207-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Teryt_2022-207">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup> Major cities normally have the status of both <i>gmina</i> and <i>powiat</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Teryt_2022_207-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Teryt_2022-207">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup> The provinces are largely founded on the borders of <a href="/wiki/Polish_historical_regions" title="Polish historical regions">historic regions</a>, or named for individual cities.<sup id="cite_ref-Marti-Henneberg_2021_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marti-Henneberg_2021-208">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup> Administrative authority at the voivodeship level is shared between a government-appointed governor (<a href="/wiki/Voivodes_of_Poland_(since_1999)" title="Voivodes of Poland (since 1999)">voivode</a>), an elected regional assembly (<a href="/wiki/Voivodeship_sejmik" title="Voivodeship sejmik">sejmik</a>) and a <a href="/wiki/Voivodeship_marshal" title="Voivodeship marshal">voivodeship marshal</a>, an executive elected by the assembly.<sup id="cite_ref-Marti-Henneberg_2021_208-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marti-Henneberg_2021-208">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<table style="background:none;">

<tbody><tr>
<td>
<div role="img" class="floatleft noresize" style="width: 410px; padding: 15px; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Poland_colorful.png" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Map_of_Poland_colorful.png/410px-Map_of_Poland_colorful.png" decoding="async" width="410" height="379" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Map_of_Poland_colorful.png/615px-Map_of_Poland_colorful.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9f/Map_of_Poland_colorful.png 2x" data-file-width="732" data-file-height="677" /></a></span> <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:145.7px; top:49.4px"><span class="flagicon"><span class="mw-image-border" typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/Pomeranian_Voivodeship" title="Pomeranian Voivodeship"><img alt="Pomeranian Voivodeship" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_pomorskie_flag.svg/23px-POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_pomorskie_flag.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="14" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_pomorskie_flag.svg/35px-POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_pomorskie_flag.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_pomorskie_flag.svg/46px-POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_pomorskie_flag.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="469" /></a></span></span><br /><b><a href="/wiki/Pomeranian_Voivodeship" title="Pomeranian Voivodeship">Pomeranian</a></b></div>

<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:244.1px; top:61.7px"><span class="flagicon"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/Warmian%E2%80%93Masurian_Voivodeship" title="WarmianâMasurian Voivodeship"><img alt="WarmianâMasurian Voivodeship" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_warmi%C5%84sko-mazurskie_flag.svg/23px-POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_warmi%C5%84sko-mazurskie_flag.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_warmi%C5%84sko-mazurskie_flag.svg/35px-POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_warmi%C5%84sko-mazurskie_flag.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_warmi%C5%84sko-mazurskie_flag.svg/46px-POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_warmi%C5%84sko-mazurskie_flag.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="500" /></a></span></span><br /><b><a href="/wiki/Warmian-Masurian_Voivodeship" class="mw-redirect" title="Warmian-Masurian Voivodeship">Warmian-Masurian</a></b></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:338.4px; top:106.8px"><span class="flagicon"><span class="mw-image-border" typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/Podlaskie_Voivodeship" title="Podlaskie Voivodeship"><img alt="Podlaskie Voivodeship" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_podlaskie_flag.svg/23px-POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_podlaskie_flag.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="14" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_podlaskie_flag.svg/35px-POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_podlaskie_flag.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_podlaskie_flag.svg/46px-POL_wojew%C3%B3dztwo_podlaskie_flag.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="500" /></a></span></span><br /><b><a href="/wiki/Podlaskie_Voivodeship" title="Podlaskie Voivodeship">Podlaskie</a></b></div>
