<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law">Law</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Poland" title="Law of Poland">Law of Poland</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Manuscript_of_the_Constitution_of_the_3rd_May_1791.PNG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Manuscript_of_the_Constitution_of_the_3rd_May_1791.PNG/170px-Manuscript_of_the_Constitution_of_the_3rd_May_1791.PNG" decoding="async" width="170" height="258" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Manuscript_of_the_Constitution_of_the_3rd_May_1791.PNG/255px-Manuscript_of_the_Constitution_of_the_3rd_May_1791.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Manuscript_of_the_Constitution_of_the_3rd_May_1791.PNG/340px-Manuscript_of_the_Constitution_of_the_3rd_May_1791.PNG 2x" data-file-width="554" data-file-height="842" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_May_3,_1791" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitution of May 3, 1791"><i>Constitution of 3 May</i></a> adopted in 1791 was the first modern constitution in Europe.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Poland" title="Constitution of Poland">Constitution of Poland</a> is the enacted supreme law, and Polish judicature is based on the principle of civil rights, governed by the code of <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup> The current democratic constitution was adopted by the <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="National Assembly of Poland">National Assembly of Poland</a> on 2 April 1997; it guarantees a <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_state" class="mw-redirect" title="Multi-party state">multi-party state</a> with freedoms of religion, speech and assembly, prohibits the practices of forced <a href="/wiki/Medical_experimentation" class="mw-redirect" title="Medical experimentation">medical experimentation</a>, torture or <a href="/wiki/Corporal_punishment" title="Corporal punishment">corporal punishment</a>, and acknowledges the inviolability of the home, the right to form trade unions, and the right to <a href="/wiki/Strike_action" title="Strike action">strike</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">judiciary</a> in Poland is composed of the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Poland" title="Supreme Court of Poland">Supreme Court</a> as the country's highest judicial organ, the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Administrative_Court_of_Poland" title="Supreme Administrative Court of Poland">Supreme Administrative Court</a> for the judicial control of public administration, Common Courts (<a href="/wiki/District_Court" class="mw-redirect" title="District Court">District</a>, <a href="/wiki/Regional_Court_(Poland)" class="mw-redirect" title="Regional Court (Poland)">Regional</a>, <a href="/wiki/Appellate_court" title="Appellate court">Appellate</a>) and the <a href="/wiki/Court-martial" title="Court-martial">Military Court</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Tribunal_(Poland)" title="Constitutional Tribunal (Poland)">Constitutional</a> and State Tribunals are separate judicial bodies, which rule the constitutional liability of people holding the highest offices of state and supervise the compliance of <a href="/wiki/Statutory_law" class="mw-redirect" title="Statutory law">statutory law</a>, thus protecting the Constitution.<sup id="cite_ref-Jaremba_2013_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jaremba_2013-213">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup> Judges are nominated by the <a href="/wiki/National_Council_of_the_Judiciary" class="mw-redirect" title="National Council of the Judiciary">National Council of the Judiciary</a> and are appointed for life by the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Poland" title="President of Poland">president</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Jaremba_2013_213-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jaremba_2013-213">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup> On the approval of the Senate, the Sejm appoints an <a href="/wiki/Ombudsman" title="Ombudsman">ombudsman</a> for a five-year term to guard the observance of social justice.<sup id="cite_ref-Granat_2021_203-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Granat_2021-203">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Poland has a low <a href="/wiki/Homicide" title="Homicide">homicide</a> rate at 0.7 murders per 100,000 people, as of 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup> Rape, assault and violent crime remain at a very low level.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup> The country has imposed strict regulations on <a href="/wiki/Abortion_in_Poland" title="Abortion in Poland">abortion</a>, which is permitted only in cases of rape, incest or when the woman's life is in danger; <a href="/wiki/Congenital_disorder" class="mw-redirect" title="Congenital disorder">congenital disorder</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stillbirth" title="Stillbirth">stillbirth</a> are not covered by the law, prompting some women to seek abortion abroad.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Historically, the most significant Polish legal act is the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_3_May_1791" title="Constitution of 3 May 1791">Constitution of 3 May 1791</a>. Instituted to redress long-standing political defects of the <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federative</a> <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth">PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth</a> and its <a href="/wiki/Golden_Liberty" title="Golden Liberty">Golden Liberty</a>, it was the first modern constitution in Europe and influenced many later <a href="/wiki/Democratic_movement" class="mw-redirect" title="Democratic movement">democratic movements</a> across the globe.<sup id="cite_ref-Davies_1996_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davies_1996-217">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup> In 1918, the <a href="/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic" title="Second Polish Republic">Second Polish Republic</a> became one of the first countries to introduce universal <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage" title="Women&#39;s suffrage">women's suffrage</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Poland" title="Foreign relations of Poland">Foreign relations of Poland</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_of_Poland" title="List of diplomatic missions of Poland">List of diplomatic missions of Poland</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Ministerstwo_Spraw_Zagraniczych_al._Szucha_23.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Ministerstwo_Spraw_Zagraniczych_al._Szucha_23.JPG/220px-Ministerstwo_Spraw_Zagraniczych_al._Szucha_23.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="159" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Ministerstwo_Spraw_Zagraniczych_al._Szucha_23.JPG/330px-Ministerstwo_Spraw_Zagraniczych_al._Szucha_23.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Ministerstwo_Spraw_Zagraniczych_al._Szucha_23.JPG/440px-Ministerstwo_Spraw_Zagraniczych_al._Szucha_23.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4095" data-file-height="2958" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Poland)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Poland)">Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a>, located in <a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">Warsaw</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Poland is a <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a> and is transitioning into a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a> in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup> It has a total of 52 representatives in the <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a> as of 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">Warsaw</a> serves as the headquarters for <a href="/wiki/Frontex" title="Frontex">Frontex</a>, the European Union's agency for external border security as well as <a href="/wiki/ODIHR" class="mw-redirect" title="ODIHR">ODIHR</a>, one of the principal institutions of the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup> Apart from the European Union, Poland has been a member of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, the United Nations, and the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a>.
</p><p>In recent years, Poland significantly strengthened its <a href="/wiki/Poland%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="PolandâUnited States relations">relations</a> with the United States, thus becoming one of its closest <a href="/wiki/Alliance" title="Alliance">allies</a> and strategic partners in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup> Historically, Poland maintained strong <a href="/wiki/Hungary%E2%80%93Poland_relations" title="HungaryâPoland relations">cultural and political</a> ties to Hungary; this special relationship was recognised by the parliaments of both countries in 2007 with the joint declaration of 23 March as "The Day of Polish-Hungarian Friendship".<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Polish_Armed_Forces" title="Polish Armed Forces">Polish Armed Forces</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:F-16_Jastrz%C4%85b_(48).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/F-16_Jastrz%C4%85b_%2848%29.jpg/220px-F-16_Jastrz%C4%85b_%2848%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/F-16_Jastrz%C4%85b_%2848%29.jpg/330px-F-16_Jastrz%C4%85b_%2848%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/F-16_Jastrz%C4%85b_%2848%29.jpg/440px-F-16_Jastrz%C4%85b_%2848%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="533" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Polish_Air_Force" title="Polish Air Force">Polish Air Force</a> <a href="/wiki/F-16_Fighting_Falcon" class="mw-redirect" title="F-16 Fighting Falcon">F-16s</a>, a single-engine <a href="/wiki/Multirole_combat_aircraft" title="Multirole combat aircraft">multirole</a> <a href="/wiki/Fighter_aircraft" title="Fighter aircraft">fighter aircraft</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>The Polish Armed Forces are composed of five branches â the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Land_Forces" title="Polish Land Forces">Land Forces</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Navy" title="Polish Navy">Navy</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Air_Force" title="Polish Air Force">Air Force</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Special_forces_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Special forces of Poland">Special Forces</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Territorial_Defence_Force_(Poland)" title="Territorial Defence Force (Poland)">Territorial Defence Force</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Mihalcova_2019_228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mihalcova_2019-228">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup> The military is subordinate to the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Defence_of_the_Republic_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of National Defence of the Republic of Poland">Ministry of National Defence of the Republic of Poland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Mihalcova_2019_228-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mihalcova_2019-228">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup> However, its commander-in-chief in peacetime is the president, who nominates officers, the Minister for National Defence and the chief of staff.<sup id="cite_ref-Mihalcova_2019_228-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mihalcova_2019-228">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup> Polish military tradition is generally commemorated by the <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_Day_(Poland)" title="Armed Forces Day (Poland)">Armed Forces Day</a>, celebrated annually on 15 August.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup> As of 2022, the Polish Armed Forces have a combined strength of 114,050 active soldiers, with a further 75,400 active in the <a href="/wiki/Military_Gendarmerie_(Poland)" title="Military Gendarmerie (Poland)">gendarmerie</a> and <a href="/wiki/Home_guard" title="Home guard">defence force</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-IISS_2022_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IISS_2022-230">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Poland is spending 2% of its GDP on defence, equivalent to approximately US$14.5 billion in 2022, with a slated increase to US$29 billion in 2023.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup> From 2022, Poland is set to spend 110 billion euros on the modernisation of its armed forces, in close cooperation with American, South Korean and local Polish <a href="/wiki/Arms_industry" title="Arms industry">defence manufacturers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup> Also, the Polish military is set to increase its size to 250,000 enlisted and officers, and 50,000 defence force personnel.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/SIPRI" class="mw-redirect" title="SIPRI">SIPRI</a>, the country exported â¬487 million worth of arms and armaments to foreign countries in 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Compulsory <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">military service</a> for men, who previously had to serve for nine months, was discontinued in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-Day_2008_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Day_2008-236">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup> Polish military doctrine reflects the same defensive nature as that of its NATO partners and the country actively hosts NATO's <a href="/wiki/Military_exercises" class="mw-redirect" title="Military exercises">military exercises</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-IISS_2022_230-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IISS_2022-230">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup> Since 1953, the country has been a large contributor to various United Nations peacekeeping missions,<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup> and currently maintains military presence in the Middle East, Africa, the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">Baltic states</a> and southeastern Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-IISS_2022_230-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IISS_2022-230">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Security.2C_law_enforcement_and_emergency_services"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Security,_law_enforcement_and_emergency_services">Security, law enforcement and emergency services</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Poland" title="Law enforcement in Poland">Law enforcement in Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emergency_medical_services_in_Poland" title="Emergency medical services in Poland">Emergency medical services in Poland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/State_Fire_Service" title="State Fire Service">State Fire Service</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter_Policja_Krakow_G719.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter_Policja_Krakow_G719.JPG/220px-Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter_Policja_Krakow_G719.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="154" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter_Policja_Krakow_G719.JPG/330px-Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter_Policja_Krakow_G719.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter_Policja_Krakow_G719.JPG/440px-Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter_Policja_Krakow_G719.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2784" data-file-height="1952" /></a><figcaption>A <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter" title="Mercedes-Benz Sprinter">Mercedes-Benz Sprinter</a> patrol van belonging to the Polish <a href="/wiki/Policja" class="mw-redirect" title="Policja">State Police Service</a> (<i>Policja</i>)</figcaption></figure>
<p>Thanks to its location, Poland is a country essentially free from the threat of natural disasters such as <a href="/wiki/Earthquakes" class="mw-redirect" title="Earthquakes">earthquakes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Volcanic_eruptions" class="mw-redirect" title="Volcanic eruptions">volcanic eruptions</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tornadoes" class="mw-redirect" title="Tornadoes">tornadoes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tropical_cyclones" class="mw-redirect" title="Tropical cyclones">tropical cyclones</a>. However, <a href="/wiki/Flood" title="Flood">floods</a> have occurred in low-lying areas from time to time during periods of extreme rainfall (e.g. during the <a href="/wiki/2010_Central_European_floods" title="2010 Central European floods">2010 Central European floods</a>).
</p><p>Law enforcement in Poland is performed by several agencies which are subordinate to the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Interior_and_Administration_(Poland)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Interior and Administration (Poland)">Ministry of Interior and Administration</a> â the <a href="/wiki/Policja" class="mw-redirect" title="Policja">State Police</a> (<i>Policja</i>), assigned to investigate crimes or transgression; the <a href="/wiki/City_Guard_(Poland)" title="City Guard (Poland)">Municipal City Guard</a>, which maintains public order; and several specialised agencies, such as the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Border_Guard" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish Border Guard">Polish Border Guard</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Narodowego_2013_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Narodowego_2013-238">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup> Private security firms are also common, although they possess no legal authority to arrest or detain a suspect.<sup id="cite_ref-Narodowego_2013_238-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Narodowego_2013-238">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup> Municipal guards are primarily headed by provincial, regional or city councils; individual guards are not permitted to carry <a href="/wiki/Firearms" class="mw-redirect" title="Firearms">firearms</a> unless instructed by the superior commanding officer.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup> Security service personnel conduct regular patrols in both large urban areas or smaller suburban localities.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Internal_Security_Agency" title="Internal Security Agency">Internal Security Agency</a> (ABW, or ISA in English) is the chief <a href="/wiki/Intelligence_agency" title="Intelligence agency">counter-intelligence instrument</a> safeguarding Poland's internal security, along with <a href="/wiki/Agencja_Wywiadu" class="mw-redirect" title="Agencja Wywiadu">Agencja Wywiadu</a> (AW) which identifies threats and collects secret information abroad.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">&#91;238&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Centralne_Biuro_%C5%9Aledcze_Policji" class="mw-redirect" title="Centralne Biuro Åledcze Policji">Central Investigation Bureau of Police</a> (CBÅP) and the <a href="/wiki/Central_Anticorruption_Bureau" title="Central Anticorruption Bureau">Central Anticorruption Bureau</a> (CBA) are responsible for countering organised crime and corruption in state and private institutions.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">&#91;239&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">&#91;240&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Emergency services in Poland consist of the <a href="/wiki/Emergency_medical_services_in_Poland" title="Emergency medical services in Poland">emergency medical services</a>, <a href="/wiki/Search_and_rescue#Poland" title="Search and rescue">search and rescue</a> units of the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Armed_Forces" title="Polish Armed Forces">Polish Armed Forces</a> and <a href="/wiki/State_Fire_Service" title="State Fire Service">State Fire Service</a>. Emergency medical services in Poland are operated by local and regional governments,<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup> but are a part of the centralised national agency â the <a href="/wiki/Emergency_medical_services_in_Poland" title="Emergency medical services in Poland">National Medical Emergency Service</a> (<i>PaÅstwowe Ratownictwo Medyczne</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<td>$340 billion <small>(2022)</small><sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Poland" title="Economy of Poland">Economy of Poland</a></div>
<p>As of 2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Poland&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, Poland's economy and gross domestic product (GDP) is the sixth largest in the European Union by <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_European_Union" title="Economy of the European Union">nominal standards</a> and the fifth largest by <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_in_Europe_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of sovereign states in Europe by GDP (PPP)">purchasing power parity</a>. It is also one of the fastest growing within the Union and reached a <a href="/wiki/Developed_market" title="Developed market">developed market</a> status in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup> The unemployment rate published by <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a> in 2023 amounted to 2.8%, which was the second-lowest in the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-Ministry_of_Family_and_Social_Policy_250-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ministry_of_Family_and_Social_Policy-250">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup> As of 2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Poland&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, around 62% of the employed population works in the <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">service sector</a>, 29% in manufacturing, and 8% in the agricultural sector.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">&#91;249&#93;</a></sup> Although Poland is a member of the <a href="/wiki/European_single_market" title="European single market">European single market</a>, the country has not adopted the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">Euro</a> as legal tender and maintains its own currency â the <a href="/wiki/Polish_z%C5%82oty" title="Polish zÅoty">Polish zÅoty</a> (zÅ, PLN).
</p><p>Poland is the regional economic leader in Central Europe, with nearly 40 per cent of the 500 biggest companies in the region (by revenues) as well as a <a href="/wiki/Globalisation_index" class="mw-redirect" title="Globalisation index">high globalisation rate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Polish_economy_seen_as_stable_and_competitive_254-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Polish_economy_seen_as_stable_and_competitive-254">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup> The country's largest firms compose the <a href="/wiki/WIG20" title="WIG20">WIG20</a> and <a href="/wiki/WIG30" title="WIG30">WIG30</a> <a href="/wiki/Stock_market_index" title="Stock market index">indexes</a>, which is traded on the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Stock_Exchange" title="Warsaw Stock Exchange">Warsaw Stock Exchange</a>. According to reports made by the <a href="/wiki/National_Bank_of_Poland" title="National Bank of Poland">National Bank of Poland</a>, the value of Polish foreign direct investments reached almost 300 billion <a href="/wiki/Polish_z%C5%82oty" title="Polish zÅoty">PLN</a> at the end of 2014. The <a href="/wiki/Central_Statistical_Office_(Poland)" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Statistical Office (Poland)">Central Statistical Office</a> estimated that in 2014 there were 1,437 Polish corporations with interests in 3,194 foreign entities.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Poland has the largest banking sector in Central Europe,<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup> with 32.3 branches per 100,000 adults.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup> It was the only European economy to have avoided the <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">recession of 2008</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Schwab_2011_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schwab_2011-258">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup> The country is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports" title="List of countries by exports">20th largest exporter</a> of goods and services in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup> Exports of goods and services are valued at approximately 56% of GDP, as of 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup> In 2019, Poland passed a law that would exempt workers under the age of 26 from <a href="/wiki/Income_tax" title="Income tax">income tax</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Poland" title="Tourism in Poland">Tourism in Poland</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Zamojski_ratusz_2.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Zamojski_ratusz_2.jpg/220px-Zamojski_ratusz_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Zamojski_ratusz_2.jpg/330px-Zamojski_ratusz_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Zamojski_ratusz_2.jpg/440px-Zamojski_ratusz_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6000" data-file-height="4000" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Zamo%C5%9B%C4%87" title="ZamoÅÄ">Old City of ZamoÅÄ</a> is a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Poland experienced a significant increase in the number of tourists after joining the European Union in 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-Travel_And_Tourism_in_Poland_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Travel_And_Tourism_in_Poland-262">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup> With over 21 million international arrivals in 2019, tourism contributes considerably to the overall economy and makes up a relatively large proportion of the country's service market.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Tourist attractions in Poland vary, from the mountains in the south to the sandy beaches in the north, with a trail of nearly every architectural style. The most visited city is <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="KrakÃ³w">KrakÃ³w</a>, which was the former capital of Poland and serves as a relic of the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Golden_Age" title="Polish Golden Age">Polish Golden Age</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_in_Poland" title="Renaissance in Poland">Renaissance</a>. KrakÃ³w also held <a href="/wiki/Royal_coronations_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Royal coronations in Poland">royal coronations</a> of <a href="/wiki/List_of_Polish_monarchs" title="List of Polish monarchs">most Polish kings and monarchs</a> at <a href="/wiki/Wawel" class="mw-redirect" title="Wawel">Wawel</a>, the nation's chief historical landmark. Among other notable sites in the country is <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw" title="WrocÅaw">WrocÅaw</a>, one of the oldest cities in Poland which was a model for the founding of KrakÃ³w. WrocÅaw is famous for its <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw%27s_dwarfs" class="mw-redirect" title="WrocÅaw&#39;s dwarfs">dwarf statues</a>, a large <a href="/wiki/Market_Square,_Wroc%C5%82aw" title="Market Square, WrocÅaw">market square</a> with two <a href="/wiki/Ratusz" title="Ratusz">town halls</a>, and the oldest <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw_Zoo" title="WrocÅaw Zoo">Zoological Gardens</a> with one of the world's largest number of animal <a href="/wiki/Species" title="Species">species</a>. The Polish capital <a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">Warsaw</a> and its historical <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Old_Town" class="mw-redirect" title="Warsaw Old Town">Old Town</a> were entirely reconstructed after <a href="/wiki/Destruction_of_Warsaw" title="Destruction of Warsaw">wartime destruction</a>. Other cities attracting countless tourists include <a href="/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk" title="GdaÅsk">GdaÅsk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pozna%C5%84" title="PoznaÅ">PoznaÅ</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lublin" title="Lublin">Lublin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toru%C5%84" title="ToruÅ">ToruÅ</a> as well as the site of the German <a href="/wiki/Auschwitz_concentration_camp" title="Auschwitz concentration camp">Auschwitz concentration camp</a> in <a href="/wiki/O%C5%9Bwi%C4%99cim" title="OÅwiÄcim">OÅwiÄcim</a>. A highlight is the 13th-century <a href="/wiki/Wieliczka_Salt_Mine" title="Wieliczka Salt Mine">Wieliczka Salt Mine</a> with its labyrinthine tunnels, <a href="/wiki/Underground_lake" title="Underground lake">underground lake</a> and chapels carved by miners out of <a href="/wiki/Rock_salt" class="mw-redirect" title="Rock salt">rock salt</a> beneath the ground.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">&#91;261&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Poland has a 770&#160;km long coastline of the southern <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a> with many wide sandy beaches, which are frequently visited by tourists in the summer season.
</p><p>Other tourist destinations include the <a href="/wiki/Masurian_Lake_District" title="Masurian Lake District">Masurian Lake District</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bia%C5%82owie%C5%BCa_Forest" title="BiaÅowieÅ¼a Forest">BiaÅowieÅ¼a Forest</a> in the east; on the south <a href="/wiki/Karkonosze" class="mw-redirect" title="Karkonosze">Karkonosze</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Table_Mountains" class="mw-redirect" title="Table Mountains">Table Mountains</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Tatra_Mountains" title="Tatra Mountains">Tatra Mountains</a>, where <a href="/wiki/Rysy" title="Rysy">Rysy</a> â the highest peak of Poland, and <a href="/wiki/Orla_Per%C4%87" title="Orla PerÄ">Eagle's Path</a> mountain trail are located. The <a href="/wiki/Pieniny" title="Pieniny">Pieniny</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bieszczady_Mountains" title="Bieszczady Mountains">Bieszczady Mountains</a> lie in the extreme south-east.<sup id="cite_ref-UNTWO_2008_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNTWO_2008-266">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup> There are <a href="/wiki/List_of_castles_in_Poland" title="List of castles in Poland">over 100 castles</a> in the country, most in the <a href="/wiki/Lower_Silesian_Voivodeship" title="Lower Silesian Voivodeship">Lower Silesian Voivodeship</a>, and also on the <a href="/wiki/Trail_of_the_Eagles%27_Nests" class="mw-redirect" title="Trail of the Eagles&#39; Nests">Trail of the Eagles' Nests</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup> The largest castle in the world by land area is situated in <a href="/wiki/Malbork_Castle" title="Malbork Castle">Malbork</a>, in north-central Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Poland" title="Transport in Poland">Transport in Poland</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:WK15_Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_(2)_Lichen99.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/WK15_Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_%282%29_Lichen99.jpg/220px-WK15_Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_%282%29_Lichen99.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/WK15_Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_%282%29_Lichen99.jpg/330px-WK15_Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_%282%29_Lichen99.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/WK15_Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_%282%29_Lichen99.jpg/440px-WK15_Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_%282%29_Lichen99.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="3072" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Polish_State_Railways" title="Polish State Railways">PKP Intercity</a> <a href="/wiki/New_Pendolino" title="New Pendolino">Pendolino</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_railway_station" title="WrocÅaw GÅÃ³wny railway station">WrocÅaw railway station</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Transport in Poland is provided by means of <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Poland" title="Rail transport in Poland">rail</a>, <a href="/wiki/Highways_in_Poland" title="Highways in Poland">road</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polish_Merchant_Navy" title="Polish Merchant Navy">marine shipping</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Poland" title="List of airports in Poland">air travel</a>. The country is part of EU's <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen Area</a> and is an important transport hub due to its strategic geographical position in Central Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup> Some of the longest European routes, including the <a href="/wiki/European_route_E30" title="European route E30">E30</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_route_E40" title="European route E40">E40</a>, run through Poland. The country has a good network of <a href="/wiki/Highways_in_Poland" title="Highways in Poland">highways</a> comprising <a href="/wiki/Limited-access_road" title="Limited-access road">express roads</a> and <a href="/wiki/Controlled-access_highway" title="Controlled-access highway">motorways</a>. As of August 2023, Poland has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_road_network_size" title="List of countries by road network size">21st-largest road network</a>, maintaining over 5,000&#160;km (3,100&#160;mi) of highways in use.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2022, the nation had 19,393 kilometres (12,050&#160;mi) of railway track, the third longest in the European Union after Germany and France.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">&#91;267&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Polish_State_Railways" title="Polish State Railways">Polish State Railways</a> (PKP) is the dominant railway operator, with certain major voivodeships or urban areas possessing their own <a href="/wiki/Commuter_rail" title="Commuter rail">commuter</a> and <a href="/wiki/Regional_rail" title="Regional rail">regional rail</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">&#91;268&#93;</a></sup> Poland has a number of international airports, the largest of which is <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Chopin_Airport" title="Warsaw Chopin Airport">Warsaw Chopin Airport</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup> It is the primary global hub for <a href="/wiki/LOT_Polish_Airlines" title="LOT Polish Airlines">LOT Polish Airlines</a>, the country's <a href="/wiki/Flag_carrier" title="Flag carrier">flag carrier</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">&#91;270&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Seaports exist all along Poland's Baltic coast, with most freight operations using <a href="/wiki/Port_of_%C5%9Awinouj%C5%9Bcie" title="Port of ÅwinoujÅcie">ÅwinoujÅcie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Police" title="Port of Police">Police</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Szczecin" title="Port of Szczecin">Szczecin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Ko%C5%82obrzeg" title="Port of KoÅobrzeg">KoÅobrzeg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Gdynia" title="Port of Gdynia">Gdynia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Gda%C5%84sk" title="Port of GdaÅsk">GdaÅsk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Elbl%C4%85g" title="ElblÄg">ElblÄg</a> as their base. The <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Gda%C5%84sk" title="Port of GdaÅsk">Port of GdaÅsk</a> is the only port in the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a> adapted to receive oceanic vessels. <a href="/wiki/Polferries" title="Polferries">Polferries</a> and <a href="/wiki/Unity_Line" title="Unity Line">Unity Line</a> are the largest Polish ferry operators, with the latter providing <a href="/wiki/Roll-on/roll-off" title="Roll-on/roll-off">roll-on/roll-off</a> and <a href="/wiki/Train_ferry" title="Train ferry">train ferry</a> services to <a href="/wiki/Scandinavia" title="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">&#91;271&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Poland" title="Energy in Poland">Energy in Poland</a></div>
<p>The electricity generation sector in Poland is largely <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel" title="Fossil fuel">fossil-fuel</a>âbased. Coal production in Poland is a major source of employment and the largest source of the nation's <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas_emissions" title="Greenhouse gas emissions">greenhouse gas emissions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-International_Energy_Agency_2022_276-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-International_Energy_Agency_2022-276">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup> Many power plants nationwide use Poland's position as a major European exporter of coal to their advantage by continuing to use coal as the primary raw material in the production of their energy. The three largest Polish coal mining firms (<a href="/wiki/W%C4%99glokoks" title="WÄglokoks">WÄglokoks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kompania_W%C4%99glowa" title="Kompania WÄglowa">Kompania WÄglowa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jastrz%C4%99bska_Sp%C3%B3%C5%82ka_W%C4%99glowa" title="JastrzÄbska SpÃ³Åka WÄglowa">JSW</a>) extract around 100 million tonnes of coal annually.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">&#91;273&#93;</a></sup> After coal, Polish energy supply relies significantly on oilâthe nation is the third-largest buyer of Russian oil exports to the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The new <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Poland" title="Energy in Poland">Energy Policy of Poland until 2040</a> (EPP2040) would reduce the share of coal and <a href="/wiki/Lignite" title="Lignite">lignite</a> in electricity generation by 25% from 2017 to 2030. The plan involves deploying new nuclear plants, increasing energy efficiency, and decarbonising the Polish transport system in order to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and prioritise long-term energy security.<sup id="cite_ref-International_Energy_Agency_2022_276-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-International_Energy_Agency_2022-276">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Polish_science_and_technology" title="Timeline of Polish science and technology">Timeline of Polish science and technology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Polish_people#Science_and_technology" title="Polish people">Polish people Â§&#160;Science and technology</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Marie_Curie_c1920.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Marie_Curie_c1920.jpg/150px-Marie_Curie_c1920.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="204" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Marie_Curie_c1920.jpg/225px-Marie_Curie_c1920.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Marie_Curie_c1920.jpg/300px-Marie_Curie_c1920.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1460" data-file-height="1984" /></a><figcaption>Physicist and chemist <a href="/wiki/Marie_Curie" title="Marie Curie">Marie Curie</a> was the first person to win two Nobel Prizes.<sup id="cite_ref-Mould_1993_280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mould_1993-280">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Over the course of history, the Polish people have made considerable contributions in the fields of science, technology and mathematics.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup> Perhaps the most renowned Pole to support this theory was <a href="/wiki/Nicolaus_Copernicus" title="Nicolaus Copernicus">Nicolaus Copernicus</a> (<i>MikoÅaj Kopernik</i>), who triggered the <a href="/wiki/Copernican_Revolution" title="Copernican Revolution">Copernican Revolution</a> by placing the <a href="/wiki/Heliocentrism" title="Heliocentrism">Sun rather than the Earth at the center of the universe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">&#91;278&#93;</a></sup> He also derived a <a href="/wiki/Quantity_theory_of_money" title="Quantity theory of money">quantity theory of money</a>, which made him a pioneer of economics. Copernicus' achievements and discoveries are considered the basis of Polish culture and cultural identity.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">&#91;279&#93;</a></sup> Poland was ranked 41st in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2023.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Nikolaus_Kopernikus.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Nikolaus_Kopernikus.jpg/170px-Nikolaus_Kopernikus.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="166" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Nikolaus_Kopernikus.jpg/255px-Nikolaus_Kopernikus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Nikolaus_Kopernikus.jpg/340px-Nikolaus_Kopernikus.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="1001" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Nicolaus_Copernicus" title="Nicolaus Copernicus">Nicolaus Copernicus</a>, the 16th century Polish astronomer who formulated the <a href="/wiki/Heliocentrism" title="Heliocentrism">heliocentric</a> model of the solar system</figcaption></figure>
<p>Poland's tertiary education institutions; traditional <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Poland" title="List of universities in Poland">universities</a>, as well as technical, medical, and economic institutions, employ around tens of thousands of researchers and staff members. There are hundreds of research and development institutes.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup> However, in the 19th and 20th centuries many Polish scientists worked abroad; one of the most important of these exiles was <a href="/wiki/Marie_Curie" title="Marie Curie">Marie Curie</a>, a physicist and chemist who lived much of her life in France. In 1925, she established Poland's <a href="/wiki/Curie_Institute_(Warsaw)" class="mw-redirect" title="Curie Institute (Warsaw)">Radium Institute</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Mould_1993_280-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mould_1993-280">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the first half of the 20th century, Poland was a flourishing centre of mathematics. Outstanding Polish mathematicians formed the <a href="/wiki/Lw%C3%B3w_School_of_Mathematics" title="LwÃ³w School of Mathematics">LwÃ³w School of Mathematics</a> (with <a href="/wiki/Stefan_Banach" title="Stefan Banach">Stefan Banach</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_Mazur" title="StanisÅaw Mazur">StanisÅaw Mazur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hugo_Steinhaus" title="Hugo Steinhaus">Hugo Steinhaus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_Ulam" title="StanisÅaw Ulam">StanisÅaw Ulam</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_School_of_Mathematics" class="mw-redirect" title="Warsaw School of Mathematics">Warsaw School of Mathematics</a> (with <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Tarski" title="Alfred Tarski">Alfred Tarski</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazimierz_Kuratowski" title="Kazimierz Kuratowski">Kazimierz Kuratowski</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wac%C5%82aw_Sierpi%C5%84ski" title="WacÅaw SierpiÅski">WacÅaw SierpiÅski</a> and <a href="/wiki/Antoni_Zygmund" title="Antoni Zygmund">Antoni Zygmund</a>). Numerous mathematicians, scientists, chemists or economists emigrated due to historic vicissitudes, among them <a href="/wiki/Benoit_Mandelbrot" title="Benoit Mandelbrot">Benoit Mandelbrot</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Hurwicz" title="Leonid Hurwicz">Leonid Hurwicz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Tarski" title="Alfred Tarski">Alfred Tarski</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Rotblat" title="Joseph Rotblat">Joseph Rotblat</a> and Nobel Prize laureates <a href="/wiki/Roald_Hoffmann" title="Roald Hoffmann">Roald Hoffmann</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georges_Charpak" title="Georges Charpak">Georges Charpak</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tadeusz_Reichstein" title="Tadeusz Reichstein">Tadeusz Reichstein</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Poland" title="Demographics of Poland">Demographics of Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Poland" title="List of cities and towns in Poland">List of cities and towns in Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_areas_in_Poland" title="Metropolitan areas in Poland">Metropolitan areas in Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polish_people" title="Polish people">Polish people</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Polish_diaspora" title="Polish diaspora">Polish diaspora</a></div>
<p>Poland has a population of approximately 38.2 million as of 2021, and is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_countries_by_population" title="List of European countries by population">ninth-most populous country</a> in Europe, as well as the fifth-most populous member state of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">&#91;282&#93;</a></sup> It has a population density of 122 inhabitants&#160;per square kilometre (320 inhabitants/sq&#160;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> was estimated at 1.33 children born to a woman in 2021, which is <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependencies_by_total_fertility_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="List of sovereign states and dependencies by total fertility rate">among the world's lowest</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup> Furthermore, Poland's population is <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_median_age" title="List of countries by median age">aging significantly</a>, and the country has a <a href="/wiki/Median_age" class="mw-redirect" title="Median age">median age</a> of 42.2.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Population_of_Poland.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Population_of_Poland.svg/240px-Population_of_Poland.svg.png" decoding="async" width="240" height="140" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Population_of_Poland.svg/360px-Population_of_Poland.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Population_of_Poland.svg/480px-Population_of_Poland.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="659" data-file-height="384" /></a><figcaption>Population of Poland from 1900 to 2010 in millions of inhabitants</figcaption></figure>
<p>Around 60% of the country's population lives in urban areas or major cities and 40% in rural zones.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">&#91;286&#93;</a></sup> In 2020, 50.2% of Poles resided in <a href="/wiki/Detached_dwelling" class="mw-redirect" title="Detached dwelling">detached dwellings</a> and 44.3% in apartments.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">&#91;287&#93;</a></sup> The most populous administrative province or state is the <a href="/wiki/Masovian_Voivodeship" title="Masovian Voivodeship">Masovian Voivodeship</a> and the most populous city is the capital, <a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">Warsaw</a>, at 1.8 million inhabitants with a further 2â3 million people living in its <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_metropolitan_area" title="Warsaw metropolitan area">metropolitan area</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">&#91;288&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">&#91;289&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">&#91;290&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Katowice_urban_area" title="Katowice urban area">metropolitan area</a> of <a href="/wiki/Katowice" title="Katowice">Katowice</a> is the largest urban <a href="/wiki/Conurbation" title="Conurbation">conurbation</a> with a population between 2.7 million<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">&#91;291&#93;</a></sup> and 5.3 million residents.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">&#91;292&#93;</a></sup> Population density is higher in the south of Poland and mostly concentrated between the cities of <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw" title="WrocÅaw">WrocÅaw</a> and <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="KrakÃ³w">KrakÃ³w</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">&#91;293&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Polish_census_of_2011" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish census of 2011">2011 Polish census</a>, 37,310,341 people reported <a href="/wiki/Polish_people" title="Polish people">Polish</a> identity, 846,719 <a href="/wiki/Silesians" title="Silesians">Silesian</a>, 232,547 <a href="/wiki/Kashubians" title="Kashubians">Kashubian</a> and 147,814 <a href="/wiki/German_minority_in_Poland" title="German minority in Poland">German</a>. Other <a href="/wiki/Polish_people#National_minorities" title="Polish people">identities</a> were reported by 163,363 people (0.41%) and 521,470 people (1.35%) did not specify any nationality.<sup id="cite_ref-Central_Statistical_Office_2015_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Central_Statistical_Office_2015-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> Official population statistics do not include migrant workers who do not possess a permanent residency permit or <a href="/wiki/Karta_Polaka" title="Karta Polaka">Karta Polaka</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup> More than 1.7 million <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians" title="Ukrainians">Ukrainian</a> citizens worked legally in Poland in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">&#91;295&#93;</a></sup> The number of migrants is rising steadily; the country approved 504,172 work permits for foreigners in 2021 alone.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">&#91;296&#93;</a></sup>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1148739982">.mw-parser-output .largestCities-table-background{background:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .largestCities-cell-background{background:#f0f0f0}</style>
</p>
<div>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Poland" title="Languages of Poland">Languages of Poland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bilingual_communes_in_Poland" title="Bilingual communes in Poland">Bilingual communes in Poland</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Dolina_Jadwigi_znak.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Dolina_Jadwigi_znak.jpg/240px-Dolina_Jadwigi_znak.jpg" decoding="async" width="240" height="126" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Dolina_Jadwigi_znak.jpg/360px-Dolina_Jadwigi_znak.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Dolina_Jadwigi_znak.jpg/480px-Dolina_Jadwigi_znak.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2778" data-file-height="1461" /></a><figcaption><i>Dolina Jadwigi</i>âa <a href="/wiki/Bilingual" class="mw-redirect" title="Bilingual">bilingual</a> Polish-<a href="/wiki/Kashubian_language" title="Kashubian language">Kashubian</a> road sign with the village name</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official</a> and predominant spoken language in Poland, and is one of the official <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_European_Union" title="Languages of the European Union">languages of the European Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">&#91;299&#93;</a></sup> It is also a <a href="/wiki/Second_language" title="Second language">second language</a> in parts of neighbouring <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">Lithuania</a>, where it is taught in Polish-minority schools.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">&#91;300&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">&#91;301&#93;</a></sup> Contemporary Poland is a linguistically <a href="/wiki/Homogeneous" class="mw-redirect" title="Homogeneous">homogeneous</a> nation, with 97% of respondents declaring Polish as their mother tongue.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">&#91;302&#93;</a></sup> There are currently 15 minority languages in Poland,<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">&#91;303&#93;</a></sup> including one recognised regional language, <a href="/wiki/Kashubian_language" title="Kashubian language">Kashubian</a>, which is spoken by approximately 100,000 people on a daily basis in the northern regions of <a href="/wiki/Kashubia" title="Kashubia">Kashubia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pomerania" title="Pomerania">Pomerania</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">&#91;304&#93;</a></sup> Poland also recognises <a href="/wiki/Bilingual_communes_in_Poland" title="Bilingual communes in Poland">secondary administrative languages or auxiliary languages in bilingual municipalities</a>, where bilingual signs and placenames are commonplace.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">&#91;305&#93;</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Centre_for_Public_Opinion_Research" title="Centre for Public Opinion Research">Centre for Public Opinion Research</a>, around 32% of Polish citizens declared knowledge of the English language in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">&#91;306&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Poland" title="Religion in Poland">Religion in Poland</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Pope_John_Paul_II_in_Krak%C3%B3w_%E2%80%93_1983.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Pope_John_Paul_II_in_Krak%C3%B3w_%E2%80%93_1983.jpg/170px-Pope_John_Paul_II_in_Krak%C3%B3w_%E2%80%93_1983.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="211" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Pope_John_Paul_II_in_Krak%C3%B3w_%E2%80%93_1983.jpg/255px-Pope_John_Paul_II_in_Krak%C3%B3w_%E2%80%93_1983.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Pope_John_Paul_II_in_Krak%C3%B3w_%E2%80%93_1983.jpg/340px-Pope_John_Paul_II_in_Krak%C3%B3w_%E2%80%93_1983.jpg 2x" data-file-width="765" data-file-height="949" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II" title="Pope John Paul II">John Paul II</a>, born Karol WojtyÅa, held the papacy between 1978â2005 and was the first <a href="/wiki/Polish_people" title="Polish people">Pole</a> to become a <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholic">Roman Catholic</a> Pope.</figcaption></figure>
<p>According to the 2021 census, 71.3% of all Polish citizens adhere to the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholic Church in Poland">Roman Catholic Church</a>, with 6.9% identifying as having no religion and 20.6% refusing to answer.<sup id="cite_ref-Census_2021_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census_2021-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Poland is one of the <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Europe" title="Religion in Europe">most religious countries in Europe</a>, where Roman Catholicism remains a part of national identity and Polish-born <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II" title="Pope John Paul II">Pope John Paul II</a> is widely revered.<sup id="cite_ref-Rocca_2022_311-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rocca_2022-311">&#91;307&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">&#91;308&#93;</a></sup> In 2015, 61.6% of respondents outlined that religion is of high or very high importance.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">&#91;309&#93;</a></sup> However, church attendance has greatly decreased in recent years; only 28% of Catholics attended <a href="/wiki/Mass_(liturgy)" title="Mass (liturgy)">mass</a> weekly in 2021, down from around half in 2000.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">&#91;310&#93;</a></sup> According to <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i>, "Of [the] more than 100 countries studied by the <i><a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research Center</a></i> in 2018, Poland was <a href="/wiki/Secularization" title="Secularization">secularizing</a> the fastest, as measured by the disparity between the religiosity of young people and their elders."<sup id="cite_ref-Rocca_2022_311-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rocca_2022-311">&#91;307&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Freedom of religion in Poland is guaranteed by the Constitution, and Poland's <a href="/wiki/Concordat" title="Concordat">concordat</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a> enables the teaching of religion in public schools.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">&#91;311&#93;</a></sup> Historically, the Polish state maintained a high degree of <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Confederation" title="Warsaw Confederation">religious tolerance</a> and provided asylum for refugees fleeing religious persecution in other parts of Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">&#91;312&#93;</a></sup> Poland hosted Europe's largest <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Poland" title="History of the Jews in Poland">Jewish diaspora</a>, and the country was a centre of <a href="/wiki/Ashkenazi_Jewish" class="mw-redirect" title="Ashkenazi Jewish">Ashkenazi Jewish</a> culture and traditional learning until the <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust" title="The Holocaust">Holocaust</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">&#91;313&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Contemporary religious minorities include <a href="/wiki/Polish_Orthodox_Church" title="Polish Orthodox Church">Orthodox Christians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Protestants" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestants">Protestants</a>âincluding <a href="/wiki/Lutherans" class="mw-redirect" title="Lutherans">Lutherans</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Evangelical-Augsburg_Church_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Evangelical-Augsburg Church in Poland">Evangelical-Augsburg Church</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pentecostalism" title="Pentecostalism">Pentecostals</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Pentecostal_Church_in_Poland" title="Pentecostal Church in Poland">Pentecostal Church in Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adventists" class="mw-redirect" title="Adventists">Adventists</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church" title="Seventh-day Adventist Church">Seventh-day Adventist Church</a>, and other smaller <a href="/wiki/Evangelicalism" title="Evangelicalism">Evangelical</a> denominationsâ<a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah&#39;s Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mariavite_Church" title="Mariavite Church">Mariavites</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Poland" title="History of the Jews in Poland">Jews</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Poland" title="Islam in Poland">Muslims</a> (<a href="/wiki/Tatars" title="Tatars">Tatars</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Modern_Paganism" class="mw-redirect" title="Modern Paganism">neopagans</a>, some of whom are members of the <a href="/wiki/Native_Polish_Church" title="Native Polish Church">Native Polish Church</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Central_Statistical_Office_2008_318-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Central_Statistical_Office_2008-318">&#91;314&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Pilgrimage" title="Pilgrimage">Pilgrimages</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Jasna_G%C3%B3ra_Monastery" title="Jasna GÃ³ra Monastery">Jasna GÃ³ra Monastery</a>, a shrine <a href="/wiki/The_Most_Holy_Virgin_Mary,_Queen_of_Poland#History" title="The Most Holy Virgin Mary, Queen of Poland">dedicated</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Black_Madonna_of_Cz%C4%99stochowa" title="Black Madonna of CzÄstochowa">Black Madonna</a>, take place annually.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">&#91;315&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Poland" title="Health in Poland">Health in Poland</a></div>
<p>Medical service providers and <a href="/wiki/Hospitals" class="mw-redirect" title="Hospitals">hospitals</a> (<i>szpitale</i>) in Poland are subordinate to the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_of_the_Republic_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Health of the Republic of Poland">Ministry of Health</a>; it provides administrative oversight and scrutiny of general medical practice, and is obliged to maintain a high standard of <a href="/wiki/Hygiene" title="Hygiene">hygiene</a> and patient care. Poland has a <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal healthcare system</a> based on an all-inclusive <a href="/wiki/Health_insurance" title="Health insurance">insurance system</a>; state subsidised healthcare is available to all citizens covered by the general health insurance program of the <a href="/wiki/National_Health_Fund" title="National Health Fund">National Health Fund</a> (NFZ). Private medical complexes exist nationwide; over 50% of the population uses both public and private sectors.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">&#91;316&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">&#91;317&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-justlanded_322-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-justlanded-322">&#91;318&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the <a href="/wiki/HDI" class="mw-redirect" title="HDI">Human Development Report</a> from 2020, the average life expectancy at birth is 79 years (around 75 years for an infant male and 83 years for an infant female);<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">&#91;319&#93;</a></sup> the country has a low <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Infant mortality rate">infant mortality rate</a> (4 per 1,000 births).<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">&#91;320&#93;</a></sup> In 2019, the principal cause of death was <a href="/wiki/Ischemic_heart_disease" class="mw-redirect" title="Ischemic heart disease">ischemic heart disease</a>; diseases of the <a href="/wiki/Circulatory_system" title="Circulatory system">circulatory system</a> accounted for 45% of all deaths.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">&#91;321&#93;</a></sup> In the same year, Poland was also the 15th-largest importer of <a href="/wiki/Medications" class="mw-redirect" title="Medications">medications</a> and pharmaceutical products.<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">&#91;322&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Poland" title="Education in Poland">Education in Poland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Universities_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Universities in Poland">Universities in Poland</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Jagiellonian_University_05.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Jagiellonian_University_05.jpg/220px-Jagiellonian_University_05.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="112" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Jagiellonian_University_05.jpg/330px-Jagiellonian_University_05.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Jagiellonian_University_05.jpg/440px-Jagiellonian_University_05.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6016" data-file-height="3055" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Jagiellonian_University" title="Jagiellonian University">Jagiellonian University</a> in <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="KrakÃ³w">KrakÃ³w</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Jagiellonian_University" title="Jagiellonian University">Jagiellonian University</a> founded in 1364 by <a href="/wiki/Casimir_III_the_Great" title="Casimir III the Great">Casimir III</a> in <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="KrakÃ³w">KrakÃ³w</a> was the first institution of higher learning established in Poland, and is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_oldest_universities_in_continuous_operation" title="List of oldest universities in continuous operation">oldest universities</a> still in continuous operation.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">&#91;323&#93;</a></sup> Poland's <a href="/wiki/Commission_of_National_Education" title="Commission of National Education">Commission of National Education</a> (<i>Komisja Edukacji Narodowej</i>), established in 1773, was the world's first state ministry of education.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">&#91;324&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">&#91;325&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The framework for primary, secondary and higher tertiary education are established by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Education_(Poland)" title="Ministry of National Education (Poland)">Ministry of Education and Science</a>. Kindergarten attendance is optional for children aged between three and five, with one year being <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_education" title="Compulsory education">compulsory</a> for six-year-olds.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">&#91;326&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Sejm_2016_331-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sejm_2016-331">&#91;327&#93;</a></sup> Primary education traditionally begins at the age of seven, although children aged six can attend at the request of their parents or guardians.<sup id="cite_ref-Sejm_2016_331-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sejm_2016-331">&#91;327&#93;</a></sup> Elementary school spans eight grades and secondary schooling is dependent on student preference â a four-year high school (<i><a href="/wiki/General_education_liceum" title="General education liceum">liceum</a></i>), a five-year technical school (<i><a href="/wiki/Technikum_(Polish_education)" title="Technikum (Polish education)">technikum</a></i>) or various <a href="/wiki/Vocational_school" title="Vocational school">vocational studies</a> (<i>szkoÅa branÅ¼owa</i>) can be pursued by each individual pupil.<sup id="cite_ref-Sejm_2016_331-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sejm_2016-331">&#91;327&#93;</a></sup> A liceum or technikum is concluded with a maturity exit exam (<i><a href="/wiki/Matura" title="Matura">matura</a></i>), which must be passed in order to apply for a university or other institutions of higher learning.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">&#91;328&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In Poland, there are over 500 university-level institutions,<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">&#91;329&#93;</a></sup> with technical, medical, economic, agricultural, pedagogical, theological, musical, maritime and military faculties.<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">&#91;330&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/University_of_Warsaw" title="University of Warsaw">University of Warsaw</a> and <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Polytechnic" class="mw-redirect" title="Warsaw Polytechnic">Warsaw Polytechnic</a>, the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Wroc%C5%82aw" title="University of WrocÅaw">University of WrocÅaw</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adam_Mickiewicz_University_in_Pozna%C5%84" title="Adam Mickiewicz University in PoznaÅ">Adam Mickiewicz University in PoznaÅ</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk_University_of_Technology" title="GdaÅsk University of Technology">University of Technology in GdaÅsk</a> are among the most prominent.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">&#91;331&#93;</a></sup> There are three conventional <a href="/wiki/Academic_degree" title="Academic degree">academic degrees</a> in Poland â <i><a href="/wiki/Licentiate_(degree)" title="Licentiate (degree)">licencjat</a></i> or <i><a href="/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree" title="Bachelor&#39;s degree">inÅ¼ynier</a></i> (first cycle qualification), <i><a href="/wiki/Magister_(degree)" class="mw-redirect" title="Magister (degree)">magister</a></i> (second cycle qualification) and <i><a href="/wiki/PhD" class="mw-redirect" title="PhD">doktor</a></i> (third cycle qualification).<sup id="cite_ref-OECD_2009_336-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD_2009-336">&#91;332&#93;</a></sup> In 2018, the <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">Programme for International Student Assessment</a>, coordinated by the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a>, ranked Poland's educational system higher than the OECD average; the study showed that students in Poland perform better academically than in most OECD countries.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">&#91;333&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Poland" title="Culture of Poland">Culture of Poland</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Sigismund%27s_Chapel_01_AB.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Sigismund%27s_Chapel_01_AB.jpg/220px-Sigismund%27s_Chapel_01_AB.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Sigismund%27s_Chapel_01_AB.jpg/330px-Sigismund%27s_Chapel_01_AB.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Sigismund%27s_Chapel_01_AB.jpg/440px-Sigismund%27s_Chapel_01_AB.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3600" data-file-height="2740" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Poland" title="Coat of arms of Poland">Polish White Eagle</a> is Poland's enduring <a href="/wiki/National_symbols_of_Poland" title="National symbols of Poland">national and cultural symbol</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The culture of Poland is closely connected with its intricate 1,000-year <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland" title="History of Poland">history</a>, and forms an important constituent in the <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">Western civilisation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">&#91;334&#93;</a></sup> The Poles take great pride in their national identity which is often associated with the colours white and red, and exuded by the expression <i>biaÅo-czerwoni</i> ("whitereds").<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">&#91;335&#93;</a></sup> National symbols, chiefly the crowned <a href="/wiki/White-tailed_eagle" title="White-tailed eagle">white-tailed eagle</a>, are often visible on clothing, insignia and emblems.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">&#91;336&#93;</a></sup> The architectural monuments of great importance are protected by the <a href="/wiki/National_Heritage_Board_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="National Heritage Board of Poland">National Heritage Board of Poland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">&#91;337&#93;</a></sup> Over 100 of the country's most significant tangible wonders were enlisted onto the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Historic_Monuments_(Poland)" title="List of Historic Monuments (Poland)">Historic Monuments Register</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">&#91;338&#93;</a></sup> with further 17 being recognised by <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> as World Heritage Sites.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">&#91;339&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Holidays_and_traditions">Holidays and traditions</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Christmas_in_Poland" title="Christmas in Poland">Christmas in Poland</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Celebraci%C3%B3n_de_Todos_los_Santos,_cementerio_de_la_Santa_Cruz,_Gniezno,_Polonia,_2017-11-01,_DD_10-12_HDR.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Celebraci%C3%B3n_de_Todos_los_Santos%2C_cementerio_de_la_Santa_Cruz%2C_Gniezno%2C_Polonia%2C_2017-11-01%2C_DD_10-12_HDR.jpg/220px-Celebraci%C3%B3n_de_Todos_los_Santos%2C_cementerio_de_la_Santa_Cruz%2C_Gniezno%2C_Polonia%2C_2017-11-01%2C_DD_10-12_HDR.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Celebraci%C3%B3n_de_Todos_los_Santos%2C_cementerio_de_la_Santa_Cruz%2C_Gniezno%2C_Polonia%2C_2017-11-01%2C_DD_10-12_HDR.jpg/330px-Celebraci%C3%B3n_de_Todos_los_Santos%2C_cementerio_de_la_Santa_Cruz%2C_Gniezno%2C_Polonia%2C_2017-11-01%2C_DD_10-12_HDR.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Celebraci%C3%B3n_de_Todos_los_Santos%2C_cementerio_de_la_Santa_Cruz%2C_Gniezno%2C_Polonia%2C_2017-11-01%2C_DD_10-12_HDR.jpg/440px-Celebraci%C3%B3n_de_Todos_los_Santos%2C_cementerio_de_la_Santa_Cruz%2C_Gniezno%2C_Polonia%2C_2017-11-01%2C_DD_10-12_HDR.jpg 2x" data-file-width="8140" data-file-height="5427" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/All_Saints%27_Day" title="All Saints&#39; Day">All Saints' Day</a> on 1 November is one of the most important public holidays in Poland.</figcaption></figure>
