<p>There are 13 government-approved annual public holidays â New Year on 1 January, <a href="/wiki/Epiphany_(holiday)" title="Epiphany (holiday)">Three Kings' Day</a> on 6 January, <a href="/wiki/Easter_Sunday" class="mw-redirect" title="Easter Sunday">Easter Sunday</a> and <a href="/wiki/Easter_Monday" title="Easter Monday">Easter Monday</a>, <a href="/wiki/International_Workers%27_Day" title="International Workers&#39; Day">Labour Day</a> on 1 May, <a href="/wiki/3_May_Constitution_Day" title="3 May Constitution Day">Constitution Day</a> on 3 May, <a href="/wiki/Pentecost" title="Pentecost">Pentecost</a>, <a href="/wiki/Feast_of_Corpus_Christi" title="Feast of Corpus Christi">Corpus Christi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Assumption_of_Mary" title="Assumption of Mary">Feast of the Assumption</a> on 15 August, <a href="/wiki/All_Saints%27_Day" title="All Saints&#39; Day">All Saints' Day</a> on 1 November, <a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(Poland)" class="mw-redirect" title="Independence Day (Poland)">Independence Day</a> on 11 November and Christmastide on 25 and 26 December.<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">&#91;340&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Particular traditions and superstitious customs observed in Poland are not found elsewhere in Europe. Though Christmas Eve (<i><a href="/wiki/Wigilia" title="Wigilia">Wigilia</a></i>) is not a public holiday, it remains the most memorable day of the entire year. <a href="/wiki/Christmas_trees" class="mw-redirect" title="Christmas trees">Trees</a> are decorated on 24 December, hay is placed under the tablecloth to resemble Jesus' <a href="/wiki/Manger" title="Manger">manger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christmas_wafer" title="Christmas wafer">Christmas wafers</a> (<i>opÅatek</i>) are shared between gathered guests and a <a href="/wiki/Twelve-dish_Christmas_Eve_supper" title="Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper">twelve-dish meatless supper</a> is served that same evening when the <a href="/wiki/Star_of_Bethlehem" title="Star of Bethlehem">first star</a> appears.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">&#91;341&#93;</a></sup> An empty plate and seat are symbolically left at the table for an unexpected guest.<sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">&#91;342&#93;</a></sup> On occasion, <a href="/wiki/Christmas_carols" class="mw-redirect" title="Christmas carols">carolers</a> journey around smaller towns with a folk <a href="/wiki/Turo%C5%84" title="TuroÅ">TuroÅ</a> creature until the <a href="/wiki/Lent" title="Lent">Lent</a> period.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">&#91;343&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>A widely-popular <a href="/wiki/P%C4%85czki" title="PÄczki">doughnut</a> and sweet pastry feast occurs on <a href="/wiki/Fat_Thursday" title="Fat Thursday">Fat Thursday</a>, usually 52 days prior to Easter.<sup id="cite_ref-Borodo_2020_348-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Borodo_2020-348">&#91;344&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Easter_egg" title="Easter egg">Eggs</a> for <a href="/wiki/Easter_Sunday" class="mw-redirect" title="Easter Sunday">Holy Sunday</a> are painted and placed in decorated <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Awi%C4%99conka" title="ÅwiÄconka">baskets</a> that are previously blessed by clergymen in churches on <a href="/wiki/Easter_Saturday" title="Easter Saturday">Easter Saturday</a>. Easter Monday is celebrated with pagan <i><a href="/wiki/%C5%9Amigus-dyngus" title="Åmigus-dyngus">dyngus</a></i> festivities, where the youth is engaged in water fights.<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">&#91;345&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Borodo_2020_348-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Borodo_2020-348">&#91;344&#93;</a></sup> Cemeteries and graves of the deceased are annually visited by family members on All Saints' Day; tombstones are cleaned as a sign of respect and candles are lit to honour the dead on an unprecedented scale.<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">&#91;346&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Poland" title="Music of Poland">Music of Poland</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:148px;max-width:148px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Frederic_Chopin_photo.jpeg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="FrÃ©dÃ©ric Chopin" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Frederic_Chopin_photo.jpeg/146px-Frederic_Chopin_photo.jpeg" decoding="async" width="146" height="209" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Frederic_Chopin_photo.jpeg/219px-Frederic_Chopin_photo.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Frederic_Chopin_photo.jpeg/292px-Frederic_Chopin_photo.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="1014" data-file-height="1455" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric_Chopin" title="FrÃ©dÃ©ric Chopin">FrÃ©dÃ©ric Chopin</a> was a renowned classical composer and virtuoso pianist.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:140px;max-width:140px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Optreden_Arthur_Rubinstein_in_Concertgebouw,_Bestanddeelnr_913-5228.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Artur Rubinstein" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Optreden_Arthur_Rubinstein_in_Concertgebouw%2C_Bestanddeelnr_913-5228.jpg/138px-Optreden_Arthur_Rubinstein_in_Concertgebouw%2C_Bestanddeelnr_913-5228.jpg" decoding="async" width="138" height="209" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Optreden_Arthur_Rubinstein_in_Concertgebouw%2C_Bestanddeelnr_913-5228.jpg/207px-Optreden_Arthur_Rubinstein_in_Concertgebouw%2C_Bestanddeelnr_913-5228.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Optreden_Arthur_Rubinstein_in_Concertgebouw%2C_Bestanddeelnr_913-5228.jpg/276px-Optreden_Arthur_Rubinstein_in_Concertgebouw%2C_Bestanddeelnr_913-5228.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2406" data-file-height="3648" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Arthur_Rubinstein" title="Arthur Rubinstein">Artur Rubinstein</a> was one of the greatest concert pianists of the 20th century.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Artists from Poland, including famous musicians such as <a href="/wiki/Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric_Chopin" title="FrÃ©dÃ©ric Chopin">FrÃ©dÃ©ric Chopin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artur_Rubinstein" class="mw-redirect" title="Artur Rubinstein">Artur Rubinstein</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ignacy_Jan_Paderewski" title="Ignacy Jan Paderewski">Ignacy Jan Paderewski</a>, <a href="/wiki/Krzysztof_Penderecki" title="Krzysztof Penderecki">Krzysztof Penderecki</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henryk_Wieniawski" title="Henryk Wieniawski">Henryk Wieniawski</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karol_Szymanowski" title="Karol Szymanowski">Karol Szymanowski</a>, and traditional, regionalised <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk composers</a> create a lively and diverse music scene, which even recognises its own music genres, such as <a href="/wiki/Sung_poetry" title="Sung poetry">sung poetry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Disco_polo" title="Disco polo">disco polo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">&#91;347&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The origins of Polish music can be traced to the 13th century; manuscripts have been found in <a href="/wiki/Stary_S%C4%85cz" title="Stary SÄcz">Stary SÄcz</a> containing <a href="/wiki/Polyphony" title="Polyphony">polyphonic</a> compositions related to the Parisian <a href="/wiki/Notre_Dame_School" class="mw-redirect" title="Notre Dame School">Notre Dame School</a>. Other early compositions, such as the melody of <i><a href="/wiki/Bogurodzica" title="Bogurodzica">Bogurodzica</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/God_Is_Born" title="God Is Born">God Is Born</a></i> (a coronation <a href="/wiki/Polonaise_(dance)" class="mw-redirect" title="Polonaise (dance)">polonaise tune</a> for Polish kings by an unknown composer), may also date back to this period, however, the first known notable composer, <a href="/wiki/Miko%C5%82aj_z_Radomia" title="MikoÅaj z Radomia">Nicholas of Radom</a>, lived in the 15th century. <a href="/wiki/Diomedes_Cato" title="Diomedes Cato">Diomedes Cato</a>, a native-born Italian who lived in KrakÃ³w, became a renowned lutenist at the court of Sigismund III; he not only imported some of the musical styles from southern Europe but blended them with native folk music.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Music_Courts_of_the_Polish_Vasas_352-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Music_Courts_of_the_Polish_Vasas-352">&#91;348&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 17th and 18th centuries, Polish baroque composers wrote <a href="/wiki/Liturgical_music" title="Liturgical music">liturgical music</a> and secular compositions such as concertos and <a href="/wiki/Sonata" title="Sonata">sonatas</a> for voices or instruments. At the end of the 18th century, Polish classical music evolved into national forms like the <a href="/wiki/Polonaise" title="Polonaise">polonaise</a>. <a href="/wiki/Wojciech_Bogus%C5%82awski" title="Wojciech BogusÅawski">Wojciech BogusÅawski</a> is accredited with composing the first Polish national opera, titled <i><a href="https://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krakowiacy_i_G%C3%B3rale" class="extiw" title="pl:Krakowiacy i GÃ³rale">Krakowiacy i GÃ³rale</a></i>, which premiered in 1794.<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">&#91;349&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1134653256">.mw-parser-output .side-box{margin:4px 0;box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid #aaa;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em;background-color:#f9f9f9;display:flow-root}.mw-parser-output .side-box-abovebelow,.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{padding:0.25em 0.9em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-image{padding:2px 0 2px 0.9em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-imageright{padding:2px 0.9em 2px 0;text-align:center}@media(min-width:500px){.mw-parser-output .side-box-flex{display:flex;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{flex:1}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .side-box{width:238px}.mw-parser-output .side-box-right{clear:right;float:right;margin-left:1em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-left{margin-right:1em}}</style><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096940132">.mw-parser-output .listen .side-box-text{line-height:1.1em}.mw-parser-output .listen-plain{border:none;background:transparent}.mw-parser-output .listen-embedded{width:100%;margin:0;border-width:1px 0 0 0;background:transparent}.mw-parser-output .listen-header{padding:2px}.mw-parser-output .listen-embedded .listen-header{padding:2px 0}.mw-parser-output .listen-file-header{padding:4px 0}.mw-parser-output .listen .description{padding-top:2px}.mw-parser-output .listen .mw-tmh-player{max-width:100%}@media(max-width:719px){.mw-parser-output .listen{clear:both}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .listen:not(.listen-noimage){width:320px}.mw-parser-output .listen-left{overflow:visible;float:left}.mw-parser-output .listen-center{float:none;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto}}</style><div class="side-box side-box-left listen noprint listen-left"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409">
<div class="side-box-flex">
<div class="side-box-image"><figure class="mw-halign-center" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="50" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/75px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/100px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="160" data-file-height="160" /></span><figcaption></figcaption></figure></div>
<div class="side-box-text plainlist"><div class="listen-header"><b><a href="/wiki/Fryderyk_Chopin" class="mw-redirect" title="Fryderyk Chopin">Fryderyk Chopin</a></b></div>
<div class="haudio">
<div class="listen-file-header"><a href="/wiki/File:Frederic_Chopin_-_mazurka_no._4_in_a_minor,_op._17.ogg" title="File:Frederic Chopin - mazurka no. 4 in a minor, op. 17.ogg">Mazurka no. 4 in a minor, op. 17</a></div>
<div><span typeof="mw:File"><span><audio id="mwe_player_1" controls="" preload="none" class="mw-file-element" width="232" style="width:232px;" data-durationhint="335" data-mwtitle="Frederic_Chopin_-_mazurka_no._4_in_a_minor,_op._17.ogg" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/ca/Frederic_Chopin_-_mazurka_no._4_in_a_minor%2C_op._17.ogg" type="audio/ogg; codecs=&quot;vorbis&quot;" data-width="0" data-height="0" /><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/c/ca/Frederic_Chopin_-_mazurka_no._4_in_a_minor%2C_op._17.ogg/Frederic_Chopin_-_mazurka_no._4_in_a_minor%2C_op._17.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" data-height="0" /></audio></span></span></div>
<div class="description"><a href="/wiki/Mazurka" title="Mazurka">Mazurka</a> (<a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a>: <i lang="pl">mazurek</i>), stylised <a href="/wiki/Folk_dance" title="Folk dance">folk dance</a> in <a href="/wiki/Triple_meter" class="mw-redirect" title="Triple meter">triple meter</a> (1832), commemorating the <a href="/wiki/November_Uprising" title="November Uprising">November Uprising</a></div></div></div></div>
</div>
<p>Poland today has an active music scene, with the jazz and metal genres being particularly popular among the contemporary populace. Polish jazz musicians such as <a href="/wiki/Krzysztof_Komeda" title="Krzysztof Komeda">Krzysztof Komeda</a> created a unique style, which was most famous in the 1960s and 1970s and continues to be popular to this day. Poland has also become a major venue for large-scale music festivals, chief among which are the <a href="/wiki/Pol%27and%27Rock_Festival" title="Pol&#39;and&#39;Rock Festival">Pol'and'Rock Festival</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">&#91;350&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Open%27er_Festival" title="Open&#39;er Festival">Open'er Festival</a>, <a href="/wiki/Opole_Festival" class="mw-redirect" title="Opole Festival">Opole Festival</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sopot_Festival" class="mw-redirect" title="Sopot Festival">Sopot Festival</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">&#91;351&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art">Art</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Art_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Art in Poland">Art in Poland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Young_Poland" title="Young Poland">Young Poland</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:293px;max-width:293px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:137px;max-width:137px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Matejko_Self-portrait.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Jan Matejko" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Matejko_Self-portrait.jpg/135px-Matejko_Self-portrait.jpg" decoding="async" width="135" height="201" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Matejko_Self-portrait.jpg/203px-Matejko_Self-portrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Matejko_Self-portrait.jpg/270px-Matejko_Self-portrait.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1631" data-file-height="2433" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Jan_Matejko" title="Jan Matejko">Jan Matejko</a>, leading Polish <a href="/wiki/History_painting" title="History painting">history painter</a> whose works depict Poland's heritage and key historical events</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:152px;max-width:152px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Lady_with_an_Ermine_-_Leonardo_da_Vinci_(adjusted_levels).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Lady with an Ermine" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Lady_with_an_Ermine_-_Leonardo_da_Vinci_%28adjusted_levels%29.jpg/150px-Lady_with_an_Ermine_-_Leonardo_da_Vinci_%28adjusted_levels%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="202" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Lady_with_an_Ermine_-_Leonardo_da_Vinci_%28adjusted_levels%29.jpg/225px-Lady_with_an_Ermine_-_Leonardo_da_Vinci_%28adjusted_levels%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Lady_with_an_Ermine_-_Leonardo_da_Vinci_%28adjusted_levels%29.jpg/300px-Lady_with_an_Ermine_-_Leonardo_da_Vinci_%28adjusted_levels%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="2754" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><i><a href="/wiki/Lady_with_an_Ermine" title="Lady with an Ermine">Lady with an Ermine</a></i> (1490) by <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">Leonardo da Vinci</a> is displayed in the <a href="/wiki/Czartoryski_Museum" title="Czartoryski Museum">Czartoryski Museum</a> in KrakÃ³w.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Art in Poland has invariably reflected <a href="/wiki/Art_of_Europe" title="Art of Europe">European</a> trends, with Polish painting pivoted on <a href="/wiki/Folklore" title="Folklore">folklore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_art" title="Catholic art">Catholic themes</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_painting" title="History painting">historicism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Realism_(arts)" title="Realism (arts)">realism</a>, but also on <a href="/wiki/Impressionism" title="Impressionism">impressionism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Romanticism_in_Poland" title="Romanticism in Poland">romanticism</a>. An important art movement was <a href="/wiki/Young_Poland" title="Young Poland">Young Poland</a>, developed in the late 19th century for promoting <a href="/wiki/Decadent_movement" title="Decadent movement">decadence</a>, <a href="/wiki/Symbolism_(arts)" title="Symbolism (arts)">symbolism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Art_nouveau" class="mw-redirect" title="Art nouveau">art nouveau</a>. Since the 20th century Polish documentary art and photography has enjoyed worldwide fame, especially the <a href="/wiki/Polish_School_of_Posters" title="Polish School of Posters">Polish School of Posters</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MFA_356-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MFA-356">&#91;352&#93;</a></sup> One of the most distinguished paintings in Poland is <i><a href="/wiki/Lady_with_an_Ermine" title="Lady with an Ermine">Lady with an Ermine</a></i> (1490) by <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">Leonardo da Vinci</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">&#91;353&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Internationally renowned Polish artists include <a href="/wiki/Jan_Matejko" title="Jan Matejko">Jan Matejko</a> (historicism), <a href="/wiki/Jacek_Malczewski" title="Jacek Malczewski">Jacek Malczewski</a> (symbolism), <a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_Wyspia%C5%84ski" title="StanisÅaw WyspiaÅski">StanisÅaw WyspiaÅski</a> (art nouveau), <a href="/wiki/Henryk_Siemiradzki" title="Henryk Siemiradzki">Henryk Siemiradzki</a> (Roman <a href="/wiki/Academic_art" title="Academic art">academic art</a>), <a href="/wiki/Tamara_de_Lempicka" title="Tamara de Lempicka">Tamara de Lempicka</a> (<a href="/wiki/Art_deco" class="mw-redirect" title="Art deco">art deco</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Zdzis%C5%82aw_Beksi%C5%84ski" title="ZdzisÅaw BeksiÅski">ZdzisÅaw BeksiÅski</a> (dystopian <a href="/wiki/Surrealism" title="Surrealism">surrealism</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">&#91;354&#93;</a></sup> Several Polish artists and sculptors were also acclaimed representatives of <a href="/wiki/Avant-garde" title="Avant-garde">avant-garde</a>, <a href="/wiki/Constructivism_(art)" title="Constructivism (art)">constructivist</a>, <a href="/wiki/Minimalism" title="Minimalism">minimalist</a> and contemporary art movements, including <a href="/wiki/Katarzyna_Kobro" title="Katarzyna Kobro">Katarzyna Kobro</a>, <a href="/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_Strzemi%C5%84ski" title="WÅadysÅaw StrzemiÅski">WÅadysÅaw StrzemiÅski</a>, <a href="/wiki/Magdalena_Abakanowicz" title="Magdalena Abakanowicz">Magdalena Abakanowicz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alina_Szapocznikow" title="Alina Szapocznikow">Alina Szapocznikow</a>, <a href="/wiki/Igor_Mitoraj" title="Igor Mitoraj">Igor Mitoraj</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_Sasnal" title="Wilhelm Sasnal">Wilhelm Sasnal</a>.
</p><p>Notable art academies in Poland include the <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w_Academy_of_Fine_Arts" class="mw-redirect" title="KrakÃ³w Academy of Fine Arts">KrakÃ³w Academy of Fine Arts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Academy_of_Fine_Arts_in_Warsaw" class="mw-redirect" title="Academy of Fine Arts in Warsaw">Academy of Fine Arts in Warsaw</a>, <a href="/wiki/Art_Academy_of_Szczecin" title="Art Academy of Szczecin">Art Academy of Szczecin</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Fine_Arts_in_Pozna%C5%84" class="mw-redirect" title="University of Fine Arts in PoznaÅ">University of Fine Arts in PoznaÅ</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Eugeniusz_Geppert_Academy_of_Fine_Arts" title="Eugeniusz Geppert Academy of Fine Arts">Geppert Academy of Fine Arts in WrocÅaw</a>. Contemporary works are exhibited at <a href="/wiki/Zach%C4%99ta" class="mw-redirect" title="ZachÄta">ZachÄta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ujazd%C3%B3w_Castle" title="UjazdÃ³w Castle">UjazdÃ³w</a>, and <a href="/wiki/MOCAK,_Museum_of_Contemporary_Art_in_Krak%C3%B3w" class="mw-redirect" title="MOCAK, Museum of Contemporary Art in KrakÃ³w">MOCAK</a> art galleries.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">&#91;355&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Poland" title="Architecture of Poland">Architecture of Poland</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:293px;max-width:293px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:154px;max-width:154px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:St_Mary%27s_Krakow.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Saint Mary&#39;s Church in KrakÃ³w" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/St_Mary%27s_Krakow.jpg/152px-St_Mary%27s_Krakow.jpg" decoding="async" width="152" height="217" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/St_Mary%27s_Krakow.jpg/228px-St_Mary%27s_Krakow.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/St_Mary%27s_Krakow.jpg/304px-St_Mary%27s_Krakow.jpg 2x" data-file-width="847" data-file-height="1211" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/St._Mary%27s_Basilica,_Krak%C3%B3w" title="St. Mary&#39;s Basilica, KrakÃ³w">St. Mary's Basilica</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Main_Market_Square,_Krak%C3%B3w" class="mw-redirect" title="Main Market Square, KrakÃ³w">Main Market Square</a> in <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="KrakÃ³w">KrakÃ³w</a> is an example of <a href="/wiki/Brick_Gothic" title="Brick Gothic">Brick Gothic</a> architecture.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:135px;max-width:135px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Ayuntamiento,_Poznan,_Polonia,_2014-09-18,_DD_67-72_HDR.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="PoznaÅ City Hall" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Ayuntamiento%2C_Poznan%2C_Polonia%2C_2014-09-18%2C_DD_67-72_HDR.jpg/133px-Ayuntamiento%2C_Poznan%2C_Polonia%2C_2014-09-18%2C_DD_67-72_HDR.jpg" decoding="async" width="133" height="218" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Ayuntamiento%2C_Poznan%2C_Polonia%2C_2014-09-18%2C_DD_67-72_HDR.jpg/200px-Ayuntamiento%2C_Poznan%2C_Polonia%2C_2014-09-18%2C_DD_67-72_HDR.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Ayuntamiento%2C_Poznan%2C_Polonia%2C_2014-09-18%2C_DD_67-72_HDR.jpg/266px-Ayuntamiento%2C_Poznan%2C_Polonia%2C_2014-09-18%2C_DD_67-72_HDR.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3088" data-file-height="5064" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">The 16th-century <a href="/wiki/Pozna%C5%84_Town_Hall" title="PoznaÅ Town Hall">City Hall</a> of <a href="/wiki/Pozna%C5%84" title="PoznaÅ">PoznaÅ</a> illustrates the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_in_Poland" title="Renaissance in Poland">Renaissance</a> style.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Poland" title="Architecture of Poland">architecture of Poland</a> reflects <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Architecture of Europe">European architectural</a> styles, with strong historical influences derived from <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Italy" title="Architecture of Italy">Italy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Germany" title="Architecture of Germany">Germany</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Low_Countries" title="Low Countries">Low Countries</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">&#91;356&#93;</a></sup> Settlements founded on <a href="/wiki/Magdeburg_rights" title="Magdeburg rights">Magdeburg Law</a> evolved around <a href="/wiki/Town_square" title="Town square">central marketplaces</a> (<i>plac</i>, <i>rynek</i>), encircled by a grid or <a href="/wiki/Concentric_objects" title="Concentric objects">concentric</a> network of streets forming an <a href="/wiki/Old_town" title="Old town">old town</a> (<i>stare miasto</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">&#91;357&#93;</a></sup> Poland's traditional landscape is characterised by ornate churches, <a href="/wiki/Kamienica_(architecture)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kamienica (architecture)">city tenements</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ratusz" title="Ratusz">town halls</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">&#91;358&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cloth_hall" title="Cloth hall">Cloth hall markets</a> (<i>sukiennice</i>) were once an abundant feature of Polish urban architecture.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">&#91;359&#93;</a></sup> The mountainous south is known for its <a href="/wiki/Zakopane_Style" title="Zakopane Style">Zakopane chalet style</a>, which originated in Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">&#91;360&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The earliest architectonic trend was <a href="/wiki/Romanesque_architecture" title="Romanesque architecture">Romanesque</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 11th century), but its traces in the form of <a href="/wiki/Rotunda_(architecture)" title="Rotunda (architecture)">circular rotundas</a> are scarce.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">&#91;361&#93;</a></sup> The arrival of <a href="/wiki/Brick_Gothic" title="Brick Gothic">brick Gothic</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 13th century) defined Poland's most distinguishable medieval style, exuded by the castles of <a href="/wiki/Malbork_Castle" title="Malbork Castle">Malbork</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lidzbark_Castle" title="Lidzbark Castle">Lidzbark</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gniew_Castle" title="Gniew Castle">Gniew</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kwidzyn_Castle" title="Kwidzyn Castle">Kwidzyn</a> as well as the cathedrals of <a href="/wiki/Gniezno_Cathedral" title="Gniezno Cathedral">Gniezno</a>, <a href="/wiki/St._Mary%27s_Church,_Gda%C5%84sk" title="St. Mary&#39;s Church, GdaÅsk">GdaÅsk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw_Cathedral" title="WrocÅaw Cathedral">WrocÅaw</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frombork_Cathedral" class="mw-redirect" title="Frombork Cathedral">Frombork</a> and <a href="/wiki/St._Mary%27s_Basilica,_Krak%C3%B3w" title="St. Mary&#39;s Basilica, KrakÃ³w">KrakÃ³w</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">&#91;362&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_in_Poland" title="Renaissance in Poland">Renaissance</a> (16th century) gave rise to Italianate courtyards, defensive <a href="/wiki/Palazzo" class="mw-redirect" title="Palazzo">palazzos</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sigismund%27s_Chapel" title="Sigismund&#39;s Chapel">mausoleums</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">&#91;363&#93;</a></sup> Decorative <a href="/wiki/Attic_(architecture)" title="Attic (architecture)">attics</a> with <a href="/wiki/Pinnacle" title="Pinnacle">pinnacles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arcade_(architecture)" title="Arcade (architecture)">arcade</a> <a href="/wiki/Loggia" title="Loggia">loggias</a> are elements of <a href="/wiki/Mannerist_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Mannerist architecture">Polish Mannerism</a>, found in <a href="/wiki/Pozna%C5%84" title="PoznaÅ">PoznaÅ</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lublin" title="Lublin">Lublin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zamo%C5%9B%C4%87" title="ZamoÅÄ">ZamoÅÄ</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">&#91;364&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Mikos_369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mikos-369">&#91;365&#93;</a></sup> Foreign artisans often came at the expense of kings or nobles, whose palaces were built thereafter in the <a href="/wiki/Baroque_in_Poland" title="Baroque in Poland">Baroque</a>, <a href="/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture_in_Poland" title="Neoclassical architecture in Poland">Neoclassical</a> and <a href="/wiki/Revivalism_(architecture)" title="Revivalism (architecture)">Revivalist</a> styles (17thâ19th century).<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">&#91;366&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Primary building materials comprising <a href="/wiki/Lumber" title="Lumber">timber</a> or <a href="/wiki/Brick" title="Brick">red brick</a> were extensively utilised in Polish folk architecture,<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">&#91;367&#93;</a></sup> and the concept of a <a href="/wiki/Fortified_church" title="Fortified church">fortified church</a> was commonplace.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">&#91;368&#93;</a></sup> Secular structures such as <a href="/wiki/Dw%C3%B3r_(manor_house)" class="mw-redirect" title="DwÃ³r (manor house)"><i>dworek</i> manor houses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Farmhouses" class="mw-redirect" title="Farmhouses">farmsteads</a>, <a href="/wiki/Granary" title="Granary">granaries</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gristmill" title="Gristmill">mills</a> and country <a href="/wiki/Inn" title="Inn">inns</a> are still present in some regions or in open air museums (<i><a href="/wiki/Open-Air_Museum" class="mw-redirect" title="Open-Air Museum">skansen</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">&#91;369&#93;</a></sup> However, traditional construction methods faded in the early-mid 20th century due to urbanisation and the construction of <a href="/wiki/Functionalist_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Functionalist architecture">functionalist</a> <a href="/wiki/Housing_estate" title="Housing estate">housing estates</a> and <a href="/wiki/Residential_architecture_in_Poland" title="Residential architecture in Poland">residential areas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">&#91;370&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Polish_literature" title="Polish literature">Polish literature</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_philosophy_in_Poland" title="History of philosophy in Poland">History of philosophy in Poland</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:300px;max-width:300px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:156px;max-width:156px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Wa%C5%84kowicz_Adam_Mickiewicz.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Adam Mickiewicz" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Wa%C5%84kowicz_Adam_Mickiewicz.jpg/154px-Wa%C5%84kowicz_Adam_Mickiewicz.jpg" decoding="async" width="154" height="191" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Wa%C5%84kowicz_Adam_Mickiewicz.jpg/231px-Wa%C5%84kowicz_Adam_Mickiewicz.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Wa%C5%84kowicz_Adam_Mickiewicz.jpg/308px-Wa%C5%84kowicz_Adam_Mickiewicz.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1969" data-file-height="2437" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Adam_Mickiewicz" title="Adam Mickiewicz">Adam Mickiewicz</a>, whose <a href="/wiki/Epic_poetry" title="Epic poetry">national epic poem</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Pan_Tadeusz" title="Pan Tadeusz">Pan Tadeusz</a></i> (1834) is considered a masterpiece of <a href="/wiki/Polish_literature" title="Polish literature">Polish literature</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:140px;max-width:140px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Joseph_Conrad,_Fotografie_von_George_Charles_Beresford,_1904.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Joseph Conrad-Korzeniowski" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Joseph_Conrad%2C_Fotografie_von_George_Charles_Beresford%2C_1904.jpg/138px-Joseph_Conrad%2C_Fotografie_von_George_Charles_Beresford%2C_1904.jpg" decoding="async" width="138" height="191" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Joseph_Conrad%2C_Fotografie_von_George_Charles_Beresford%2C_1904.jpg/207px-Joseph_Conrad%2C_Fotografie_von_George_Charles_Beresford%2C_1904.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Joseph_Conrad%2C_Fotografie_von_George_Charles_Beresford%2C_1904.jpg/276px-Joseph_Conrad%2C_Fotografie_von_George_Charles_Beresford%2C_1904.jpg 2x" data-file-width="555" data-file-height="770" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Joseph_Conrad" title="Joseph Conrad">Joseph Conrad</a>, author of popular books such as <i><a href="/wiki/Heart_of_Darkness" title="Heart of Darkness">Heart of Darkness</a></i> (1899) and <i><a href="/wiki/Nostromo" title="Nostromo">Nostromo</a></i> (1904)</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Polish_literature" title="Polish literature">literary works of Poland</a> have traditionally concentrated around the themes of patriotism, <a href="/wiki/Spirituality" title="Spirituality">spirituality</a>, social <a href="/wiki/Allegory" title="Allegory">allegories</a> and moral narratives.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">&#91;371&#93;</a></sup> The earliest examples of Polish literature, written in <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a>, date to the 12th century.<sup id="cite_ref-Koca_2006_376-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Koca_2006-376">&#91;372&#93;</a></sup> The first <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a> phrase <i>Day ut ia pobrusa, a ti poziwai</i> (officially translated as "Let me, I shall grind, and you take a rest") was documented in the <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Henryk%C3%B3w" title="Book of HenrykÃ³w">Book of HenrykÃ³w</a> and reflected the use of a <a href="/wiki/Quern-stone" title="Quern-stone">quern-stone</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">&#91;373&#93;</a></sup> It has been since included in <a href="/wiki/Memory_of_the_World_Programme" title="Memory of the World Programme">UNESCO's Memory of World Register</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">&#91;374&#93;</a></sup> The oldest extant manuscripts of fine <a href="/wiki/Prose" title="Prose">prose</a> in <a href="/wiki/Old_Polish_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Old Polish language">Old Polish</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Cross_Sermons" title="Holy Cross Sermons">Holy Cross Sermons</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Bible_of_Queen_Sophia" title="Bible of Queen Sophia">Bible of Queen Sophia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">&#91;375&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Almanach_cracoviense_ad_annum_1474" title="Almanach cracoviense ad annum 1474">Calendarium cracoviense</a> (1474) is Poland's oldest surviving <a href="/wiki/Printing_press" title="Printing press">print</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">&#91;376&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The poets <a href="/wiki/Jan_Kochanowski" title="Jan Kochanowski">Jan Kochanowski</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Rey" class="mw-redirect" title="Nicholas Rey">Nicholas Rey</a> became the first <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_in_Poland" title="Renaissance in Poland">Renaissance</a> authors to write in Polish.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">&#91;377&#93;</a></sup> Prime literarians of the period included <a href="/wiki/Johannes_Dantiscus" title="Johannes Dantiscus">Dantiscus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andreus_Fricius_Modrevius" class="mw-redirect" title="Andreus Fricius Modrevius">Modrevius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wawrzyniec_Go%C5%9Blicki" title="Wawrzyniec GoÅlicki">Goslicius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Matthias_Sarbievius" class="mw-redirect" title="Matthias Sarbievius">Sarbievius</a> and theologian <a href="/wiki/John_Laski" class="mw-redirect" title="John Laski">John Laski</a>. In the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Baroque" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish Baroque">Baroque</a> era, <a href="/wiki/Jesuits" title="Jesuits">Jesuit philosophy</a> and local culture greatly influenced the literary techniques of <a href="/wiki/Jan_Andrzej_Morsztyn" title="Jan Andrzej Morsztyn">Jan Andrzej Morsztyn</a> (<a href="/wiki/Marinism" title="Marinism">Marinism</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Jan_Chryzostom_Pasek" title="Jan Chryzostom Pasek">Jan Chryzostom Pasek</a> (<a href="/wiki/Sarmatism" title="Sarmatism">sarmatian</a> memoirs).<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">&#91;378&#93;</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Enlightenment" title="Polish Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a>, playwright <a href="/wiki/Ignacy_Krasicki" title="Ignacy Krasicki">Ignacy Krasicki</a> composed the first Polish-language <a href="/wiki/The_Adventures_of_Mr._Nicholas_Wisdom" title="The Adventures of Mr. Nicholas Wisdom">novel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">&#91;379&#93;</a></sup> Poland's leading 19th-century <a href="/wiki/Romanticism_in_Poland" title="Romanticism in Poland">romantic poets</a> were the <a href="/wiki/Three_Bards" title="Three Bards">Three Bards</a> â <a href="/wiki/Juliusz_S%C5%82owacki" title="Juliusz SÅowacki">Juliusz SÅowacki</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zygmunt_Krasi%C5%84ski" title="Zygmunt KrasiÅski">Zygmunt KrasiÅski</a> and <a href="/wiki/Adam_Mickiewicz" title="Adam Mickiewicz">Adam Mickiewicz</a>, whose epic poem <i><a href="/wiki/Pan_Tadeusz" title="Pan Tadeusz">Pan Tadeusz</a></i> (1834) is a national classic.<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">&#91;380&#93;</a></sup> In the 20th century, the English <a href="/wiki/Impressionism_(literature)" title="Impressionism (literature)">impressionist</a> and early <a href="/wiki/Literary_modernism" title="Literary modernism">modernist</a> writings of <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Conrad" title="Joseph Conrad">Joseph Conrad</a> made him one of the most eminent novelists of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">&#91;381&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">&#91;382&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Contemporary Polish literature is versatile, with its fantasy genre having been particularly praised.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">&#91;383&#93;</a></sup> The philosophical <a href="/wiki/Science-fiction" class="mw-redirect" title="Science-fiction">sci-fi</a> novel <i><a href="/wiki/Solaris_(novel)" title="Solaris (novel)">Solaris</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_Lem" title="StanisÅaw Lem">StanisÅaw Lem</a> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Witcher" title="The Witcher">The Witcher</a></i> series by <a href="/wiki/Andrzej_Sapkowski" title="Andrzej Sapkowski">Andrzej Sapkowski</a> are celebrated works of world fiction.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">&#91;384&#93;</a></sup> Poland has six <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel-Prize winning</a> authors â <a href="/wiki/Henryk_Sienkiewicz" title="Henryk Sienkiewicz">Henryk Sienkiewicz</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Quo_Vadis_(novel)" title="Quo Vadis (novel)">Quo Vadis</a></i>; 1905), <a href="/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_Reymont" title="WÅadysÅaw Reymont">WÅadysÅaw Reymont</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/The_Peasants" title="The Peasants">The Peasants</a></i>; 1924), <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Bashevis_Singer" title="Isaac Bashevis Singer">Isaac Bashevis Singer</a> (1978), <a href="/wiki/Czes%C5%82aw_Mi%C5%82osz" title="CzesÅaw MiÅosz">CzesÅaw MiÅosz</a> (1980), <a href="/wiki/Wis%C5%82awa_Szymborska" title="WisÅawa Szymborska">WisÅawa Szymborska</a> (1996), and <a href="/wiki/Olga_Tokarczuk" title="Olga Tokarczuk">Olga Tokarczuk</a> (2018).<sup id="cite_ref-Facts_on_the_Nobel_Prize_in_Literature_389-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Facts_on_the_Nobel_Prize_in_Literature-389">&#91;385&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Gopnik_2007_390-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gopnik_2007-390">&#91;386&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">&#91;387&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Polish_cuisine" title="Polish cuisine">Polish cuisine</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:07425_Jahrmarkt_in_Sanok_am_17_Juli_2011.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/07425_Jahrmarkt_in_Sanok_am_17_Juli_2011.jpg/220px-07425_Jahrmarkt_in_Sanok_am_17_Juli_2011.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/07425_Jahrmarkt_in_Sanok_am_17_Juli_2011.jpg/330px-07425_Jahrmarkt_in_Sanok_am_17_Juli_2011.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/07425_Jahrmarkt_in_Sanok_am_17_Juli_2011.jpg/440px-07425_Jahrmarkt_in_Sanok_am_17_Juli_2011.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600" /></a><figcaption>Selection of popular traditional dishes from Poland, including <a href="/wiki/Bigos" title="Bigos">hunter's stew</a>, <a href="/wiki/Go%C5%82%C4%85bki" title="GoÅÄbki">stuffed cabbage rolls</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C5%BBurek" class="mw-redirect" title="Å»urek">rye soup</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pierogi" title="Pierogi">pierogi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Potato_pancakes" class="mw-redirect" title="Potato pancakes">potato pancakes</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rye_bread" title="Rye bread">rye bread</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>The cuisine of Poland is eclectic and shares similarities with other regional cuisines. Among the staple or regional dishes are <a href="/wiki/Pierogi" title="Pierogi">pierogi</a> (filled dumplings), <a href="/wiki/Kielbasa" title="Kielbasa">kielbasa</a> (sausage), <a href="/wiki/Bigos" title="Bigos">bigos</a> (hunter's stew), <a href="/wiki/Kotlet_schabowy" title="Kotlet schabowy">kotlet schabowy</a> (breaded cutlet), <a href="/wiki/Go%C5%82%C4%85bki" title="GoÅÄbki">goÅÄbki</a> (cabbage rolls), <a href="/wiki/Borscht" title="Borscht">barszcz</a> (borscht), <a href="/wiki/%C5%BBurek" class="mw-redirect" title="Å»urek">Å¼urek</a> (soured rye soup), <a href="/wiki/Oscypek" title="Oscypek">oscypek</a> (smoked cheese), and <a href="/wiki/Tomato_soup" title="Tomato soup">tomato soup</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Marc_Heine_392-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marc_Heine-392">&#91;388&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Strybel_2003_393-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Strybel_2003-393">&#91;389&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bagel" title="Bagel">Bagels</a>, a type of <a href="/wiki/Bread_roll" title="Bread roll">bread roll</a>, also originated in Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">&#91;390&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Traditional dishes are hearty and abundant in pork, potatoes, eggs, cream, mushrooms, regional herbs, and sauce.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">&#91;391&#93;</a></sup> Polish food is characteristic for its various kinds of <a href="/wiki/Kluski" title="Kluski">kluski</a> (soft dumplings), <a href="/wiki/Soup" title="Soup">soups</a>, cereals and a variety of breads and <a href="/wiki/Open_sandwich" title="Open sandwich">open sandwiches</a>. Salads, including <a href="/wiki/Mizeria" title="Mizeria">mizeria</a> (cucumber salad), <a href="/wiki/Coleslaw" title="Coleslaw">coleslaw</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sauerkraut" title="Sauerkraut">sauerkraut</a>, carrot and <a href="/wiki/Searing" title="Searing">seared beets</a>, are common. Meals conclude with a dessert such as <a href="/wiki/Cheesecake" title="Cheesecake">sernik</a> (cheesecake), <a href="/wiki/Makowiec_(pastry)" class="mw-redirect" title="Makowiec (pastry)">makowiec</a> (poppy seed roll), or <a href="/wiki/Napoleonka" title="Napoleonka">napoleonka</a> (<a href="/wiki/Mille-feuille" title="Mille-feuille">mille-feuille</a>) cream pie.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">&#91;392&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Traditional alcoholic beverages include honey <a href="/wiki/Mead_in_Poland" title="Mead in Poland">mead</a>, widespread since the 13th century, <a href="/wiki/Beer_in_Poland" title="Beer in Poland">beer</a>, wine and <a href="/wiki/Vodka" title="Vodka">vodka</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">&#91;393&#93;</a></sup> The world's first written mention of vodka originates from Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">&#91;394&#93;</a></sup> The most popular alcoholic drinks at present are beer and wine which took over from vodka more popular in the years 1980â1998.<sup id="cite_ref-beverages_399-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-beverages-399">&#91;395&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Grodziskie" title="Grodziskie">Grodziskie</a>, sometimes referred to as "Polish Champagne", is an example of a historical beer style from Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">&#91;396&#93;</a></sup> Tea remains common in Polish society since the 19th century, whilst coffee is drunk widely since the 18th century.<sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">&#91;397&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fashion_and_design">Fashion and design</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Category:Polish_fashion" title="Category:Polish fashion">Category:Polish fashion</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Robe_%C3%A0_la_Polonaise_MET_DT11155.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Robe_%C3%A0_la_Polonaise_MET_DT11155.jpg/150px-Robe_%C3%A0_la_Polonaise_MET_DT11155.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="188" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Robe_%C3%A0_la_Polonaise_MET_DT11155.jpg/225px-Robe_%C3%A0_la_Polonaise_MET_DT11155.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Robe_%C3%A0_la_Polonaise_MET_DT11155.jpg/300px-Robe_%C3%A0_la_Polonaise_MET_DT11155.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1488" data-file-height="1861" /></a><figcaption>Traditional <i><a href="/wiki/Polonaise_(clothing)" title="Polonaise (clothing)">polonaise</a></i> dresses, 1780â1785</figcaption></figure>
<p>Several Polish designers and stylists left a legacy of beauty inventions and cosmetics; including <a href="/wiki/Helena_Rubinstein" title="Helena Rubinstein">Helena Rubinstein</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maksymilian_Faktorowicz" class="mw-redirect" title="Maksymilian Faktorowicz">Maksymilian Faktorowicz</a>, who created a line of cosmetics company in California known as <a href="/wiki/Max_Factor" title="Max Factor">Max Factor</a> and formulated the term "make-up" which is now widely used as an alternative for describing cosmetics.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">&#91;398&#93;</a></sup> Faktorowicz is also credited with inventing modern <a href="/wiki/Eyelash_extensions" class="mw-redirect" title="Eyelash extensions">eyelash extensions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">&#91;399&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">&#91;400&#93;</a></sup> As of 2020, Poland possesses the sixth-largest cosmetic market in Europe. <a href="/wiki/Inglot_Cosmetics" title="Inglot Cosmetics">Inglot Cosmetics</a> is the country's largest beauty products manufacturer,<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">&#91;401&#93;</a></sup> and the retail store <a href="/wiki/Reserved" title="Reserved">Reserved</a> is the country's most successful clothing store chain.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">&#91;402&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Historically, fashion has been an important aspect of Poland's national consciousness or <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Poland" title="Culture of Poland">cultural manifestation</a>, and the country developed its own style known as <a href="/wiki/Sarmatism" title="Sarmatism">Sarmatism</a> at the turn of the 17th century.<sup id="cite_ref-Biedronska-Slota_2005_407-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Biedronska-Slota_2005-407">&#91;403&#93;</a></sup> The national dress and etiquette of Poland also reached the court at <a href="/wiki/Versailles" class="mw-redirect" title="Versailles">Versailles</a>, where French dresses inspired by Polish garments included <i><a href="/wiki/Polonaise_(clothing)" title="Polonaise (clothing)">robe Ã  la polonaise</a></i> and the <a href="/wiki/Witzchoura" title="Witzchoura">witzchoura</a>. The scope of influence also entailed furniture; rococo <a href="/wiki/Polish_bed" title="Polish bed">Polish beds</a> with <a href="/wiki/Canopy_bed" title="Canopy bed">canopies</a> became fashionable in French chÃ¢teaus.<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">&#91;404&#93;</a></sup> Sarmatism eventually faded in the wake of the 18th century.<sup id="cite_ref-Biedronska-Slota_2005_407-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Biedronska-Slota_2005-407">&#91;403&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Poland" title="Cinema of Poland">Cinema of Poland</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Andrzej_Wajda_1974.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Andrzej_Wajda_1974.jpg/220px-Andrzej_Wajda_1974.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="156" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Andrzej_Wajda_1974.jpg/330px-Andrzej_Wajda_1974.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Andrzej_Wajda_1974.jpg/440px-Andrzej_Wajda_1974.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2400" data-file-height="1702" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Andrzej_Wajda" title="Andrzej Wajda">Andrzej Wajda</a>, the recipient of an <a href="/wiki/Honorary_Oscar" class="mw-redirect" title="Honorary Oscar">Honorary Oscar</a>, the <span title="French-language text"><span lang="fr" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/Palme_d%27Or" title="Palme d&#39;Or">Palme d'Or</a></span></span>, as well as Honorary <a href="/wiki/Golden_Lion" title="Golden Lion">Golden Lion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Golden_Bear" title="Golden Bear">Golden Bear</a> awards</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Poland" title="Cinema of Poland">cinema of Poland</a> traces its origins to 1894, when inventor <a href="/wiki/Kazimierz_Pr%C3%B3szy%C5%84ski" title="Kazimierz PrÃ³szyÅski">Kazimierz PrÃ³szyÅski</a> patented the <a href="/wiki/Pleograph" title="Pleograph">Pleograph</a> and subsequently the <a href="/wiki/Aeroscope" title="Aeroscope">Aeroscope</a>, the first successful hand-held operated film camera.<sup id="cite_ref-Ford_2009_409-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ford_2009-409">&#91;405&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Haltof_2015_410-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haltof_2015-410">&#91;406&#93;</a></sup> In 1897, <a href="/wiki/Jan_Szczepanik" title="Jan Szczepanik">Jan Szczepanik</a> constructed the <a href="/wiki/Telectroscope" title="Telectroscope">Telectroscope</a>, a prototype of television transmitting images and sounds.<sup id="cite_ref-Ford_2009_409-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ford_2009-409">&#91;405&#93;</a></sup> They are both recognised as pioneers of <a href="/wiki/Cinematography" title="Cinematography">cinematography</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ford_2009_409-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ford_2009-409">&#91;405&#93;</a></sup> Poland has also produced influential directors, film producers and actors, many of whom were active in <a href="/wiki/Hollywood,_Los_Angeles" title="Hollywood, Los Angeles">Hollywood</a>, chiefly <a href="/wiki/Roman_Pola%C5%84ski" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman PolaÅski">Roman PolaÅski</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andrzej_Wajda" title="Andrzej Wajda">Andrzej Wajda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pola_Negri" title="Pola Negri">Pola Negri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Goldwyn" title="Samuel Goldwyn">Samuel Goldwyn</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Warner_Brothers" class="mw-redirect" title="Warner Brothers">Warner brothers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Max_Fleischer" title="Max Fleischer">Max Fleischer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Agnieszka_Holland" title="Agnieszka Holland">Agnieszka Holland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Krzysztof_Zanussi" title="Krzysztof Zanussi">Krzysztof Zanussi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Krzysztof_Kie%C5%9Blowski" title="Krzysztof KieÅlowski">Krzysztof KieÅlowski</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">&#91;407&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Film_genre" title="Film genre">themes</a> commonly explored in Polish cinema include <a href="/wiki/Historical_film" class="mw-redirect" title="Historical film">history</a>, <a href="/wiki/Drama_(film_and_television)" title="Drama (film and television)">drama</a>, war, culture and black realism (<a href="/wiki/Film_noir" title="Film noir">film noir</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-Ford_2009_409-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ford_2009-409">&#91;405&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Haltof_2015_410-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haltof_2015-410">&#91;406&#93;</a></sup> In the 21st-century, two Polish productions won the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Awards" title="Academy Awards">Academy Awards</a> â <i><a href="/wiki/The_Pianist_(2002_film)" title="The Pianist (2002 film)">The Pianist</a></i> (2002) by Roman PolaÅski and <i><a href="/wiki/Ida_(film)" title="Ida (film)">Ida</a></i> (2013) by <a href="/wiki/Pawe%C5%82_Pawlikowski" title="PaweÅ Pawlikowski">PaweÅ Pawlikowski</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Haltof_2015_410-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haltof_2015-410">&#91;406&#93;</a></sup> Polish cinematography also created many well-received comedies. The most known of them were made by <a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_Bareja" title="StanisÅaw Bareja">StanisÅaw Bareja</a> and <a href="/wiki/Juliusz_Machulski" title="Juliusz Machulski">Juliusz Machulski</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mass_media_in_Poland" title="Mass media in Poland">Mass media in Poland</a></div>
<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Eurobarometer" title="Eurobarometer">Eurobarometer Report</a> (2015), 78 percent of Poles watch the <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Poland" title="Television in Poland">television</a> daily.<sup id="cite_ref-Stepinska_2020_412-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stepinska_2020-412">&#91;408&#93;</a></sup> In 2020, 79 percent of the population read the news more than once a day, placing it second behind Sweden.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">&#91;409&#93;</a></sup> Poland has a number of major domestic media outlets, chiefly the <a href="/wiki/Public_broadcasting" title="Public broadcasting">public broadcasting</a> corporation <a href="/wiki/Telewizja_Polska" title="Telewizja Polska">TVP</a>, <a href="/wiki/Free-to-air" title="Free-to-air">free-to-air</a> channels <a href="/wiki/TVN_(Polish_TV_channel)" title="TVN (Polish TV channel)">TVN</a> and <a href="/wiki/Polsat" title="Polsat">Polsat</a> as well as 24-hour news channels <a href="/wiki/TVP_Info" title="TVP Info">TVP Info</a>, <a href="/wiki/TVN_24" class="mw-redirect" title="TVN 24">TVN 24</a> and <a href="/wiki/Polsat_News" title="Polsat News">Polsat News</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">&#91;410&#93;</a></sup> Public television extends its operations to genre-specific programmes such as <a href="/wiki/TVP_Sport" title="TVP Sport">TVP Sport</a>, <a href="/wiki/TVP_Historia" title="TVP Historia">TVP Historia</a>, <a href="/wiki/TVP_Kultura" title="TVP Kultura">TVP Kultura</a>, <a href="/wiki/TVP_Rozrywka" title="TVP Rozrywka">TVP Rozrywka</a>, TVP Seriale and <a href="/wiki/TVP_Polonia" title="TVP Polonia">TVP Polonia</a>, the latter a state-run channel dedicated to the transmission of Polish-language telecasts for the <a href="/wiki/Polish_diaspora" title="Polish diaspora">Polish diaspora</a>. In 2020, the most popular types of newspapers were <a href="/wiki/Tabloid_(newspaper_format)" title="Tabloid (newspaper format)">tabloids</a> and socio-political news dailies.<sup id="cite_ref-Stepinska_2020_412-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stepinska_2020-412">&#91;408&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Poland is a major European hub for video game developers and among the most successful companies are <a href="/wiki/CD_Projekt" title="CD Projekt">CD Projekt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Techland" title="Techland">Techland</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Farm_51" title="The Farm 51">The Farm 51</a>, <a href="/wiki/CI_Games" title="CI Games">CI Games</a> and <a href="/wiki/People_Can_Fly" title="People Can Fly">People Can Fly</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MarszaÅkowski_2021_415-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MarszaÅkowski_2021-415">&#91;411&#93;</a></sup> Some of the popular video games developed in Poland include <a href="/wiki/The_Witcher_(video_game_series)" title="The Witcher (video game series)">The Witcher</a> trilogy and <a href="/wiki/Cyberpunk_2077" title="Cyberpunk 2077">Cyberpunk 2077</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MarszaÅkowski_2021_415-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MarszaÅkowski_2021-415">&#91;411&#93;</a></sup> The Polish city of <a href="/wiki/Katowice" title="Katowice">Katowice</a> also hosts <a href="/wiki/Intel_Extreme_Masters" title="Intel Extreme Masters">Intel Extreme Masters</a>, one of the biggest <a href="/wiki/Esports" title="Esports">esports</a> events in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-MarszaÅkowski_2021_415-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MarszaÅkowski_2021-415">&#91;411&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Poland" title="Sport in Poland">Sport in Poland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Poland_at_the_Olympics" title="Poland at the Olympics">Poland at the Olympics</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:National_Stadium_Warsaw_aerial_view_2.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/National_Stadium_Warsaw_aerial_view_2.jpg/220px-National_Stadium_Warsaw_aerial_view_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/National_Stadium_Warsaw_aerial_view_2.jpg/330px-National_Stadium_Warsaw_aerial_view_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/National_Stadium_Warsaw_aerial_view_2.jpg/440px-National_Stadium_Warsaw_aerial_view_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4180" data-file-height="2349" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Stadion_Narodowy" title="Stadion Narodowy">Stadion Narodowy</a> in Warsaw, home of the <a href="/wiki/Poland_national_football_team" title="Poland national football team">national football team</a></figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Motorcycle_Speedway" class="mw-redirect" title="Motorcycle Speedway">Motorcycle Speedway</a>, volleyball and association football are among the country's most popular sports, with a rich history of international competitions.<sup id="cite_ref-FIFA_World_Cup_416-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FIFA_World_Cup-416">&#91;412&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FIFA_Statistics_417-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FIFA_Statistics-417">&#91;413&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Track_and_field_athletics" class="mw-redirect" title="Track and field athletics">Track and field</a>, basketball, <a href="/wiki/Handball" title="Handball">handball</a>, boxing, <a href="/wiki/Mixed_martial_arts" title="Mixed martial arts">MMA</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ski_jumping" title="Ski jumping">ski jumping</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cross-country_skiing_(sport)" title="Cross-country skiing (sport)">cross-country skiing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey" title="Ice hockey">ice hockey</a>, tennis, fencing, swimming, and <a href="/wiki/Olympic_weightlifting" title="Olympic weightlifting">weightlifting</a> are other popular sports.
The golden era of <a href="/wiki/Football_in_Poland" title="Football in Poland">football in Poland</a> occurred throughout the 1970s and went on until the early 1980s when the <a href="/wiki/Poland_national_football_team" title="Poland national football team">Polish national football team</a> achieved their best results in any FIFA World Cup competitions finishing third place in <a href="/wiki/1974_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1974 FIFA World Cup">the 1974</a> and <a href="/wiki/1982_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1982 FIFA World Cup">the 1982</a> tournaments. The team won a gold medal <a href="/wiki/Football_at_the_Summer_Olympics" title="Football at the Summer Olympics">in football</a> at the <a href="/wiki/1972_Summer_Olympics" title="1972 Summer Olympics">1972 Summer Olympics</a> and two silver medals, <a href="/wiki/1976_Summer_Olympics" title="1976 Summer Olympics">in 1976</a> and <a href="/wiki/1992_Summer_Olympics" title="1992 Summer Olympics">in 1992</a>. In 2012, Poland co-hosted the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012" title="UEFA Euro 2012">UEFA European Football Championship</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-warsaw-life_418-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-warsaw-life-418">&#91;414&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As of August 2023, the <a href="/wiki/Poland_men%27s_national_volleyball_team" title="Poland men&#39;s national volleyball team">Polish men's national volleyball team</a> is ranked <a href="/wiki/FIVB_World_Rankings" class="mw-redirect" title="FIVB World Rankings">as first</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">&#91;415&#93;</a></sup> The team won a gold medal at the <a href="/wiki/Volleyball_at_the_1976_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_tournament" title="Volleyball at the 1976 Summer Olympics â Men&#39;s tournament">1976 Summer Olympics</a> and the gold medal at the <a href="/wiki/FIVB_Volleyball_Men%27s_World_Championship" title="FIVB Volleyball Men&#39;s World Championship">FIVB World Championship</a> <a href="/wiki/1974_FIVB_Volleyball_Men%27s_World_Championship" title="1974 FIVB Volleyball Men&#39;s World Championship">1974</a>, <a href="/wiki/2014_FIVB_Volleyball_Men%27s_World_Championship" title="2014 FIVB Volleyball Men&#39;s World Championship">2014</a> and <a href="/wiki/2018_FIVB_Volleyball_Men%27s_World_Championship" title="2018 FIVB Volleyball Men&#39;s World Championship">2018</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">&#91;416&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">&#91;417&#93;</a></sup>
<a href="/wiki/Mariusz_Pudzianowski" title="Mariusz Pudzianowski">Mariusz Pudzianowski</a> is a highly successful strongman competitor and has won more <a href="/wiki/World%27s_Strongest_Man" title="World&#39;s Strongest Man">World's Strongest Man</a> titles than any other competitor in the world, winning the event in 2008 for the fifth time.<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">&#91;418&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Poland has made a distinctive mark <a href="/wiki/Speedway_in_Poland" title="Speedway in Poland">in motorcycle speedway racing</a>. The top <a href="/wiki/Speedway_Ekstraliga" class="mw-redirect" title="Speedway Ekstraliga">Ekstraliga</a> division has one of <a href="/wiki/List_of_attendance_figures_at_domestic_professional_sports_leagues#Outdoor_sports" title="List of attendance figures at domestic professional sports leagues">the highest average attendances</a> for any sport in Poland. The <a href="/wiki/Poland_national_speedway_team" title="Poland national speedway team">national speedway team of Poland</a> is one of the major teams in international speedway. Individually, Poland has three <a href="/wiki/Speedway_Grand_Prix" title="Speedway Grand Prix">Speedway Grand Prix</a> World Champions, with the most successful being three-time World Champion <a href="/wiki/Bartosz_Zmarzlik" title="Bartosz Zmarzlik">Bartosz Zmarzlik</a> who won back-to-back championships in 2019 and 2020 as well as 2022 and 2023. In 2021, Poland finished runners-up in the Speedway of Nations world championship final, held in <a href="/wiki/Manchester" title="Manchester">Manchester</a>, England in 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-Speedway_423-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Speedway-423">&#91;419&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 21st century, the country has seen a growth of popularity of tennis and produced a number of successful tennis players including World No. 1 <a href="/wiki/Iga_%C5%9Awi%C4%85tek" title="Iga ÅwiÄtek">Iga ÅwiÄtek</a>, winner of four <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slam</a> singles titles; former World No. 2 <a href="/wiki/Agnieszka_Radwanska" class="mw-redirect" title="Agnieszka Radwanska">Agnieszka Radwanska</a>, winner of 20 WTA career singles titles including <a href="/wiki/2015_WTA_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles" title="2015 WTA Finals â Singles">2015 WTA Finals</a>; Top 10 ATP player <a href="/wiki/Hubert_Hurkacz" title="Hubert Hurkacz">Hubert Hurkacz</a>; and former World No. 1 doubles player <a href="/wiki/%C5%81ukasz_Kubot" title="Åukasz Kubot">Åukasz Kubot</a> whose career highlights include winning two Grand Slam doubles titles â <a href="/wiki/2014_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_doubles" title="2014 Australian Open â Men&#39;s doubles">2014 Australian Open</a> and <a href="/wiki/2017_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_doubles" title="2017 Wimbledon Championships â Men&#39;s doubles">2017 Wimbledon Championships</a>. Poland also won the <a href="/wiki/2015_Hopman_Cup" title="2015 Hopman Cup">2015 Hopman Cup</a> with Agnieszka RadwaÅska and <a href="/wiki/Jerzy_Janowicz" title="Jerzy Janowicz">Jerzy Janowicz</a> representing the country.<sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">&#91;420&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">&#91;421&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Poles made significant achievements in mountaineering, in particular, in the <a href="/wiki/Himalayas" title="Himalayas">Himalayas</a> and the winter ascending of the <a href="/wiki/Eight-thousander" title="Eight-thousander">eight-thousanders</a>. Polish mountains are one of the tourist attractions of the country. Hiking, climbing, skiing and mountain biking and attract numerous tourists every year from all over the world.<sup id="cite_ref-UNTWO_2008_266-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNTWO_2008-266">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup> Water sports are the most popular summer recreation activities, with ample locations for fishing, canoeing, kayaking, sailing and windsurfing especially in the northern regions of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">&#91;422&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:left;" class=""></div>

A missionary bishopric directly dependent on the papacy was established in PoznaÅ. This was the true beginning of Polish history, for Christianity was a carrier of Western civilization with which Poland was henceforth associated."<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup></span>

<li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Poland/History">"Poland"</a>. <i>Encyclopedia Britannica</i>. 2023<span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>

<li id="cite_note-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-35">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFPrice2015" class="citation book cs1">Price, T. <li id="cite_note-60"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-60">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFKula2000" class="citation book cs1">Kula, Marcin (2000). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=VBa1AAAAIAAJ&amp;q=%25C5%2582okietek%25201320%2520zjednoczenie"><i>ZupeÅnie normalna historia, czyli, Dzieje Polski zanalizowane przez Marcina KulÄ w krÃ³tkich sÅowach, subiektywnie, ku poÅ¼ytkowi miejscowych i cudzoziemcÃ³w</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-Knoll_2011-76"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Knoll_2011_76-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Knoll_2011_76-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFPaul_W._Knoll2011" class="citation book cs1">Paul W. Political Realities and Social Constrains."</a>. In Howard Louthan; Gary B. Cohen; Franz A.J. Szabo (eds.). <i>Diversity and Dissent: Negotiating Religious Difference in Central Europe, 1500â1800</i>. Berghahn Books. pp.&#160;30â45. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-85745-109-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-85745-109-5"><bdi>978-0-85745-109-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Religious+Toleration+in+Sixteenth-Century+Poland.+Political+Realities+and+Social+Constrains.&amp;rft.btitle=Diversity+and+Dissent%3A+Negotiating+Religious+Difference+in+Central+Europe%2C+1500%E2%80%931800&amp;rft.pages=30-45&amp;rft.pub=Berghahn+Books&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-85745-109-5&amp;rft.au=Paul+W.+Knoll&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DKuzLNXpa-hYC%26pg%3DPA30&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APoland" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-117"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-117">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFKoryÅ2018" class="citation book cs1">KoryÅ, Piotr (2018). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=kKR8DwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA181&amp;q=january%2Buprising%2Beconomic"><i>Poland From Partitions to EU Accession: A Modern Economic History, 1772â2004</i></a>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-137"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-137">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFSnyder2015" class="citation book cs1">Snyder, Timothy (2015). <i>Black earth: the Holocaust as history and warning</i> (First&#160;ed.). </li>
<li id="cite_note-138"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-138">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMaterskiSzarota2009">Materski &amp; Szarota (2009)</a> <i>Quote:</i> Liczba Å»ydÃ³w i PolakÃ³w Å¼ydowskiego pochodzenia, obywateli II Rzeczypospolitej, zamordowanych przez NiemcÃ³w siÄga 2,7- 2,9 mln osÃ³b. <i>Translation:</i> The number of Jewish victims is estimated at 2,9 million. This was about 90% of the 3.3 million Jews living in prewar Poland. <i>Source:</i> IPN.</span>

<li id="cite_note-Korzeniewska_2020-187"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Korzeniewska_2020_187-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Korzeniewska_2020_187-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Korzeniewska_2020_187-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Korzeniewska_2020_187-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFKorzeniewskaHarnisz2020" class="citation book cs1">Korzeniewska, Ewa; Harnisz, Monika (2020). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=KGydDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA4&amp;dq=%22%2522poland%2522%2Boceanic%2Bcontinental%2Btemperate%2Bclimate%22"><i>Polish River Basins and Lakes</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-Azad_2021-188"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Azad_2021_188-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Azad_2021_188-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFAzadKhan2021" class="citation book cs1">Azad, Abdul Kalam; Khan, Mohammad Masud Kamal (2021). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=9OgGEAAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA6&amp;dq=%22annual%2Bseasonal%2Bmean%2Btemperature%2Bpoland%22"><i>Bioenergy Resources and Technologies</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-Anna_Chodubska_2020-189"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Anna_Chodubska_2020_189-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Anna_Chodubska_2020_189-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFZbigniew_UstrunulAgnieszka_WypychEwa_JakusikDawid_Biernacik2020" class="citation report cs1">Zbigniew Ustrunul; Agnieszka Wypych; Ewa Jakusik; Dawid Biernacik; Danuta Czekierda; Anna Chodubska (2020). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.imgw.pl/sites/default/files/2021-04/imgw-pib-klimat-polski-2020-opracowanie-final-eng-rozkladowki-min.pdf">Climate of Poland</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> (Report). Institute of Meteorology and Water Management â National Research Institute (IMGW). p.&#160;7<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-202"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-202">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFGwiazda2015" class="citation book cs1">Gwiazda, Anna (2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=VBk-CgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA67&amp;dq=%22sejm%2B%2Bd%2527Hondt%22"><i>Democracy in Poland: Representation, participation, competition and accountability since 1989</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-239"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-239">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFRybak2018" class="citation web cs1">Rybak, Marcin (6 December 2018). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://gazetawroclawska.pl/klient-kontra-ochrona-sklepu-czy-moga-nas-zatrzymac-przeszukac-legitymowac/ar/13722260">"Klient kontra ochrona sklepu. <li id="cite_note-Schwab_2011-258"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Schwab_2011_258-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFSchwab" class="citation web cs1">Schwab, Klaus. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GlobalCompetitivenessReport_2010-11.pdf">"The Global Competitiveness Report 2010â2011"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <li id="cite_note-275"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-275">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFGennady_FedorovAlexander_DruzhininElena_GolubevaDmitry_Subetto2019" class="citation book cs1">Gennady Fedorov; Alexander Druzhinin; Elena Golubeva; Dmitry Subetto; Tadeusz Palmowski (2019). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=VEa5DwAAQBAJ&amp;dq=%22polferries%22+unity+line+poland&amp;pg=PA203"><i>Baltic RegionâThe Region of Cooperation</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-307"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-307">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210306175740/http://ksng.gugik.gov.pl/english/files/act_on_national_minorities.pdf">"Act of 6 January 2005 on national and ethnic minorities and on the regional languages"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>GUGiK.gov.pl</i>. <li id="cite_note-368"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-368">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFMiÅobÄdzki1994" class="citation book cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source">MiÅobÄdzki, Adam (1994). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=QAMtAQAAIAAJ&amp;q=pa%25C5%2582ac%2520biskup%25C3%25B3w%2520kielce%2520manieryzm"><i>The architecture of Poland: a chapter of the European heritage</i></a> (in Polish). <li id="cite_note-Mikos-369"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Mikos_369-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Many designs imitated the arcaded courtyard and arched loggias of the Wawel palace. <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFMichael_J._MikoÅ" class="citation web cs1">Michael J. MikoÅ. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.staropolska.pl/ang/renaissance/Mikos_renaissance/Cultural_r.html">"Renaissance Cultural Background"</a>. <i>www.staropolska.pl</i>. p.&#160;9<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">23 April</span> 2009</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.staropolska.pl&amp;rft.atitle=Renaissance+Cultural+Background&amp;rft.pages=9&amp;rft.au=Michael+J.+Miko%C5%9B&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.staropolska.pl%2Fang%2Frenaissance%2FMikos_renaissance%2FCultural_r.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APoland" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-370"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-370">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFStanley2004" class="citation journal cs1">Stanley, John (2004). <li id="cite_note-MarszaÅkowski_2021-415"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-MarszaÅkowski_2021_415-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-MarszaÅkowski_2021_415-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-MarszaÅkowski_2021_415-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFMarszaÅkowskiBiedermannRutkowski2021" class="citation book cs1">MarszaÅkowski, Jakub; Biedermann, SÅawomir; Rutkowski, Eryk (2021). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.parp.gov.pl/storage/publications/pdf/GIofP_2021_FINAL.pdf"><i>The Game Industry of Poland</i></a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>.
